

\lx -a
\sf

\sn
\ge IMP
\de imperative ending for irregular verbs 'garrany' 'be' and 'wandany' 'fall'
\sd ZZ Verbal Inflection
\re

\va
\sc
\so
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf

\ee

\lf
\lv
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 02/May/2017

\lx -gujarra
\sf
\ps suf
\sn
\ge two
\de ending indicates two of something
\sd Y Word Endings
\re
\sy
\va
\sc
\so
\xv Ngarlu-ma-bawula baraj bunya jan.ga-gujarra-rlu.
\sfx
\xe The two girls found sugarbag.
\rf NH:CJ:1/1/95, ER:ESB:99
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 18/Jul/2018

\lx -nganyjug
\sf
\ps suf
\sn
\ge related.group
\de ending indicates a group of related things or people
\sd Y Word Endings

\re etc

\va
\sc

\sfx
\xe bread and everything

\sfx
\xe Nangari and her friends

\lx bunburru
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge everyone
\de everyone, the whole group
\sd N Description
\re everyone
\re group
\sy
\va
\sc
\so JC,CD:CJ:2018
\xv Yanin-balu Wirigwirig-jirri bunburru marlurluga.
\sfx
\xe All of the old men went to VRD.
\rf JC,CD:CJ:2018
\xv Yan.gula bunburru.
\sfx
\xe Let's all get up and go.
\rf ES:ESB:1994
\xv Baraj-barnalu binya niinii bunburru.
\sfx
\xe We found finches flying away in a flock.
\rf NH:CJ:10/7/98
\xv Gunama-ma bunburru yanan.
\sfx
\xe The flies are taking off.
\rf ER:ES03_n02_Ngar.004
\xv Wanyjarniny-bangandibanggulu, yanin-balu ganimbarra, bunburru.
\sfx
\xe They left us, and they all went off that way.
\rf NH:CJ:98, NH,IW:CJ:98
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf Jaminjung
\lv bunburr
\lf Mudburra
\lv bunburr
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 6/Aug/2018

\lx -ba
\sf
\ps suf
\sn
\ge BA
\de this joins a word that ends in a consonant to an ending (epenthetic syllable)
\sd Y Word Endings
\re linking element
\sy -wa
\va
\sc
\so
\xv Yanin-ba-lu Wirigwirig-jirri bunburru marlurluga.
\sfx
\xe All of the old men went to VRD.
\rf JC,CD:CJ:2018
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt

\lx -bari
\sf
\ps suf
\sn
\ge ADJ
\de ending used to describe the property of something, for example 'ngarrab-bari' is something which is hot. This is similar to '-ness' in English, for example 'darkness' (adjectival)
\sd Y Word Endings
\re
\sy -wari
\va
\sc
\so
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 6/Aug/2018

\lx -barla
\sf
\ps suf
\sn
\ge FOC
\de focus marker. It is used to draw attention to something in the sentence or contrast it with something else (as elderly speakers might say, 'this one now'). It is also used to link two events which happen one after the other. It translates as 'then' in these cases
\sd Y Word Endings
\re now
\re then
\sy -warla
\va
\sc
\so
\xv Yanda-warla!
\sfx
\xe Go now!
\rf ER:ES99_V01_01.203
\xv Marndaj-warla, nyawa-rni-warla jaru!
\xe All right, that's all I'm saying!
\rf ER:ES99_V01_04.083
\dt 6/Aug/2018
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf Kriol
\lv na
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt

\lx -biya
\sf
\ps suf
\sn 1
\ge BIT
\de a little bit
\sd Y Word Endings

\sy

\sc
\so NH,KJ:CJ:98, NH:CJ:2005
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc
\sn 2
\ge SEQ
\de this ending marks an event in sequence or a contrast, where something is different compared with what was previously talked about
\sd Y Word Endings

\sy
\va
\sc
\so
\xv
\sfx

\rf

\ee

\lx -g
\sf
\ps suf
\sn 1
\ge TO
\de to. This ending is only found on directional words and cardinal points (allative)
\sd Y Word Endings
\re to
\sy
\va
\sc
\so
\xv Yawarda-ma gayirra-g garra ngarlaga-ma.
\sfx
\xe The horse heads north
\rf NH:CJ:01/06/1995
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\sn 2
\ge FACT
\de make something happen (factive ending)
\sd Y Word Endings
\re resultative
\sy
\va
\sc
\so
\xv Ngurra mani gilga-g, Nimarra-rlu.
\sfx
\xe Nimarra has made the place clean.
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 08/May/2006

\lx -ga
\sf
\ps case
\sn 1
\ge LOC
\de this ending marks where something is located, such as 'at', 'on', 'in' (locative case ending)
\sd Y Word Endings
\re on
\re in
\re at
\sy -ngga, -rla, -gurla, -rda, -ja
\va
\sc
\so
\xv Marndaj burduj yuwarru-la-nga jawi ganyjungurlung garndi-ga.
\sfx
\xe All right we might light a fire underneath the tree (to kill the flying fox).
\rf ER:ES96_n01_Ngar.061
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc
\sn 2
\ge LOC
\de make something out of something else e.g. bread out of flour
\sd Y Word Endings
\re with
\sy
\va
\sc
\so
\xv Namawurru garndi-ga garrany dalag.
\sfx
\xe Tree sugarbag is sweet.
\rf ER:CM:2008
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc
\sn 3
\ge LOC
\de with another human
\sd Y Word Endings
\re
\sy
\va
\sc
\so
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc
\sn 4
\ge LOC
\de time period
\sd Y Word Endings
\re
\sy
\va
\sc
\so
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc
\sn 5
\ge LOC
\de purposeful goal
\sd Y Word Endings
\re
\sy
\va
\sc
\so
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc
\sn 6
\ge LOC
\de warning, aversive
\sd Y Word Endings
\re
\sy
\va
\sc
\so
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc
\dt 02/May/2017

\lx -gaji
\sf
\ps suf
\sn
\ge AGENT
\de person or thing that does something. This is the same as the English ending '-er', as in 'driver' (agentive)
\sd Y Word Endings
\re -er
\sy -waji
\va
\sc
\so
\xv Bulngayid-ngurlung yirr manan malang-jirri jindaba-rlu rarraj-gaji-rlu.
\sfx
\xe The other car is pulling it out of the floodwater, onto the other bank.
\rf NH:CJ:1/1/95; NH,JC:CJ,JM:2017
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc
\se rarrajgaji
\de motor; car (lit. 'running thing')
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\se durlggaji
\de rifle (lit. 'shooting thing')
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt

\lx -warra
\sf
\ps suf
\sn
\ge CONT
\de -ing, keep doing something (continuative)
\sd Y Word Endings
\re -ing
\sy -garra
\va
\sc
\so
\xv Janggarni-rla-lu-rla horse budubuduwarra gab bani bijimbat-balu bani.
\sfx
\xe In the big yard, he kept hitting at the horse hard on the flank.
\rf NH:CJ:5/6/95
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe

\lx -gijag
\sf
\ps suf
\sn 1
\ge UNTIL
\de until somebody or something has achieved some state (factive)
\sd Y Word Endings
\re
\sy -g
\va
\sc
\so SK:CJ:7/6/95, KJ:CJ:3/6/95
\xv Janggarni-gijag gambarlan-barna.
\sfx
\xe I treat (a baby) with heat so he gets strong.
\rf ER:ES99_V01_01.042
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf Bilinarra
\lv -gijag
\pc
\se dambang-gijag
\de until it's dead
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\sn 2
\ge UP.TO
\de as far as, up to, the extent of something (terminative ending)
\sd Y Word Endings
\re up to
\re as far as
\sy
\va
\sc
\so
\xv
\sfx

\rf
\ue
\ee

\dt 6/Aug/2018

\lx -gu
\sf
\ps case
\sn 1
\ge DAT
\de for. This ending marks a recipient or a person who receives something (dative case ending)
\sd Y Word Endings
\re for
\re to someone
\sy -wu
\va
\sc
\so
\xv Mangarri nyila-ma jalag-barna wuyarnin, stock camp-jirri, ngumbin-gu nyamu-lu warug yanin, dimarna-yawung.
\sfx
\xe I used to send that food to the stockcamp, for the men who were working with the horses.
\rf ER:ES08_A03_01.020-021
\xv Gimarrib-barla marla nyanuny-gu ngamayi-gu.
\sfx
\xe He is telling a lie to his mum.
\xv Dimana ngagagab marlan munggaj-gu.
\sfx
\xe The horse is whinnying, looking around for his wife.
\rf NH:JM:2015
\rf
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc
\sn 2
\ge DAT
\de about, of
\sd Y Word Endings
\re about, of
\va
\sc
\so
\xv Nangari-rlu marni-ngali barn.garrang-gu.
\sfx
\xe Nangari told you and me about the murderer.
\rf
\xv Garrany ngayi gawurru gula-rna bunyu ngayiny-gu gaminyjarr-wu.
\sfx
\xe I'm worried about my grandchildren.
\rf ER:CM:2007
\xv Burndurd garrany nyanuny-gu munggaj-gu.
\sfx
\xe He's proud of his wife.
\rf JC,CD:CJ:2018
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc
\sn 3
\ge DAT
\de for. This ending marks a person who benefits from another person's actions (benefactive)
\sd Y Word Endings
\re on behalf of
\va
\sc
\so
\xv Dubuluj nyanuny-gu mangarri-wu, wululu yuwarru-nga.
\sfx
\xe This is a bag for her tucker, she might put it inside.
\rf ER:KH06_a011_01
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc
\sn 4
\ge DAT
\de 's. This ending marks a person who owns something (possessive)
\sd Y Word Endings
\re own
\va
\sc
\so
\xv Nyila bulyja nyanbulanguny garu-gujarra-wu
\sfx
\xe That ball belongs to the two children.
\rf ER:KH06_a019_01tr_0150
\xv Judug-barni marlan-barna jaru-ma nyama Ngarinyman-ma ngayiny-gu ngamayi-wu.
\sfx
\xe I'm talking my mother's language, Ngarinyman, properly.
\rf BB:CM:07
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc
\sn 5
\ge DAT
\de to. This ending marks a person who is a goal
\sd Y Word Endings
\re
\va
\sc
\so
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc
\sn 6
\ge DAT
\de to, in order to. This ending marks the purpose of another action (purposive)
\sd Y Word Endings
\re
\va
\sc
\so
\xv Galbun-rdu-ngalang garrab nyangan, ngarin-gu.
\sfx
\xe The black kite is watching us for meat.
\rf ER:ES03_A03_02.110
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc
\sn 7
\ge DAT
\de purposive location. This ending marks a location and a purpose at the same time
\sd Y Word Endings
\re
\va
\sc
\so
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc
\sn 8
\ge DAT
\de this ending is used to show that the agent of the second verb is the same as the agent of the first verb (short clause marker)
\sd Y Word Endings
\re
\va
\sc
\so
\xv Wanyjanin-bangandibanggulu, yanin-balu ganimbarra, bunburr, garrab-gu gardiba-wu.
\sfx
\xe They left us, they all went off that way, to look at the whitefellas.
\rf NH:CJ:98
\xv Gub-barna mani, warnan-gu.
\sfx
\xe I took off my clothes to go to sleep.
\rf NH,KJ,JK:CJ:2005
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc
\dt 02/May/2017

\lx -gu
\sf
\ps case
\sn 1
\ge ERG
\de this ending marks the one who performs the action, the 'doer' or 'agent' (ergative case ending)
\sd Y Word Endings
\re
\sy -nggu, -rlu, -gurlu, -rdu, -ju
\va
\sc
\so
\xv Gurnbirlirn-gu bunyug manana garu.
\sfx
\xe A doctor makes kids better.
\rf NH:CJ:1/1/95, ER:CM:2008
\xv Jan.ga-gu wanyjarrany jurrb jarrajarraj-ngarna.
\sfx
\xe The girl is leaving the pencil there.
\rf NH:CJ:1/1/95
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc
\sn 2
\ge ERG
\de with. This ending marks an instrument, implement or weapon (instrumental)
\sd Y Word Endings
\re with
\va
\sc
\so
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc
\sn 3
\ge ERG
\de adverb agreement
\sd Y Word Endings
\re
\va
\sc
\so
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc
\dt 02/May/2017

\lx -gula
\sf
\ps pro
\sn
\ge 2DU.O
\de the two of you, you two
\sd Z Pronouns
\re you two
\sy -nggula, -wula, nyunbula
\va
\sc
\so SG:J94:C39
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt

\lx -gulu
\sf
\ps pro
\sn
\ge 3PL.S
\de they
\sd Z Pronouns
\re they
\sy -lu, -wulu, -luwa, nyarrulu
\va
\sc
\so SG:J94
\xv Bilg-gulu wanyjani ngamayi-ma.
\sfx
\xe They left their mother.
\rf BB:CM:2007
\ee
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt

\lx -gurla
\sf
\ps case
\sn 1
\ge LOC
\de this ending marks where something is located, such as 'at', 'on', 'in' (locative case ending)
\sd Y Word Endings
\re on
\re in
\re at
\sy -ngga, -ga, -rla, -rda, -ja
\va
\sc
\so
\xv Ngamanburru-n gardag-gurla yuwani?
\sfx
\xe Did you put the white currants in the billycan?
\rf NH:CJ:21/06/1995
\xv Murlangga garra balyja-ngga nangulyug-gurla. Balyja nangulyug.
\sfx
\xe He's sitting down on the soft blanket. That blanket is soft.
\rf NH:CJ:3/1/95
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc
\sn 2
\ge LOC
\de make something out of something else e.g. bread out of flour
\sd Y Word Endings
\re with
\sy
\va
\sc
\so
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc
\sn 3
\ge LOC
\de with another human
\sd Y Word Endings
\re
\sy
\va
\sc
\so
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc
\sn 4
\ge LOC
\de time period
\sd Y Word Endings
\re
\sy
\va
\sc
\so
\xv Barung-gurla, magurru-rla bush jaju-warla garrinya, balarrgu.
\sfx
\xe In the wet season, and the cold time, my granny used to be in the bush, 'outside'.
\rf NH:CJ:2/6/95
\xv Medicine-murlung-gurla nyila-ma-rnalu darug wanda.
\sfx
\xe In the time before there was European medicine, we would bathe.
\rf NH:CJ:4/1/95
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc
\sn 5
\ge LOC
\de purposeful goal
\sd Y Word Endings
\re
\sy
\va
\sc
\so
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc
\sn 6
\ge LOC
\de warning, aversive
\sd Y Word Endings
\re
\sy
\va
\sc
\so
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc
\dt 02/May/2017

\lx -gurlu
\sf
\ps case
\sn 1
\ge ERG
\de this ending marks the one who performs the action, the 'doer' or 'agent' (ergative case ending)
\sd Y Word Endings
\re
\sy -nggu, -gu, -rlu, -rdu, -ju
\va
\sc
\so
\xv Bagayawung-gurlu nyangan muyu-biji-rni.
\sfx
\xe Echidnas eat only ants.
\rf DR/LR/CP : ES12_N03_Ngar_Ngali.017
\xv Burruwib-gurlu gamang mani.
\sfx
\xe The wind wiped away (the tracks).
\rf NH:JM1-020 2016 book 2, p55
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc
\sn 2
\ge ERG
\de with. This ending marks an instrument, implement or weapon (instrumental)
\sd Y Word Endings
\re with
\va
\sc
\so
\xv Ngarrabbari-yawung-gurlu-yilu gambarni.
\sfx
\xe They ?cooked? me with the hot stuff.
\rf NH:CJ:1995-06-07
\xv Daj barrany ngarina yingilg wumara-yawung-gurlu.
\sfx
\xe She's smashing up the beef for stew with a rock.
\rf JT:JM1-012 2016 book 2, p6
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc
\sn 3
\ge ERG
\de adverb agreement
\sd Y Word Endings
\re
\va
\sc
\so
\xv Gambarriyang-gurlu gambarni-lu ngarin jardgarra-wu.
\sfx
\xe Before, they used to cook it the meat for eating.
\rf NH:CJ:1/6/95
\xv Gurrirrinjarrij gula-lu garrab nyangga, ngajig-gurlu, ngaja-nggu nguj yuwarra. Nguj-giyan nyama.
\sfx
\xe You can't look at Gurrirrinjarrij for a long time, or it might put a curse on you. It's a cursed place.
\rf NH,IW:CJ:98
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc
\dt 02/May/2017

\lx -gurra
\sf
\ps case
\sn 1
\ge ALL
\de to. This ending is used to mark goals (allative case ending). It is not always used on place names. Human goals are marked with '-wu' or '-gu' (dative case ending)
\sd Y Word Endings
\re to
\sy -nggurra, -jirri, -yirri
\va
\sc
\so
\xv Jigamurru-lu manani, nya, gayiliyirra Gayanggayang-gurra ganyang-barnalu.
\sfx
\xe They collected water lily, yeah, we took them north to Gayanggayang.
\rf NH:CJ:2/1/95
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc
\dt 02/May/2017

\dt 21/Jun/2017

\lx -jawung
\sf
\ps suf
\sn 1
\ge PROP
\de with (proprietive). This ending is used when you have something. It is also used to describe a property of something
\sd Y Word Endings
\re have
\re possess
\sy -yawung, -mij
\va -jawu, -jang
\sc
\so
\xv Gid wanda nyila garndi janggarni mun.gud-jawung.
\sfx
\xe The big tree broke, it has white ants in it.
\rf KJ:JM1-019 2016 book 2, p50
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc
\sn 2
\ge COM
\de with (comitative). This ending is used when you are accompanied by something
\sd Y Word Endings
\re with
\sy
\va
\sc
\so
\xv Yibu yanan, dururrb-jawung.
\sfx
\xe Rain is coming, with thunder.
\rf MW:CJ:94 , NH,KJ:CJ:98
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc
\sn 3
\ge PROP
\de with (instrumental). This ending is used when you use something else
\sd Y Word Endings
\re
\sy
\va
\sc
\so
\xv Gula-rnalu gurrurrij-jawung yanarni!
\sfx
\xe We didn't come with a car!
\rf ER:ES99_V01_04.029
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc
\sn 4
\ge PROP
\de this ending is used to show what language is being spoken in
\sd Y Word Endings
\re
\sy
\va
\sc
\so
\xv Gula-n English-jawung marni!
\sfx
\xe Don't say it in English!
\rf ER:ES94_A08_01.014
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc
\dt 6/Aug/2018

\lx -jirri
\sf
\ps case
\sn 1
\ge ALL
\de to. This ending is used to mark goals (allative case ending). It is not always used on place names. Human goals are marked with '-wu' or '-gu' (dative case ending)
\sd Y Word Endings
\re to
\sy -nggurra, -gurra, -yirri
\va
\sc
\so
\xv Yanin-balu Wirigwirig-jirri bunburru marlurluga.
\sfx
\xe All of the old men went to VRD.
\rf JC,CD:CJ:2018
\xv Rarraj yanin-bawula jambarn-jirri gan.gula jarriny-jirri diliwud gujarra.
\sfx
\xe The two tawny frogmouths ran up into the hole, into a cave.
\rf ER:CM: 2006
\xv Jurlurl yuwarrany ngabulu gardag-jirri.
\sfx
\xe She's pouring milk into a cup.
\rf JT:JM1-009 2016 book 1, p87
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc
\sn 2
\ge ALL
\de this ending is used to show that the agent of the second verb is the same as the object of the first verb (short clause marker)
\sd Y Word Endings
\re
\sy
\va
\sc
\so
\xv Buny manda warnan-jirri.
\sfx
\xe Kiss him so he goes to sleep.
\rf ER:CM:2008
\xv Garrab-barnanggu nyanga nyila jarrwajarrwaj-jirri.
\sfx
\xe I'm looking at you writing there.
\rf NH,KJ:CJ:6/6/95
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc
\dt 02/May/2017

\sd Y Word Endings

\sfx
\xe I don't know, my grandmother told me that story.

\lx -murlung
\sf
\ps suf
\sn 1
\ge PRIV
\de without, lacking something (privative)
\sd Y Word Endings
\re without
\re lacking
\sy
\va
\sc
\so RB, ER:ESB
\xv Ngayi-ma wan.gaj-barna, mangarri-murlung-barna garrany.
\sfx
\xe Poor me, I have no food.
\rf ER:CM:2007
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf
\lv

\lx -ngga

\ps case
\sn 1
\ge LOC
\de this ending marks where something is located, such as 'at', 'on', 'in' (locative case ending)
\sd Y Word Endings
\re on
\re in
\re at
\sy -ga, -rla, -gurla, -rda, -ja
\va

\sfx
\xe He's sitting down on the soft blanket. That blanket is soft.

\xv Barn garrinya gan.gula. Gula jarrg waninya ngawa-ngga, magany.

\lx -nggurra
\sf
\ps case
\sn 1
\ge ALL
\de to. This ending is used to mark goals (allative case ending). It is not always used on place names. Human goals are marked with '-wu' or '-gu' (dative case ending)
\sd Y Word Endings
\re to
\sy -gurra, -jirri, -yirri
\va
\sc
\so
\xv Maitbi-nga darrmarrb-ma garrany, maitbi-nga yanirnin ngawa-nggurra barayi-jirri.
\sfx
\xe Maybe there are freshwater crocodiles, or maybe they went to the big water.
\rf ER:ES99_N02_Ngar.0135
\xv Ngayi-rna jan.gurr yanan ngawa-nggurra
\sfx
\xe I'm diving into the water.
\rf NH:JM,CS:2015-07-16
\xv Nyila-ma jarrbib yuwanin-bayi ngamayi-rlu-ma, gawarla-nggurra yuwani.
\sfx
\xe The mother used to lift me with that and put it, she put it in the coolamon.
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc
\dt 02/May/2017

\lx -nginyi
\sf
\ps case
\sn 1
\ge SOURCE
\de comes from (source case ending)
\sd Y Word Endings
\re from
\sy
\va
\sc
\so
\xv Garrinyang-barna jardgarra, ngarin, mangarri, barn.gurdi-nginyi ngayiny-nginyi.
\sfx
\xe I was eating meat and tucker from my cross-cousin.
\rf JM:ES12_A01_03.065-067
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc
\sn 2
\ge SOURCE
\de originates from somewhere
\sd Y Word Endings
\re origin
\sy
\va
\sc
\so
\xv Gula-rna-rla bina nyila ngumbin. Ngurragari-nginyi.
\sfx
\xe I don't know that man. He's from a different place.
\rf NH:CJ:1/1/95
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc
\sn 3
\ge SOURCE
\de make something out of something else
\sd Y Word Endings
\re out of
\sy
\va
\sc
\so
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc
\sn 4
\ge SOURCE
\de cause or reason
\sd Y Word Endings
\re cause
\sy
\va
\sc
\so
\xv Miyil-warna darn garrany gunama-nginyi.
\sfx
\xe My eyes are swollen from the flies.
\rf ER, ES05_n02_Ngar.005
\xv Wugarra-rla garrany gulyjany-nginyi.
\sfx
\xe He's scared of the snake.
\rf CJ95_n03_Ngar
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc
\sn 5
\ge SOURCE
\de after, because of. This ending is used to show that one action occurred before the other (switch reference marker)
\sd Y Word Endings
\re after, because of
\sy
\va
\sc
\so
\xv Mudab-nginyi yanarnin-bawula jawurrug.
\sfx
\xe After hunting, those two are coming down (off the hill).
\rf NH:CJ:1/1/95, NH:CJ:5/6/95
\xv Janga-rna garra gulygulyab-nginyi.
\sfx
\xe I'm sick with this cold.
\rf NH:CJ:98
\xv Ngaag marni warlagu, garan-nginyi.
\sfx
\xe The dog is whining because it's uncomfortable from itching.
\rf JC,CD:CJ:2018
\xv Warlayi-nginyi ngarin binangga-yi.
\sfx
\xe Give me some roasted beef.
\rf ER:ESB:99
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc
\dt 02/May/2017

\lx -ngurlung
\sf
\ps case
\sn 1
\ge ABL
\de from (ablative case ending)
\sd Y Word Endings
\re from
\re after
\sy
\va -ngurlu
\sc
\so
\xv Girrawa bad yanin jarriny-ngurlung.
\sfx
\xe The goanna came out of the hole.
\rf LR:CM:06/12/06
\xv Galu-rnalu yanin Auvergne-ngurlu-ma gan.garra Bulla-nggurra Gurrbijim-jirri.
\sfx
\xe We walked from Auvergne to Bulla.
\rf ER:JD:2006, NH,KJ:CJ:98
\xv Gub mana jinba wardan-ngurlu.
\sfx
\xe She pulled the burr out of her hand.
\rf JT:JM1-010 2016 book 1, p101.
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc
\sn 2
\ge ABL
\de make something out of something else
\sd Y Word Endings
\re out of
\sy
\va
\sc
\so
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc
\sn 3
\ge ABL
\de by, of
\sd Y Word Endings
\re by
\re of
\sy
\va
\sc
\so
\xv Gulyjany-ngurlung wugarra-rla garrany.
\sfx
\xe He's scared of the snake.
\rf CJ95_n03_Ngar
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc
\dt 02/May/2017

\lx -rni
\sf
\ps suf
\sn 1
\ge HITH
\de this way, hither. This ending is only found on some verbs
\sd Y Word Endings
\re this way
\re hither
\sy -rniny
\va
\sc
\so
\xv Gula-rnalu gurrurrij-jawung yanarni!
\sfx
\xe We didn't come with a car!
\rf ER:ES99_V01_04.029
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\sn 2
\ge ONLY
\de just, only, right at a place, directly, really
\sd Y Word Endings
\re only
\re just
\re right at a place
\sy
\va
\sc
\so
\xv Marndaj-warla, nyawa-rni-warla jaru!
\ft All right, that's all I'm saying!
\rf ER:ES99_V01_04.083
\xv Jungguwurru-ma yanarni ngijingga-rla-rni dumab.
\sfx
\xe The echidna only goes out hunting at night.
\rf NH:CJ:10/7/98
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc
\se -rnirni
\de only
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf

\lx -wari
\sf
\ps suf
\sn
\ge ADJ
\de ending used to describe the property of something, for example 'ngarrab-bari' is something which is hot. This is similar to '-ness' in English, for example 'darkness' (adjectival)
\sd Y Word Endings
\re
\sy -bari
\va
\sc
\so JT,ES:JM1-029 2016
\xv Jabal-walu garrany garu ngandu-wari.
\sfx
\xe They're talking too much, like kids.
\rf JT:JM1-029 2016 book 3, p5
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 07/Sep/2018

\lx -warla
\sf
\ps suf
\sn
\ge FOC
\de focus marker. It is used to draw attention to something in the sentence or contrast it with something else (as elderly speakers might say, 'this one now'). It is also used to link two events which happen one after the other. It translates as 'then' in these cases
\sd Y Word Endings
\re now
\re then
\sy -barla
\va
\sc
\so
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf Kriol
\lv na
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt

\lx -wu
\sf
\ps case
\sn 1
\ge DAT
\de for. This ending marks a recipient or a person who receives something (dative case ending)
\sd Y Word Endings
\re for
\re to someone
\sy -gu
\va
\sc
\so
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc
\sn 2
\ge DAT
\de about, of
\sd Y Word Endings
\re about, of
\re of
\va
\sc
\so
\xv Garrany ngayi gawurru gula-rna bunyu ngayiny-gu gaminyjarr-wu.
\sfx
\xe I'm worried about my grandchildren.
\rf ER:CM:2007
\xv Ngamanburru-wu guliwarrb garrinya nyila winini.
\sfx
\xe The baby emus were grumbling for the conkerberries.
\rf BB:CM:07
\xv Janginyina-wu wugarra garrany nyila garu.
\sfx
\xe That kid is frightened of the storm.
\rf NH:CJ:1/1/95 , ER:CM:2008
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc
\sn 3
\ge DAT
\de for. This ending marks a person who benefits from another person's actions (benefactive)
\sd Y Word Endings
\re on behalf of
\va
\sc
\so
\xv Dubuluj nyanuny-gu mangarri-wu, wululu yuwarru-nga.
\sfx
\xe This is a bag for her tucker, she might put it inside.
\rf ER:KH06_a011_01
\xv Jawardirla yinbawu-nbula ngurra-wu nyunbulany-gu.
\sfx
\xe Tomorrow you two are going to sing for your country.
\rf NH:CJ:21/06/1995
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc
\sn 4
\ge DAT
\de 's. This ending marks a person who owns something (possessive)
\sd Y Word Endings
\re own
\va
\sc
\so
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc
\sn 5
\ge DAT
\de to. This ending marks a person who is a goal
\sd Y Word Endings
\re
\va
\sc
\so
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc
\sn 6
\ge DAT
\de to, in order to. This ending marks the purpose of another action (purposive)
\sd Y Word Endings
\re
\va
\sc
\so
\xv Jardulgurru manda-yi, ganggu-rna-nga mangarri-wu birrgabirrgab-gu.
\sfx
\xe Get a dish for me; I want to take it to make damper.
\rf ER: ES01_n01_Ngar.018
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc
\sn 7
\ge DAT
\de purposive location. This ending marks a location and a purpose at the same time
\sd Y Word Endings
\re
\va
\sc
\so
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc
\sn 8
\ge DAT
\de this ending is used to show that the agent of the second verb is the same as the agent of the first verb (short clause marker)
\sd Y Word Endings
\re
\va
\sc
\so
\xv Wanyjanin-bangandibanggulu, yanin-balu ganimbarra, bunburr, garrab-gu gardiba-wu.
\sfx
\xe They left us, they all went off that way, to look at the whitefellas.
\rf NH:CJ:98
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc
\dt 02/May/2017

\lx -yawung
\sf
\ps suf
\sn 1
\ge PROP
\de with (proprietive). This ending is used when you have something. It is also used to describe a property of something
\sd Y Word Endings
\re have
\re possess
\sy -jawung, -mij
\va -yawu, -yang
\sc
\so
\xv Yawu-yawung nyila gan.gaba.
\sfx
\xe There's plenty of fish upstream.
\rf NP:ESB:1994
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc
\sn 2
\ge COM
\de with (comitative). This ending is used when you are accompanied by something
\sd Y Word Endings
\re with
\sy
\va
\sc
\so
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc
\sn 3
\ge PROP
\de with (instrumental). This ending is used when you use something else
\sd Y Word Endings
\re
\sy
\va
\sc
\so
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc
\sn 4
\ge PROP
\de this ending is used to show what language is being spoken in
\sd Y Word Endings
\re
\sy
\va
\sc
\so
\xv Manyja Ngarinyman-jawung!
\sfx
\xe Talk in Ngarinyman!
\rf
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc
\dt 07/Sep/2018

\lx -yirri
\sf
\ps case
\sn 1
\ge ALL
\de to. This ending is used to mark goals (allative case ending). It is not always used on place names. Human goals are marked with '-wu' or '-gu' (dative case ending)
\sd Y Word Endings
\re to
\sy -nggurra, -gurra, -yirri
\va
\sc
\so
\xv Langgarna-yirri yan.gu-rnalu jigamurru-wu.
\sfx
\xe We're going to the billabong for water lilies.
\rf NP:CM:10/06
\xv Mardumardu-yirri walyag waninyang.
\sfx
\xe He went inside the termite mound.
\rf ER:CM:2007
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc
\sn 2
\ge ALL
\de this ending is used to show that the agent of the second verb is the same as the object of the first verb (short clause marker)
\sd Y Word Endings
\re
\sy
\va
\sc
\so
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf
\lv

\lx baga

\ge prickle.bush

\dt 6/Aug/2018


\lx bagabaga
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge porcupine
\de porcupine, echidna, anteater
\sd H Mammals
\re porcupine
\re echidna
\re Tachyglossus aculeatus
\sy jungguwurru
\sy bagayawung
\sy nyinyiwurdu
\va
\sc Tachyglossus aculeatus
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This name for echidna refers to its spines. They often live in rocky country and are most active at night when they walk around looking for food. They are most active during full moon periods in the cold weather of the dry season. When they walk they leave a little track where the prickles drag along the ground. When approached they roll into a tight ball to protect themselves. They are often found in crevices in rocks and can be pulled out with a hooked branch or piece of wire. The prickles and feet are chopped off with a tomahawk prior to cooking the whole body in a ground oven. The meat is sweet and tastes like pork. There is a powerful creation period story about 'jungguwurru' that relates to how he got his prickles. It is a Dreaming animal for some people.
\cf
\pc echidna.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 09/Sep/2015

\lx bagalidbagalid
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge tawny.frogmouth
\de tawny frogmouth, mopoke
\sd J Birds
\re frogmouth (tawny)
\re mopoke
\re Podargus strigoides
\sy diliwud
\va
\sc Podargus strigoides
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This bird looks like a dead stick in a tree because it sits quite still. On full moons, they all sit together and make a singing noise, moving from side to side.
\cf
\pc tawny_frogmouth.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 08/Sep/2015

\dt 06/Apr/2018

\lx bagarli
\sf
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge grey.paperbark
\de grey paperbark
\sd M Plants
\re paperbark (grey)
\re grey paperbark
\re Melaleuca argentea
\sy
\va
\sc Melaleuca argentea
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This tree has grey-coloured leaves and generally occurs on river banks. It is often called 'river bagarli'. It produces very sweet smelling flowers that are like perfume. Flying-foxes (warrba) and native bees (lanu) visit the flowers to get nectar and pollen. The papery bark can be used to make bush houses, blankets and shelters for the wet season. When a flying-fox colony roosts in these trees overhanging rivers, there are often crocodiles under them and it can be a dangerous place to fish or camp.
\cf
\pc bagarli.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\sn 2
\ge river.paperbark
\de river paperbark
\sd M Plants
\re paperbark (river)
\re river paperbark
\re Melaleuca leucadendra
\sy
\va
\sc Melaleuca leucadendra
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This is a large tree that grows near rivers and springs. It can have very large sheets of bark on the trunks if it has not been harvested for a long time. The leaves are boiled in water and the cooled liquid which is dark coloured and smells like medicine is used as a wash to treat colds and congestion. The bark can be used to make a soft lining to fill a coolamon for a baby to sleep in. In the past the bark was used to make waterproof roof and walls for a humpy. The bark is also used to protect meat when cooking it in a ground oven.
\cf
\se
\de
\xv Yawu-ma-rnalu ganyang bagarli-rla julujuluj, guyi, ganinbarra.
\sfx
\xe We used to carry back fish in a coolamon, like this, upstream.
\rf ER : ES99_V01_02.076
\sn 3
\ge paper
\de paper, book
\sd D Things
\re paper
\re book
\sy
\va
\sc
\so
\xv Nyawa-warla-rna mani bagarli, warlayarra-wu.
\sfx
\xe I got you this cigarette paper.
\rf CP : ES12_A09_17.034
\ue
\ee
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 6/Aug/2018

\lx bagayawung
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge porcupine
\de porcupine, echidna, anteater
\sd H Mammals
\re porcupine
\re echidna
\re Tachyglossus aculeatus

\sc Tachyglossus aculeatus

\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This name for echnida refers to its spines. They often live in rocky country and are most active at night when they walk around looking for food. They are most active during full moon periods in the cold weather of the dry season. When they walk they leave a little track where the prickles drag along the ground. When approached they roll into a tight ball to protect themselves. They are often found in crevices in rocks and can be pulled out with a hooked branch or piece of wire. The prickles and feet are chopped off with a tomahawk prior to cooking the whole body in a ground oven. The meat is sweet and tastes like pork. There is a powerful creation period story about 'jungguwurru' that relates to how he got his prickles. It is a Dreaming animal for some people.
\cf
\pc echidna.jpg
\se

\xv Bagayawung-gurlu nyangan muyu-biji-rni.

\rf DR/LR/CP : ES12_N03_Ngar_Ngali.017

\lx balmij
\sf
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge red.root
\de red root
\sd M Plants
\re red root
\re Haemodorum coccineum
\sy
\va
\sc Haemodorum coccineum
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The tuberous roots are dug up and chipped into small pieces. This can then be added to fibres in boiling water to dye the fibres which can then be used to make dilly-bags and other fibre crafts. The roots produce red and yellow-brown colours. The fruit can be used in a similar way to make purple dyes.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\sn 2
\ge red.root
\de red root
\sd M Plants
\re Haemodorum ensifolium
\sy
\va
\sc Haemodorum ensifolium
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The fruit are crushed and used as a red dye for fibre-crafts or as a red paint.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 28/Aug/2015

\rf
\ue
\ee The timber is good firewood. Boomerangs may be made from the hard wood. The bark is chipped off and boiled in water and the liquid is used as external wash to treat skin problems and colds; a little can be drunk to treat colds. Sugarbag (native bee-hives) can be found in this tree. The sugar-leaf, sweet edible lerps, collected from 'baranybarany' is called 'malangarna'.
\cf
\pc lunyja2.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 25/Aug/2015

\dt 6/Aug/2018

\lx bardigi
\sf
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge nut.tree
\de nut tree
\sd M Plants
\re nut tree
\re Terminalia arostrata
\sy
\va
\sc Terminalia arostrata
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The hard dark fruit called 'janybarlg' is broken open and the seed inside is eaten. In the old days the fruit were cracked open with the back of a woomera, now an axe or hammer is often used. It is similar to a peanut and is pleasant tasting. The leaves are boiled in water and the liquid used as a wash to treat itchy skin or scabies. The timber is good firewood. The outer bark produces fine black soot when it is burnt. This can be used as colour during ceremonies. In the past it was rubbed onto the skin of pale-skinned babies so that the welfare officers would not take them away.
\cf janybarlg
\pc bardigi.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\sn 2
\ge nut.tree
\de nut tree
\sd M Plants
\re Terminalia grandiflora
\sy
\va
\sc Terminalia grandiflora
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The hard dark fruit is broken open and the seed inside is eaten. It is similar to a peanut and is pleasant tasting. The leaves are boiled in water and the liquid used as a wash to treat itchy skin, scabies and infected ears. It is like an antiseptic. It is also good for toothaches and as shampoo because it makes your hair dark and healthy. The timber is good firewood. This plant is considered to be a young version of Terminalia arostrata.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 28/Aug/2015

\lx barlabarla
\sf

\re bony bream
\re bubble fish
\re Nematalosa erebi
\sy buliny
\va
\sc Nematalosa erebi
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe

\lx barladmawu
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge northern.brown.bandicoot
\de northern brown bandicoot
\sd H Mammals
\re bandicoot (northern brown)
\re Isoodon macrourus
\sy
\va
\sc Isoodon macrourus
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee 'Barladmawu' is not seen often on Ngarinyman country now. It was more common in the past. The flesh is tender and tasty after roasting on hot coals. When watermelons were grown on stations in the past, they used to eat them out just leaving the hollowed-out skin in the garden.

\re emu apple
\re Owenia vernicosa
\sy
\va
\sc Owenia vernicosa
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\ue
\ee The hard wood is used to make fighting-sticks or nulla-nullas. This plant is considered to be poisonous. The fruit are eaten by emus (nangurrungurru), turkeys (jamud), and rock-wallabies (wugardij) but not by people. The inner bark or a few fruit can be boiled in water and the liquid used as a wash to treat open cuts and skin sores.
\cf
\pc barnard.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 6/Aug/2018

\lx barragal
\sf
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge spearwood
\de spearwood
\sd M Plants
\re Aeschynomene indica
\sy
\va
\sc Aeschynomene indica
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The dry stems are very good for lighting fires as they burn like kerosene. The light weight stems are used as toy spears and arrows by children, and are also used to kill fish.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf

\ee The stems are used to make light spear shafts for hunting small game, such as fish, prawns, crabs and small goannas. The stems are also used by young boys as toy spears and to make fire-sticks.

\dt 6/Aug/2018

\lx barrarraj
\sf
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge black.currant
\de black currant
\sd M Plants
\re black currant
\re currant (black)
\re Antidesma ghesaembilla
\sy
\va
\sc Antidesma ghesaembilla
\so
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee When the fruit ripen, they turn purple to black. That's when they are eaten. They are sweet and tasty and highly regarded as a food source. They are collected during the hot weather of the build-up.
\cf
\pc barrarraj.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\sn 2
\ge green.plum
\de green plum
\sd M Plants
\re plum (green)
\re green plum
\re Buchanania obovata
\sy ngaringari
\sy jamurru
\va
\sc Buchanania obovata
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The fruit are eaten when they are ripe, green but soft to touch. They are produced at the beginning or early in the wet season and are very tasty. They are generally collected once they have fallen to the ground. In the past the fruit and seed were crushed and mixed into a paste that was good for small children and old people. 'Barrarraj' are the larger trees with large woody trunks, and these are considered to be the mother of 'ngaringari' and 'jamurru', the smaller trees with thinner trunks.
\cf
\pc barrarraj2.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 04/Sep/2018

\lx barrawi
\sf
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge soap.tree
\de soap tree
\sd M Plants
\re soap tree
\re Acacia holosericea
\sy
\va
\sc Acacia holosericea
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The leaves are boiled in water and the liquid used as a wash to treat skin sores. The stems of young straight trees are used as spear shafts. The leaves can be rubbed with a little water to a soapy lather used for washing. The timber can also be used to make the hook of a woomera. The seeds are used to make small dampers or Johnny-cakes. The seeds are ground into flour and wrapped in water-lily leaves and cooked in hot coals and ashes.
\cf
\pc barrawi.jpg
\se
\de
\xv Nyila-ma barrawi -- use 'em maniny-gulu jub, wash 'em.
\sfx
\xe This is a 'barrawi' tree - they used it for soap, for washing.
\rf ER: ESB: 1994.
\sn 2
\ge wattle
\de wattle
\sd M Plants
\re wattle
\re Acacia difficilis
\sy
\va
\sc Acacia difficilis
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The stems from young straight plants are used to make shafts of fish spears. Woomera pegs are made from the forks in branches.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\sn 3
\ge elephant.ear.wattle
\de elephant ear wattle
\sd M Plants
\re wattle (elephant ear)
\re elephant ear wattle
\re Acacia dunnii
\sy
\va
\sc Acacia dunnii
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This plant has large grey leaves and it grows on sandy country and on sandstone areas. It has attractive grey leaves and bright yellow flowers; it is often planted in gardens. The stems from young straight plants can be used to make spear shafts.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\sn 4
\ge wattle
\de wattle
\sd M Plants
\re Acacia lamprocarpa
\sy
\va
\sc Acacia lamprocarpa
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The stems from young straight plants are used to make shafts of fish spears. Woomera pegs are made from the forks in branches.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe

\dt 6/Aug/2018

\lx barrayarna
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge cattle
\de cattle, bullock
\sd H Mammals
\re cattle
\re bullock
\re Bos taurus
\re Bos indicus
\sy ngarin
\sy burruna
\sy bulugi
\va
\sc Bos taurus
\sc Bos indicus
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The meat is very good to eat after roasting. In recent times brahmans have become very common and shorthorns have become less common. Shorthorns are generally easier to handle in yards and are less likely to charge, while brahmans are more dangerous. The meat from shorthorns has better flavour and is more tender. The term 'ngarin' refers to the meat. 'Bulngayarri' refers to the bull and 'burruna' refers to a young bull.
\cf
\pc cow.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 22/Sep/2015

\lx barung
\sf

\sd G Environment

\re rain time

\va barungarla

\rf NH:CJ:2/6/95
\ue
\ee The word is used like English 'year' -- for counting the yearly cycle e.g. 'jindagu barung' is 'one year', 'gujarra barung' is 'two years'.

\lx bawayangarna
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge Gould's.goanna
\de female Gould's goanna
\sd I Reptiles
\re goanna (Gould's)
\re Gould's goanna
\re Varanus gouldi
\sy wardaba
\va
\sc Varanus gouldi
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The flesh can be eaten after roasting. It is very tasty. This goanna often digs deep holes and can be tracked to the holes and then dug out. Often the holes have to be dug very deep and a lot of work is required to get the goanna out. 'Bawayangarna' is the female of this species, 'wardaba' is the male.
\cf
\pc Varanus_gouldii.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 21/Sep/2015

\lx bawulji
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge swamp.box
\de swamp box
\sd M Plants
\re Lophostemon grandiflorus
\re swamp box
\sy jinggulng
\va
\sc Lophostemon grandiflorus
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The wood is good firewood for cooking meat, fish or any food. Sugarbag or native bee-hives can be found in this tree. In the past the bark was crushed up and used to block off the ends of large coolamons to stop honey or other food falling out; the bark can then be sucked to get the honey out. This large tree grows in creek and river beds, where it provides dense, cool shade. The stems of young trees can be used to make spear shafts, larger stems can be used to make shields.
\cf
\pc swamp_box.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 26/Aug/2015

\sd J Birds

\sy guluju

\va
\sc Gallus gallus
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee 'Bawurl' and 'jugjug' are Kriol names for 'guluju'. They are derived from 'fowl' and 'chook chook'. Many people used to have chickens for the tasty meat and eggs.

\lx bayarnumirralng
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge mosquito
\de mosquito
\sd L Insects and Spiders
\re mosquito
\re Diptera, Culicidae
\sy gurrang, wamajngarna, miril
\va
\sc Diptera, Culicidae
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a Yarralin word.
\ee Mosquitoes are often active at dawn and dusk and they suck your blood. They can be chased away by lighting a smokey fire or by placing dry manure from horses or cattle on the coals. The smoke from burning gutta-percha (manyingila) and conkerberry (ngamanburru) is especially good for repelling mosquitos.
\cf
\pc Mosquito.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 21/Sep/2015

\lx bayawu-nga
\sf
\ps v
\sn
\ge bite-IRR
\de might bite
\sd S Verbs (Inflecting)
\re bite (might)
\sy
\va
\ve
\sc
\so LR:CM:07
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee
\cf bayalan
\lf
\lv
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx

\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a word from another language from the northern and western areas.
\ee The flesh can be eaten and is very tasty, the fat is also good to eat. The large ones are hard to catch and pull ashore. When landed they must be hit hard and quickly on the head to kill them. When they thrash on the bank they are very dangerous.

\lx bigibigi
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge pig
\de pig
\sd H Mammals
\re pig
\re Sus scrofa
\sy ngurrgngurrg
\sy jidjingamanyan
\sy jidjibarayi
\va

\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010

\de fern-leaved grevillea
\sd M Plants
\re grevillea (fern-leaved)
\re fern-leaved grevillea
\re Grevillea pteridifolia
\sy
\va
\sc Grevillea pteridifolia
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The straight stems can be used to make spear shafts. The sweet nectar can be sucked from the orange flowers. The flowers can also be placed in a billycan of water and swirled around; this makes a sweet drink like cordial.

\pc wiyindi.jpg

\dt 26/Aug/2015

\lx bigurda
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge bush.potato
\de bush potato
\sd M Plants
\re potato (bush)
\re bush potato
\re Ipomoea costata
\sy
\va
\sc Ipomoea costata
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This plant grows in red plain country. It has pretty pink flowers. The yams are dug up and eaten; they have an excellent taste and can often be collected in large amounts. The yams can be eaten lightly roasted or boiled. Sometimes the yams get very large and they crack the ground above them. When these cracks are seen near the plant it indicates there are large yams below. The ground around the plant can be tapped with a digging stick. If a hollow noise is heard, it indicates that a large yam is below.
\cf
\pc bigurda.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 07/Sep/2015

\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This fish is similar to the black bream but has better tasting flesh. It sometimes has a black spot on the side and is lighter in colour. It is not very common. There is a creation period story about this fish and how it got the mark on its side.
\cf
\pc
\se

\xv
\sfx

\lx bilgarri
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge ironwood.tree
\de ironwood tree
\sd M Plants
\re ironwood
\sy
\va
\sc
\so AP, NP: CR:93
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee You can make boomerangs, clap-sticks, axe handles, digging sticks and fighting-sticks from the hard wood. You can use the leaves to make smoke for funerals. You can boil the roots in water and use the liquid to treat high temperatures and fevers. You can use the sap that comes out of burnt roots as glue or cement.

\sn
\ge know
\de know, understand, knowledgeable about something
\sd R Talking and Looking
\re know
\sy binarri
\va
\ve
\sc
\so NH:CJ:1/1/95; RB, BFF:ESB:16/07/99; MW:CJ:94
\xv Ngu-rna bina nyila-ma jaru.
\sfx
\xe I know that language.
\rf RB
\xv Gula-rna bina.
\sfx
\xe I don't know.
\rf RB
\xv Gula-rna-rla bina nyila ngumbin. Ngurragari-nginyi.
\sfx
\xe I don't know that man. He's from a different place.
\rf NH:CJ:1/1/95

\sfx
\xe That's fine, I know that word.
\rf NH:CJ:1/1/95
\xv Bina-n?
\sfx
\xe Do you know?
\rf BFF:ESB:16/07/99
\xv Murluwu-ma dan.gu-ma gula-rnalu bina.
\sfx
\xe We don't know about that tucker.
\rf NH:CJ:7/6/95
\xv Gula-rna bina, ngayiny-ju jaju-rlu yurrg yuwani.
\sfx
\xe I don't know, my grandmother told me that story.

\xe I didn't know him.

\dt 18/Jul/2018

\lx binambarlij
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge desert.Rose
\de desert rose
\sd M Plants
\re desert rose
\re Gossypium australe
\sy
\va
\sc Gossypium australe
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The leaves are boiled in water and the water used as a wash to treat skin sores and scabies. It is especially good for use on children. The leaves can also be rubbed onto the legs of someone who is tired from walking and this has the effect of making the legs feel strong again. The leaves are eaten by cattle when feed gets short in the late dry season.
\cf
\pc 1Pinampalij.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 26/Aug/2015

\rf ER:CM:08
\xv Marndaj-barna binarri jaru-wu.
\sfx
\xe That's fine, I know that word.
\rf ES:JM1-021 2016 book 2, p64
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc
\se binarri garrany
\de know
\xv Gula-lu binarri English-gu garrinya; najing.
\sfx
\xe They didn't know English, no.
\rf NH:CJ:95
\rf

\lx binybiny
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge finches
\de finches, small colourful birds
\sd J Birds
\re finch
\sy
\va
\sc
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee There are many types of finches, and some other small, often colourful birds that are called by these names. They often occur in grassy areas near rivers and creeks. In dry areas they can lead you to water. If you watch them, they will always go to water for a drink. Old people say it is important not to hurt these small pretty birds and they should be left alone.
\cf
\pc crimson_finch.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf

\dt 02/Dec/2008

\lx birdba
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge northern.kurrajong
\de northern kurrajong
\sd M Plants
\re kurrajong (northern)
\re northern kurrajong
\re Brachychiton diversifolius
\sy
\va
\sc Brachychiton diversifolius
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The seeds inside the fruit can be eaten. They must be roasted on a fire before eating; this cooks the seeds and also removes the small hairs from inside the fruit. These hairs are very dangerous and can cause severe pain if they get in the eye or mouth. The seeds are considered very good food and in the past people used to enjoy them very much. The swollen tap root of young plants can be dug up, roasted and then eaten. The bark of young plants can be made into string. This string is very long lasting and strong. It can be used to tie spear heads onto spear shafts, hooks onto woomeras and tie up bundles of food, firewood or any items. The gum can be used as medicine; it is applied directly to sores and cuts, and is called 'marnda' or 'mardiya'. The inner bark is used as a bandage because it has an open weave pattern. 'Birdba' is a large tree, while the other kurrajongs are much smaller shrubs or trees.
\cf
\pc yinggi.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 17/Aug/2015

\lx birdigud
\sf

\lx birijbirij
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge Terminalia.bursarina
\de type of tree
\sd M Plants
\re Terminalia bursarina
\sy
\va
\sc Terminalia bursarina
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This tree grows in creek-beds and river-beds. The gum (marnda) that is found on the stems and branches can be eaten. It tastes like toffee. If the gum is very hard it can be placed in the hot ashes of a fire for a few minutes. This softens the gum which can then be flattened with a stone or stick into small Johnny-cakes which can then be eaten and are very tasty. The timber is good firewood.
\cf marnda, mardiya
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 28/Aug/2015

\lx birrbuny
\sf
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge wattle
\de wattle
\sd M Plants
\re wattle
\re Acacia conjunctifolia
\sy
\va
\sc Acacia conjunctifolia
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This plant is a very good medicine tree. The leaves are boiled in water and the liquid used as a wash to treat any illness. Smoke from the leaves can be used to treat stomach pains. Witchetty grubs are often found in the roots.
\cf
\pc mulurrmi.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\sn 2
\ge turpentine.wattle
\de turpentine wattle
\sd M Plants
\re wattle (turpentine)
\re turpentine wattle
\re Acacia lysiphloia
\sy
\va
\sc Acacia lysiphloia
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This plant is a very good medicine tree. The leaves are boiled in water and the liquid used as an external wash to treat colds and flu. The leaves can also be warmed on a fire and held against sore muscles and joints to relieve pain. The heated leaves can also be held against the head to relieve headaches. Leaves may be placed on hot coals so that they produce smoke; this is allowed to waft around the body to treat the same symptoms. Witchetty grubs (lamawud) are often found in the roots and stem bases of this plant.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\sn 3
\ge wattle
\de wattle
\sd M Plants
\re Acacia nuperrima
\sy
\va
\sc Acacia nuperrima
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The branches can be used a broom for sweeping around campsites to keep them clean and make it easy to see tracks in the sand.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\sn 4
\ge tree.species
\de type of tree
\sd M Plants
\re Verticordia cunninghamii
\sy
\va
\sc Verticordia cunninghamii
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The leaves and twigs are boiled in water and the liquid allowed to cool. This is used as a medicinal wash to treat colds, influenza and itchy skin. The timber is good firewood.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 17/Aug/2015

\lx budbara
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge conkerberry
\de conkerberry
\sd M Plants
\re conkerberry
\re Carissa lanceolata
\sy ngamanburru
\va
\sc Carissa lanceolata
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\lf Jaminjung
\lv budbara
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This may be a Jaminjung and Ngaliwurru word.
\ee The fruit are eaten when they are black; they are sweet and very tasty. When the fireflies are active at night in the wet season it indicates the fruit are ripe and ready to eat. Many different birds also eat the fruit, especially emus (nangurrungurru). The inner wood of the roots and stems is bright orange in colour. The wood can be used to make boomerangs, and these boomerangs fly faster and further than other boomerangs. When the wood is sanded and polished it becomes very glossy and flies through the air really well. The roots are used to cure toothaches. The roots are dug up and the inner orange wood is scraped off in fine shavings. This is pushed into a tooth cavity and it stops the pain.
\cf
\pc ngamanburru.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 6/Aug/2018

\lx budurrg
\sf
\ps cv
\sn
\ge walk
\de walk on foot
\sd P Moving
\re walk
\sy galu
\va
\ve
\sc
\so NH:CJ:98. JC: JM1-001 2016: 00:08:53.
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This word is from English 'footwalk'.
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc walk.jpg
\se budurrg yanan
\de walk
\xv Budurrg-barna yanan yinburrug.
\sfx
\xe I'm walking on foot a long way.
\rf NH:JM1-020 2016 book 2, p54
\dt 6/Aug/2018

\sf
\ps n

\xv Buduwudu-rla gula-n magin garru. Buduwudu-rla. Gala nyila yuga.
\sfx
\xe You can't sleep on the rough stuff. On the rough stuff. Leave that grass.

\ue

\lf Gurindji

\dt 27/Nov/2008

\lx bulgi
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge yellow.kapok
\de yellow kapok
\sd M Plants
\re kapok (yellow)
\re Cochlospermum fraseri
\sy galijba
\va
\sc Cochlospermum fraseri
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The fruit are called 'bulung' and the seed is called 'bulgi', and are used as toys by children. The swollen tap root is dug up and eaten raw or lightly roasted. If the plant is larger the root is not eaten as it is too fibrous. The bark is boiled in water and the liquid used as a wash to treat skin sores and irritations. The water goes red when the bark is boiled, and after washing with it people have a red glow. Dry straight stems can be used as fire-sticks, to create fire using the traditional drilling and friction method. The inner bark can be peeled off the stem and used as bandages. It can also be used to make string or rope to tie things together or carry things. The twigs can be used to make a small brush which can be used to dip honey out of sugarbag that cannot be chopped out of trees. The young green fruit are squeezed onto boils to help draw them out. The inner bark and flowers can be boiled in water and little of the liquid drunk to bring down high temperatures. The yellow flowers indicate that freshwater crocodiles are laying their eggs, and the forming of the fruit indicate that the baby crocodiles are growing. When the fruit split open the eggs have hatched and the baby crocodiles are out of the eggs.
\cf
\pc galijba.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 20/Aug/2015

\lx bulgub
\sf
\ps cv
\sn
\ge sneak.up
\de sneak up
\sd P Moving
\re sneak up
\sy
\va
\ve
\sc
\so NH,IW:CJ:98; NH,KJ,JT,ES:JM:2016; ER?

\xe
\rf

\se bulgub yanan
\de go sneaking up

\xe It went sneaking up on them.
\rf NH,IW:CJ:98

\lx bulguwung
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge death.adder
\de death adder
\sd I Reptiles
\re adder (death)
\re death adder
\re snake (death adder)
\re Acanthophis praelongus
\sy bulurrng
\sy
\sy dardalya
\sy burrul
\va
\sc Acanthophis praelongus
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv Bulguwung guliyan.
\sfx
\xe Death adders are dangerous.
\rf NH:CJ:95
\ue This is a Yarralin word.
\ee This is a small poisonous snake that is very dangerous. It has a short prickle in the end of its tail. If you are bitten by one, you will be dead in a very short time. It lives in rocky areas and in caves and crevices. There are songs to stop the poison and songs to clear the snakes away from camping areas. When they are killed you need to burn them to ash, otherwise they can heal themselves and will chase you and kill you.
\cf
\pc death_adder.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 6/Aug/2018

\lx bulugi
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge cattle
\de cattle, bullock
\sd H Mammals
\re cattle
\re bullock
\re Bos taurus
\re Bos indicus
\sy ngarin
\sy burruna
\sy barrayarna
\va
\sc Bos taurus
\sc Bos indicus
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This word is from Kriol. The meat is very good to eat after roasting. In recent times brahmans have become very common and shorthorns have become less common. Shorthorns are generally easier to handle in yards and are less likely to charge, while brahmans are more dangerous. The meat from shorthorns has better flavour and is more tender.

\pc cow.jpg

\xv

\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The flesh can be eaten after roasting or they can be used as live bait to catch bigger fish such as barramundi. There are a lot of bones in the meat. 'Buliny' often releases air bubbles when it feeds, so it is often called the bubble fish.

\lx bulngayarri
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge cattle
\de cattle, bullock
\sd H Mammals
\re cattle
\re bullock
\re Bos taurus
\re Bos indicus
\sy ngarin
\sy burruna
\sy barrayarna
\sy bulugi

\sc Bos indicus
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The meat is very good to eat after roasting. In recent times brahmans have become very common and shorthorns have become less common. Shorthorns are generally easier to handle in yards and are less likely to charge, while brahmans are more dangerous. The meat from shorthorns has better flavour and is more tender. The term 'ngarin' refers to the meat. 'Bulngayarri' refers to the bull and 'burruna' refers to a young bull.

\lx bulurrman
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge Australian.bustard
\de Australian bustard, bush turkey
\sd J Birds
\re bustard (Australian)
\re turkey (bush)
\re bush turkey
\re Ardeotis australis
\sy jamud
\sy jandura
\va
\sc Ardeotis australis
\so LR:KH:06/07
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a Jaminjung word.
\ee Bush turkeys are one of the best bush meats. They were hunted with boomerangs in the past, now shotguns and rifles are used. You can boil or roast the meat in a ground oven. It tastes like chicken. They are common in areas with large grassy plains. They like to eat grasshoppers (janyima) and various bush fruits. They have special cultural significance for Ngarinyman people.

\lx bundaru
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge quail
\de quail
\sd J Birds
\re quail
\re Coturnix spp.
\re Turnix spp.
\sy jirdij
\sy guljaru
\sy jirdij
\va
\sc Coturnix spp.
\sc Turnix spp.
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee All quail are too small to be eaten. 'Bundaru' flies out of the grass with a loud noise when you walk close to it and it can give you a fright.

\se

\xv

\dt 08/Sep/2015

\lx bundul
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge white.apple
\de white apple
\sd M Plants
\re apple (white)
\re Syzygium eucalyptoides ssp. eucalyptoides
\sy yilirli
\va
\sc Syzygium eucalyptoides ssp. eucalyptoides
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a Yarralin word.
\ee This small tree grows in creek beds and on river banks. The fruit may be eaten when ripe, pale pink to white. They are especially favoured by children. When the fruit fall in rivers and creeks they are eaten by turtles (guwarlambarla), black bream (gambajawung) and catfish (warrag). The timber is good for cooking fish and turtles. The flowers are visited by native bees (lanu) who use the pollen and nectar for making honey.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 28/Aug/2015

\lx bunggiyin
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge plains.kangaroo
\de plains kangaroo, antilopine wallaroo
\sd H Mammals
\re kangaroo (plains)
\re plains kangaroo
\re Macropus antilopinus
\sy ngalijirri
\sy jardugarl
\sy wawirri
\va
\sc Macropus antilopinus
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This kangaroo generally lives on grassy plains, often on red soil country. It is tall and thin compared to the hill kangaroo. Plains kangaroos have special significance for Ngarinyman people. It is a Dreaming for some people. 'Bunggiyin' is a term used for the female of this species.
\cf
\pc Antilopine_Wallaroo.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 09/Sep/2015

\dt 6/Aug/2018

\lx burdunburru
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge northern.long-necked.turtle
\de northern long-necked turtle
\sd I Reptiles
\re turtle (northern long-necked)
\re northern long-necked turtle
\re Chelodina rugosa
\sy wirriwurnany
\va
\sc Chelodina rugosa
\so NH,KJ,JK:CJ:2005
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\lf Jaminjung
\lv burdunburru
\ee These turtles have long necks and are very good to eat. They can be caught on hand-lines when fishing, but are also found in the drying mud around billabongs when the water dries up in the cold season. The drying mud is poked with crowbars until the turtles are found and then they can be dug out of the mud with a crowbar. They only live in the more northern areas of Ngarinyman country.
\cf
\pc long_neck_turtle.jpg
\se
\de
\xv Burdunburru-wu-rna nyawa-ma warlagab yanan.
\sfx
\xe I'm hunting for long neck turtle.
\rf ER:ES99_V01_04.004
\dt 6/Aug/2018

\lx burluburlu
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge tree.species
\de type of tree
\sd M Plants
\re Cathormion umbellatum
\sy
\va
\sc Cathormion umbellatum
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This plant is a good shade tree as its thick canopy provides dense, cool shade. It grows around rivers, creeks and billabongs and has dark green leaves.
\cf

\lx burluwulyu
\sf
\ps n
\sn

\dt 29/Jan/2018

\lx burndung
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge wallaby.grass
\de wallaby grass
\sd M Plants
\re grass (wallaby)
\re wallaby grass
\re Chrysopogon fallax
\sy jarri
\va
\sc Chrysopogon fallax
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The stem base is eaten by kangaroos and wallabies. The sharp leaf edges can cut your feet when you walk through it, or your hands if you try to pull it out. The stem base and new shoots can also be used as medicine. The yellow root is dug up and cleaned off, then smashed up and boiled in water. The cooled liquid is drunk to treat bad colds.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 06/Sep/2015

\de take it all away

\xv Maitbi-lu-nga manin burrb, guwarlambarla.

\lx burrmarri
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge mud.wasp
\de mud wasp, hornet
\sd L Insects and Spiders
\re wasp (mud)
\re mud wasp
\re hornet
\re Hymenoptera, Vespidae, Delta spp.
\sy munmunung
\va
\sc Hymenoptera, Vespidae, Delta spp.
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a Timber Creek word.
\ee These large black and yellow wasps make a nest from mud collected from the edge of puddles, creeks and waterholes. They are cheeky and can sting you. They sing when they find sugarbag.
\cf
\pc Hornet.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 21/Sep/2015

\lx burrngun
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge lerps
\de sugar leaf from river red gum, also called lerps
\sd L Insects and Spiders
\re sugarleaf
\re lerps
\re Hemiptera, Psyllidae
\sy
\va
\sc Hemiptera, Psyllidae
\so NH,KJ:CJ:98
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee Edible white secretion on the leaves of river gum (dimarlan), which you can eat straightaway (in contrast to the non-river country 'jalyingarna' which you have to leave sit for a while. You can collect the small white scale-like insect-coverings off gum leaves during the early part of the dry season when the first smoke is in the air. You knock it off the leaves and make it into johnny cakes.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 18/Feb/2018

\dt 06/Aug/2018

\lx burrul
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge death.adder
\de death adder
\sd I Reptiles
\re adder (death)
\re death adder
\re snake (death adder)
\re Acanthophis praelongus
\sy bulurrng
\sy
\sy bulguwung
\sy dardalya
\va
\sc Acanthophis praelongus
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This is a small poisonous snake that is very dangerous. It has a short prickle in the end of its tail. If you are bitten by one, you will be dead in a very short time. It lives in rocky areas and in caves and crevices. There are songs to stop the poison and songs to clear the snakes away from camping areas. When they are killed you need to burn them to ash, otherwise they can heal themselves and will chase you and kill you.
\cf
\pc death_adder.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 20/Sep/2015

\lx burruna
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge cattle
\de cattle, bullock
\sd H Mammals
\re cattle
\re bullock
\re Bos taurus
\re Bos indicus
\sy ngarin
\sy barrayarna
\sy bulugi
\va
\sc Bos taurus
\sc Bos indicus
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The meat is very good to eat after roasting. In recent times brahmans have become very common and shorthorns have become less common. Shorthorns are generally easier to handle in yards and are less likely to charge, while brahmans are more dangerous. The meat from shorthorns has better flavour and is more tender. The term 'ngarin' refers to the meat. 'Bulngayarri' refers to the bull and 'burruna' refers to a young bull.
\cf
\pc cow.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 22/Sep/2015

\lx buwumbuwa
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge bulrush
\de bulrush
\sd M Plants
\re bulrush
\re Typha domingensis
\sy
\va
\sc Typha domingensis
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The stems and leaves are used by saltwater crocodiles (jawinyin) to build nests in which they lay and incubate eggs. The fluffy seeds from the cigar-like fruit on top of the stem can be applied to the body as decoration during certain ceremonies.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 07/Sep/2015

\lx buwuny
\sf
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge stripe-faced.dunnart
\de stripe-faced dunnart
\sd H Mammals
\re dunnart (striped-faced)
\re striped-faced dunnart
\re Sminthopsis macroura
\sy bunybuny
\va
\sc Sminthopsis macroura
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This small mouse-like animal makes the haze or smoke that makes the ranges look blue in the mornings and evenings. This small rodent looks like a mouse and the language names are applied to a number of small mammals.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\sn 2
\ge native.mice
\de native mice
\sd H Mammals
\re mice (native)
\re Pseudomys spp.
\sy
\va
\sc Pseudomys spp.
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee These small mice live in the bush. They have spiritual importance and cause the fog and the blue haze around the ranges.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\sn 3
\ge house.mouse
\de house mouse, black rat
\sd H Mammals
\re mouse (house)
\re rat (black)
\re Mus musculus
\re Rattus rattus
\sy
\va
\sc Mus musculus
\sc Rattus rattus
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This introduced mouse and rat have the same names as a number of small native mice. However these occur in houses and camps, not in the bush.
\cf
\pc mouse.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf

\lx dagirriny
\sf
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge tacca
\de tacca
\sd M Plants
\re tacca
\re Tacca leontopetaloides
\sy
\va
\sc Tacca leontopetaloides
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The swollen tubers are eaten by pigs, but not by people. The fruits can be eaten when they are ripe, the seeds are spat out.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\sn 2
\ge onion.lily
\de onion lily
\sd M Plants
\re onion lily
\re Crinum angustifolium
\sy
\va
\sc Crinum angustifolium
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv Dagirriny dajgarra barru-li-nga, jardgarra nyanggu-li-nga.
\sfx
\xe You and me might smash up wild onions and eat them.
\rf ER:ESB:94
\ue
\ee This plant has a tuber like an onion underneath. The tuber can be eaten after extensive preparation. This includes smashing it into small pieces and leaching it in running water. It is then cooked for a long time. If it is not properly prepared it is rubbery, has a strong unpleasant taste and may be poisonous. Sometimes fat is rubbed into it to make it taste better. When 'dagirriny' is well cooked it tastes like mashed potato. 'Dagirriny' is closely related to 'mugaj' (Typhonium liliifolium), the small yam that also has a rubbery texture.
\cf
\pc
\sn 3
\ge onion
\de onion (non-native food)
\re onion
\se
\de
\xv Dal garrany gan.gula, dagirriny.
\sfx
\xe There is an onion on top.
\rf ER: ES97_n02_Jam.027
\dt 6/Aug/2018

\lx damarra
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge termite.mound
\de termite mound, antbed
\sd L Insects and Spiders
\re termite mound
\re Isoptera
\re antbed
\sy mardumardu
\sy marda
\va
\sc Isoptera
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The fine soil from inside termite mounds (also known as 'ant hills') can be drunk mixed with water to treat diarrhoea. It dries up 'runny-tummy'. It is also used when smoking babies to make them strong. The ant hill is placed over a fire with water sprinkled on top, and the baby is held in the smoke and steam. This strengthens the baby.
\cf
\pc Antbed.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 22/Sep/2015

\lx dambang
\sf
\ps cv
\sn
\ge die
\de die, kill
\sd T Impact
\re die
\sy
\va
\ve
\sc
\so MW:CJ:94, ESB, ER:CM:2008
\xv
\sfx
\xe
