\dt 11/Aug/2008

\lx danyan
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge spangled.perch
\de spangled perch
\sd K Water Animals
\re perch (spangled)
\re Leiopotherapon unicolor
\sy dawujban
\va
\sc Leiopotherapon unicolor
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee 'Danyan' is common in waterholes on rivers and creeks and in springs. It is often quite small and is used as bait to catch bigger fish. The larger ones are called 'dawujban' and can be roasted on hot coals and are very tasty. Sometimes the flesh contains small worms, especially when the fish are in small waterholes. They need to be well cooked to kill the worms.
\cf
\pc danyan.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 09/Sep/2015

\lx dardaga
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge bush.coconut
\de bush coconut, gall on bloodwood tree
\sd L Insects and Spiders
\re coconut (bush)
\re bush coconut
\re gall (on tree)
\re Hemiptera, Sternorrhyncha
\sy
\va
\sc Hemiptera, Sternorrhyncha
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The small grub inside these insect galls can be eaten. They are very sweet and tasty. The white inner flesh of the gall can also be eaten. It looks a bit like the inside of a coconut. They are found mainly on bloodwood trees.
\cf
\pc bloodwood_gall.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 21/Sep/2015

\lx dardalya
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge death.adder
\de death adder
\sd I Reptiles
\re adder (death)
\re death adder
\re snake (death adder)
\re Acanthophis praelongus
\sy bulurrng
\sy
\sy bulguwung
\sy burrul
\va
\sc Acanthophis praelongus
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a word from the northern and western areas.
\ee This is a small poisonous snake that is very dangerous. It has a short prickle in the end of its tail. If you are bitten by one, you will be dead in a very short time. It lives in rocky areas and in caves and crevices. There are songs to stop the poison and songs to clear the snakes away from camping areas. When they are killed you need to burn them to ash, otherwise they can heal themselves and will chase you and kill you.
\cf
\pc death_adder.jpg
\se
\de
\so NR:ESB:01
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 20/Sep/2015

\sy warrija
\va
\sc Crocodylus johnstoni
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The meat can be eaten after roasting on hot coals or cooking in a ground oven like a goanna. They are often caught on hand-lines when fishing, and they can be hit over the head with a crowbar to kill them. In the past the men used to hunt them with spears, and they were eaten more commonly than they are now. The eggs are also eaten after boiling; they are good to eat. The tracks of the mother are followed to the nest and the sand dug out and the eggs collected. 'Laging' is a small freshwater crocodile and 'darrmard' is a large one.
\cf
\pc freshwater_croc.jpg
\se
\de
\xv Darrmard-barna mani. Nyamba-yawung? Wuyurrun-yawung-gurlu.
\sfx
\xe I caught a freshwater crocodile. With what? With a fishing line.
\rf DR:ES12:A09_03
\dt 6/Aug/2018

\lx darru
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge spider
\de spider
\sd L Insects and Spiders
\re spider
\re Arachnida, Araneae
\sy marawun
\sy garra
\sy garrada
\sy jamabngarrawu
\va
\sc Arachnida, Araneae
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a Yarralin word.
\ee All spiders have the same name although many different types of spider are recognised and some are dangerous. The red-back spider has a painful bite that causes a lot of swelling. The spider web is called 'jambangarrawu' or 'garrada'.

\lx dawujban
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge spangled.perch
\de spangled perch
\sd K Water Animals
\re perch (spangled)
\re Leiopotherapon unicolor
\sy danyan
\va
\sc Leiopotherapon unicolor
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee 'Dawujban' is common in waterholes on rivers and creeks and in springs. It is often quite small and is good bait to catch bigger fish. The larger ones are called 'dawujban' and can be roasted on hot coals and are very tasty. Sometimes the flesh contains small worms, especially when the fish are in small waterholes. They need to be well cooked to kill the worms.

\pc danyan.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf

\dt 27/Nov/2008

\lx dijuna
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge black.flying.fox
\de black flying-fox
\sd H Mammals
\re flying-fox (black)
\re black flying-fox
\re Pteropus alecto
\sy warrba, yiburru, najuna
\va
\sc Pteropus alecto
\so NH,KJ,JG:KH:2007, NH,KJ:CJ:98, NH,JK,KJ:CM:08
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a Wurlayi, Gurindji and Mudburra word, used at Yarralin.
\ee Black flying foxes like to eat paperbark flowers, figs and the fruit of the Leichhardt tree. The flesh of the black flying-fox can be eaten after roasting. It has a strong distinctive smell and taste. In the past they were killed by throwing hunting sticks into the roosting colonies. Crocodiles eat them when they roost in paperbark trees hanging over rivers and billabongs. The black flying-fox is larger and more common than the red flying-fox (galanbuga). Flying foxes have special cultural significance for Ngarinyman people.
\cf
\pc Black_flying_fox.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 19/Feb/2018

\lx warrba
\sf
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge black.flying.fox
\de black flying-fox
\sd H Mammals
\re flying-fox (black)
\re black flying-fox
\re Pteropus alecto
\sy dijuna, yiburru, najuna
\va
\sc Pteropus alecto
\so NH,KJ,JG:KH:2007 , NH,KJ:CJ:98, NH,JK,KJ:CM:08
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is the usual word for black flying-fox at Yarralin.
\ee Black flying foxes like to eat paperbark flowers, figs and the fruit of the Leichhardt tree. The flesh of the black flying-fox can be eaten after roasting. It has a strong distinctive smell and taste. In the past they were killed by throwing hunting sticks into the roosting colonies. Crocodiles eat them when they roost in paperbark trees hanging over rivers and billabongs. The black flying-fox is larger and more common than the red flying-fox (galanbuga). Flying foxes have special cultural significance for Ngarinyman people.
\cf
\pc Black_flying_fox.jpg
\se
\de
\xv Jarrwangurrung warrba warrb garrany.
\sfx

\lx dilyarri
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge sand.goanna
\de sand goanna, plains goanna
\sd I Reptiles
\re goanna (sand)
\re sand goanna
\re goanna (plains)
\re plains goanna
\re Varanus panoptes
\sy girrawa
\sy jurlumirri
\sy warlgan
\va
\sc Varanus panoptes
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a Yarralin word.
\ee This is the biggest goanna. It can get very large and has a lot of tasty flesh. The language name can also be used to refer to goannas in general, however, they are used for this goanna as it is the largest and best known. 'Girrawa' is the male and 'jurlumirri' is the female of this species. 'Warlgan' is the term used in Yarralin for the female.
\cf
\pc Varanus_panoptes.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 21/Sep/2015

\lx dimarna
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge horse
\de horse
\sd H Mammals
\re horse
\re Equus caballus
\sy nindu, yawarda
\va
\sc Equus caballus
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv Mangarri nyila-ma jalag-barna wuyarnin, stock camp-jirri, ngumbin-gu nyamu-lu warug yanin, dimarna-yawung.
\sfx
\xe I used to send that food to the stockcamp, for the men who were working with the horses.
\rf ER:ES08_A03_01.020-021
\ue
\ee In the past horses were used a lot on stations for mustering. Feral horses are sometimes hunted by pet meaters. The meat is dark red and strong smelling.
\cf
\pc horse_BIG.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf

\lx dimirimiri
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge march.fly
\de march fly
\sd L Insects and Spiders
\re march fly
\sy
\va dimirrimirri
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\sc Diptera, Tabanidae
\so ER, RB:ESB, MW:CJ:94 , NH:CJ:98
\xv Dimirimiri-rlu bayarnin-bayi. Maidi-nga gambij warrija-wu.
\sfx
\xe A march fly bit me. There might be crocodile eggs here.
\rf NH:CJ:98
\ue
\ee These large flies can give a painful sting especially around the lower leg and ankles. They are slow moving and easy to kill. When these flies bite, it indicates that crocodile eggs and turtle eggs are ready to collect and eat. When they stop biting, it indicates the baby crocodiles are ready to hatch.
\cf
\pc MarchFly.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf

\dt 6/Aug/2018

\lx jirrwili
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge ironwood
\de ironwood
\sd M Plants
\re ironwood
\re Erythrophleum chlorostachys
\sy
\va jirlwirli
\va dirrwili
\sc Erythrophleum chlorostachys
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The wood is very hard and can be used to make boomerangs, clap-sticks, axe handles, digging sticks and fighting-sticks. The leaves are placed on fires to produce smoke during the cleansing stages of funeral ceremonies; this smoke is allowed to waft around areas where a deceased person lived or visited to cleanse the area of spirits and bad feelings. The roots can be boiled in water and the liquid used as a wash to treat high temperatures and fevers. Paperbark can be soaked in this liquid and then the paperbark placed against the head and body to reduce fever. The sap that comes out of burnt roots can be used like glue or cement. When it cools it sets very hard. The leaves are poisonous to cattle, horses and goats.
\cf
\pc
\lf Jaminjung
\lv thirrwili
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 6/Aug/2018

\lx dugbarugba
\sf
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge salmon.gum
\de salmon gum
\sd M Plants
\re Eucalyptus bigalerita
\sy lunyja
\va
\sc Eucalyptus bigalerita
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This tree has orange coloured smooth bark. The wood is not good firewood as it does not burn well and makes a lot of smoke.
\cf
\pc lunyja.jpg
\sn 2
\ge salmon.gum
\de salmon gum
\sd M Plants
\re Eucalyptus tintinnans
\sy lunyja
\va
\sc Eucalyptus tintinnans
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The timber is good firewood. Boomerangs may be made from the hard wood. The bark is chipped off and boiled in water and the liquid is used as external wash to treat any skin problems. Sugarbag (native bee-hives) can be found in this tree.
\cf
\pc
\dt 6/Aug/2018

\lx dugu
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge freshwater.mussel
\de freshwater mussel
\sd K Water Animals
\re mussel (freshwater)
\re freshwater mussel
\re Velesunio wilsoni
\sy daga
\sy narubu
\sy wijalngarniny
\va
\sc Velesunio wilsoni
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This big, solid mussel is found in the sand and mud at the edges of billabongs, creeks and rivers. They are eaten after roasting on hot coals or boiling in water. They are tasty. They are found in stony areas, not sandy or muddy areas.
\cf
\pc mussel.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 09/Sep/2015

\lx dugulgul
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge nail-tail.kangaroo
\de nail-tail kangaroo, left-hand kangaroo, northern nail-tail wallaby
\sd H Mammals
\re kangaroo (nail-tail)
\re nail-tail kangaroo
\re kangaroo (left-hand)
\re left-hand kangaroo
\re wallaby (northern nail-tail)
\re northern nail-tail wallaby
\re Onychogalea unguifera
\sy ngungungmarna
\va
\sc Onychogalea unguifera
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This kangaroo has a prickle in the end of its tail and often makes a 'oo..oo..oo' noise when it is hopping. There is a special song that 'dugulgul' sings as he hops along. It also holds its left arm up to its chest when hopping. The flesh can be eaten after roasting in a ground oven, but it is not eaten as often as the other kangaroos and wallabies.
\cf
\pc Northern_nailtail_wallaby.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 09/Sep/2015

\re touch
\re shake hands
\sy
\va
\ve

\so NH:CJ:1/1/95, NH,KJ:CJ:5/6/95, MW:CJ:94, ER:ESB:99 , NH,KJ:CJ:98, NJ,KJ,JK:CJ:2005, ER:CM:2008

\lv durd
\lf Gurindji
\lv durd
\pc
\se durd manan
\de hold, touch, grab, shake hands
\xv Durd-bayi mani wulu gurrwaran-rdu.
\sfx
\xe The doctor touched my leg.
\rf
\xv Nyila durd manda!
\sfx
\xe Touch it!
\xv Yingga-n durd mani?
\sfx
\xe Were you holding the spear stone?
\rf NH:CJ:21/06/1995
\xv Durd-barla mani, durlwarn-barla yuwani, ngagaj-ja. Durlwarn.
\sfx
\xe He held on to it, they put a saddle on it, on its back. A saddle.
\rf NH: CJ:95
\xv Gambarnin-balu brand 'em; durd-balu mani nyila-ma yawarda-ma.
\sfx
\xe They branded it; they held that horse.
\rf NH:CJ:95
\xv Wardan-bayi durd mana.
\sfx
\xe He shook my hand.
\rf NH:JM1-007 2016 book 1, p64.
\xv Gardbi-bawula durd mana.
\sfx
\xe They're pulling each other's hair.
\rf NH:JM1-010 2016 book 1, p101
\xv Warlagu durd mana jawuj.
\sfx
\xe She's pulling the dog's tail.
\rf NH:JM1-010 2016 book 1, p101

\de keep, hold onto
\xv Yawu durd garrwalan.
\sfx
\xe He's holding onto the fish.
\rf NH:JM1-007 2016 book 1, p65
\xv Durd-barna garrwala jarragabgaji.
\sfx
\xe I'm holding my phone.
\rf JC,CD:CJ:2018

\lx durldurl
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge pheasant.coucal
\de pheasant coucal
\sd J Birds
\re pheasant coucal
\re Centropus phasianinus
\sy wubub
\sy girribudbuda
\va
\sc Centropus phasianinus
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee 'Durldurl' calls woop...woop...woop in the wet season to make the cheeky yam (jarrwana) grow fat and produce lots of seed. It is a large, dark brown bird that often runs along the ground and then flies up into a tree.
\cf
\pc pheasant.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 08/Sep/2015

\rf CD:JM1-017 2016 book 2, p42
\xv Jinba-rdu durrb-bayi bunya yunba.
\sfx
\xe The burr poked me in the foot.
\rf KJ:JM1-017
\xv Durrb bunyang-barna girrawa.
\sfx
\xe I poked the goanna with a stick (to test if cooked).
\rf JC,CD,MS:CJ:2018
\se durrb barrany
\de stab, poke
\xv Durrb bani.
\sfx
\xe She stabbed it.
\rf JC,CD:CJ:2018
\se durrb wandany
\de get poked, stabbed, as when standing on something sharp
\xv Durrb waninya.
\sfx
\xe She got poked.
\rf JC,CD:CJ:2018
\dt 18/Jul/2018

\lx durrudurrud
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge rainbow.bee-eater
\de rainbow bee-eater
\sd J Birds
\re bee-eater (rainbow)
\re rainbow bee-eater
\re Merops ornatus
\sy jinbardbard
\sy jidjidudurrg
\va
\sc Merops ornatus
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee They often sit on high perches looking for insects to eat. They make a burrow in the banks of creeks or in termite mounds. The long tail feathers represent the woomeras that this bird always carries with it. There is an important creation period story about this bird and the woomera.
\cf
\pc Rainbow_Bee-Eater.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 08/Sep/2015

\lx duwiman
\sf
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge willings.tree
\de Willing's tree
\sd M Plants
\re Willing's tree
\re Grevillea dimidiata
\sy wubgaji
\va
\sc Grevillea dimidiata
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee When the fruit turn black they have a shiny resinous coating. This substance can cause blistering if it is allowed to get in contact with skin. In the past the fruit were rubbed on the body to cause scarring when participating in ceremonies.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\sn 2
\ge caustic.tree
\de caustic tree
\sd M Plants
\re caustic tree
\re Grevillea pyramidalis
\sy
\va
\sc Grevillea pyramidalis
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The dark and shiny fruit are covered in a thin layer of liquid. This can be rubbed onto the skin to cause scarring which is used as an indication of ceremonial rank.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 26/Aug/2015

\lx gagawurli
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge long.yam
\de long yam
\sd M Plants
\re yam (long)
\re long yam
\re Dioscorea transversa
\sy
\va
\sc Dioscorea transversa
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The long yam can be dug up and then lightly roasted before eating. These yams can get up to about 30 centimetres long and the flesh is very tasty and pleasant to eat. It tastes good when it is lightly roasted on hot coals but can also be eaten raw. It is one of the best yams to eat. They are common around Timber Creek and Bulla areas, but are not known from more southern areas.
\cf
\pc discorea_transversa.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 07/Sep/2015

\lx gajurda
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge forearm.bone
\de forearm bone (ulna), maybe also wrist
\sd A Body

\sy migirdi

\ue This is a Timber Creek word. Yarralin speakers use 'migirdi' instead.

\lv gajurda

\dt 13/Oct/2016

\lx gajuwa
\sf
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge corkwood
\de corkwood
\sd M Plants
\re corkwood
\re Erythrina vespertilio
\sy jalgaji
\va gajiwa
\sc Erythrina vespertilio
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The light wood is used to make coolamons and woomera shafts; it is light-weight wood but quite strong. The swollen tap root of young plants can be dug up, then cooked and eaten. The soot from the burnt bark can be rubbed onto the skin to make it look darker. In the past this was rubbed onto the skin of pale-skinned children. The bright red flowers indicate that freshwater crocodiles (warrija) are laying eggs and that they will be ready to collect and eat soon. The red seeds can be used to make necklaces. There are special sacred trees at Barrak Barrak, linked to the diver duck creation period story and song-line. These trees are often referred to by their Jaminjung name (julgirr) which also means woomera.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\sn 2
\ge type.of.tree
\de type of tree
\sd M Plants
\re Albizia canescens
\sy
\va
\sc Albizia canescens
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This is an introduced tree that provides cool dense shade which is good to sit under.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf

\dt 26/Nov/2008

\lx galanarrang
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge spinifex
\de spinifex
\sd M Plants
\re spinifex
\re Triodia sp.
\sy marluna
\va
\sc Triodia sp.
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The sticky leaves and stems can be used for medicine. They are boiled in water and the liquid used as a wash to treat bad colds and itchy skin. Wax (darla or gajarrang) may be obtained by burning the sticky leaves and stems. This resin is soft when it is hot but as it cools it sets very hard and is used as glue. It may be used to attach spear heads, axe heads and woomera hooks. Burning the leaves also produces smoke that repels mosquitoes. This type of spinifex grows on sandstone and limestone areas.
\cf
\pc 1Warrwa.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 07/Sep/2015

\lx galanbuga
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge little.red.flying-fox
\de little red flying-fox
\sd H Mammals
\re flying-fox (little red)
\re little red flying-fox
\re Pteropus scapulatus
\sy
\va garrabula
\sc Pteropus scapulatus
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The flesh can be eaten after roasting. It has a strong distinctive smell and taste. This flying-fox is not very common and is smaller than the black flying-fox.
\cf
\pc little_red_flying_fox.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 09/Sep/2015

\lx galbun
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge black.kite
\de black kite, whistling kite
\sd J Birds
\re kite (black)
\re black kite
\re kite (whistling)
\re whistling kite
\re Milvus migrans
\re Haliastur sphenurus
\sy bulugura
\sy bulwagngarna
\va
\sc Milvus migrans
\sc Haliastur sphenurus
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee These birds are often seen near fires hunting for food. They have a distinctive call.
\cf
\pc Whistling_Kite.jpg
\se
\de
\xv Galbun-rdu-ngalang garrab nyangan, ngarin-gu.
\sfx
\xe The black kite is watching us for meat.
\rf ER:ES03_A03_02.110
\dt 6/Aug/2018

\lx galijba
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge yellow.kapok
\de yellow kapok
\sd M Plants
\re kapok (yellow)
\re Cochlospermum fraseri
\sy bulgi
\va
\sc Cochlospermum fraseri
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The fruit are called 'bulung' and the seed is called 'bulgi', and are used as toys by children. The swollen tap root is dug up and eaten raw or lightly roasted. If the plant is larger, the root is not eaten as it is too fibrous. The bark is boiled in water and the liquid used as a wash to treat skin sores and irritations. The water goes red when the bark is boiled, and after washing with it, people have a red glow. Dry straight stems can be used as fire-sticks, to create fire using the traditional drilling and friction method. The inner bark can be peeled off the stem and used as bandages. It can also be used to make string or rope to tie things together or carry things. The twigs can be used to make a small brush which can be used to get honey out of sugarbag that cannot be chopped out of trees. The young green fruit are squeezed onto boils to help draw them out. The inner bark and flowers can be boiled in water and little of the liquid drunk to bring down high temperatures. The yellow flowers indicate that freshwater crocodiles are laying their eggs, and the forming of the fruit indicate that the baby crocodiles are growing. When the fruit split open the eggs have hatched and the baby crocodiles are out of the eggs.
\cf
\pc galijba.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 20/Aug/2015

\lx gamanyji
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge bulwaddy
\de bulwaddy
\sd M Plants
\re bulwaddy
\re Macropteranthes kekwickii
\sy
\va
\sc Macropteranthes kekwickii
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The wood of this tree is hard and strong; it can be used to make boomerangs, shields and nullu-nullas. The timber is excellent firewood as it produces hot coals that last for a long time. In the past the timber was cut to make posts and rails for stockyards. The wood blunted the saw very quickly because it is very hard. The bark can be burnt to ash and added to tobacco to improve the flavour and make it stronger.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 26/Jan/2018

\lx gamara
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge black-soil.yam
\de black-soil yam
\sd M Plants
\re yam (black-soil)
\re black-soil yam
\re Ipomoea diamantinensis
\sy
\va
\sc Ipomoea diamantinensis
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This plant grows on black soil plains that are very waterlogged in the wet season. The yams are good to eat and are long like sweet potatoes. The yam may be dug up easily because they are not very deep and the black soil is easy to dig. Some of the plants have a number of yams under them and some only have one yam. They are best dug up soon after the wet season finishes when the soil is still soft. They are eaten after a short roasting in hot coals.
\cf
\pc gamara.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 07/Sep/2015

\lx gambajawung
\sf
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge black.bream
\de black bream, sooty grunter
\sd K Water Animals
\re bream (black)
\re black bream
\re grunter (sooty)
\re sooty grunter
\re Hephaestus fuliginosus
\sy jiwug
\va
\sc Hephaestus fuliginosus
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a word from the northern and western areas.
\ee This is one of the most favoured fish because the flesh is very tasty. They are quite common and are easy to catch on hand-lines in waterholes and creeks. The flesh is roasted on hot coals or cooked on the stove.
\cf
\pc black_bream.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\sn 2
\ge Butler's.grunter
\de Butler's grunter
\sd K Water Animals
\re Butler's grunter
\re Syncomistes butleri
\sy gambajawung
\va
\sc Syncomistes butleri
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee Butler's grunter is very similar to the black bream and has the same names and uses.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 22/Sep/2015

\lx gambangayi
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge firefly
\de firefly
\sd L Insects and Spiders
\re firefly
\re Coleoptera, Lampyridae
\sy
\va
\sc Coleoptera, Lampyridae
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This small insect can be seen at night. It has a blinking light in its body. When they can be seen blinking at night, it indicates that the conkerberry (ngamanburru), the white currant (gumbulyu) and the bush grape (maguriny) have ripe fruit and are ready to be collected. Children sometimes play with 'gambangayi' because of their blinking lights.
\cf
\pc Firefly.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 21/Sep/2015

\lx gambarrngany
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge bull.shark
\de bull shark
\sd K Water Animals
\re shark (bull)
\re bull shark
\re Carcharhinus leucas
\sy bernang
\sy nuniny
\va
\sc Carcharhinus leucas
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The flesh can be eaten and is very tasty. The fat is also good to eat. The large ones are hard to catch and pull ashore. When landed they must be hit hard and quickly on the head to kill them. When they thrash on the bank they are very dangerous.
\cf
\pc bull_shark.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 09/Sep/2015

\lx gambawaji
\sf

\sn

\de Children's python
\sd I Reptiles
\re python (Children's)
\re Children's python
\re Antaresia childreni
\sy gumaji, walujabi, namijnamij, waluru
\va
\sc Antaresia childreni
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a word from the northern and western areas.
\ee This small python is considered to be the offspring of the black-headed python and has the same names. It has pretty markings on the skin.

\lx gambijung
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge bush.cockroach
\de bush cockroach
\sd L Insects and Spiders
\re cockroach (bush)
\re bush cockroach
\re Blattodea, Cosmozosteria spp.
\sy ngabujgariny
\sy gumbilirr
\va
\sc Senna notabilis
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The leaves and stems are boiled in water and the red coloured liquid used as a warm wash to treat coughs, colds, headaches and flu. It may also be used to treat boils, skin sores and itchy skin. It is very effective and will cure most skin disorders in a few days of use. The shiny brown fruit look like bush cockroaches (gumbilirr).
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 28/Aug/2015

\lx gamul
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge camel
\de camel
\sd H Mammals
\re camel
\re Camelus dromedarius
\sy yiningurru
\sy yugibgaji
\va
\sc Camelus dromedarius
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This word is from Kriol. In the past they were used at some places, like the Victoria River Downs, to carry loads. They could carry long and heavy loads and would sit down to be loaded and unloaded. They occur as feral animals further to the south.
\cf

\de
\xv
\sfx

\lx gamuyu
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge praying.mantis
\de praying mantis, stick insect
\sd L Insects and Spiders
\re praying mantis
\re stick insect
\re Mantodea
\re Phasmatodea
\sy wijirrgardi
\va
\sc Mantodea
\sc Phasmatodea
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee These insects sometimes hold their front legs up like they are praying and sometimes look like sticks. They have no specific use but there is a song about them. The Ngarinyman names can also be used to refer to whirlwinds.

\lx ganawuna
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge lancewood
\de lancewood
\sd M Plants
\re lancewood
\re Acacia shirleyi
\sy
\va
\sc Acacia shirleyi
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The wood of this tree is hard and strong and dark in colour. It makes excellent firewood because it burns evenly for long periods. The smoke from burning wood repels mosquitoes. The stems can be used for bough shelters, fence rails and fence posts. The wood is also used for boomerangs, clap sticks, spear heads and nulla-nullas.
\cf
\pc lancewood.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 12/Aug/2015

\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee There are several types of ticks; they live on many native mammals, dogs and occasionally people.
\cf

\se

\xv
\sfx

\dt 21/Sep/2015

\xe Did you bring the spear stone over here?

\xv Yingga-man ganyarni?
\sfx
\xe Did you bring the spear stone over here?
\rf NH:CJ:21/06/1995
\xv Ganggurni-nggu mangarri.
\sfx
\xe She's going to bring you tucker.
\rf NH:CJ:21/06/1995

\dt 05/Sep/2008

\lx gangarn
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge bush.plum
\de plum (bush)
\sd M Plants
\re
\re Grewia retusifolia
\sy
\va
\sc Grewia retusifolia
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The brown shiny fruit are eaten. They are very tasty. The fruit are also eaten by bush turkeys (jamud) and emus (nangurrungurru). When there are a lot of fruit on the plants it is a good place to hunt for turkeys as they will be attracted to the fruit. The leaves can be boiled in water and the liquid used to treat skin sores. It can also be drunk to treat diarrhoea.
\cf
\pc dibirl.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 28/Aug/2015

\sn

\sd K Water Animals

\re Pristis microdon
\sy gunbulu

\sc Pristis microdon

\lx ganyjulurr
\sf
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge water.chestnut
\de water chestnut
\sd M Plants
\re water chestnut
\re Eleocharis dulcis
\sy walanggarr
\va
\sc Eleocharis dulcis
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The small chestnuts at the base of the stems can be collected and lightly roasted in hot ashes. They are then eaten. They have a crunchy texture and a pleasant taste. Magpie geese (marnawirri) also eat these chestnuts.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\sn 2
\ge water.yam
\de water yam
\sd M Plants
\re yam (water)
\re water yam
\re Triglochin dubium
\sy
\va
\sc Triglochin dubium
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The small yams are dug from the floor of billabongs and creeks and lightly roasted then eaten. They are very tasty.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 26/Jan/2018

\lx garaga
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge frill-necked.lizard
\de frill-necked lizard, blanket lizard
\sd I Reptiles
\re lizard (frill-necked)
\re frill-necked lizard
\re lizard (blanket)
\re blanket lizard
\re Chlamydosaurus kingi
\sy ngarranginy
\sy gardan.ga
\sy jaman.gula
\va
\sc Chlamydosaurus kingi
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The flesh can be eaten after roasting. The flesh and fat are tasty. The frill or blanket is burnt on ashes until it turns black and it is then rubbed with fat. This is in turn rubbed through the hair to make it go dark and healthy; it makes big hair. It can also be rubbed onto the head of a baby so they grow up with healthy hair. When the rains begin the blanket lizard runs around eating ants. They are cheeky and will chase you and try to bite you.
\cf
\pc frilled_neck_lizard.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 20/Sep/2015

\lx garawa

\sd J Birds
\re eagle (wedge-tailed)
\re wedge-tailed eagle
\re Aquila audax
\sy lajabali
\sy jardarra
\sy warlawurru
\va
\sc Aquila audax
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a Yarralin word.
\ee This large eagle is an excellent hunter; it can catch small wallabies and kangaroos. It takes them high in the air and drops them to kill them. It is often seen by the side of the road eating road-kill.

\dt 25/Jul/2008

\lx gardan.ga
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge frill-necked.lizard
\de frill-necked lizard, blanket lizard
\sd I Reptiles
\re lizard (frill-necked)
\re frill-necked lizard
\re lizard (blanket)
\re blanket lizard
\re Chlamydosaurus kingi
\sy ngarranginy
\sy garaga
\sy jaman.gula
\va
\sc Chlamydosaurus kingi
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a Yarralin word.
\ee The flesh can be eaten after roasting, the flesh and fat are tasty. The frill or blanket is burnt on ashes until it turns black and it is then rubbed with fat. This is in turn rubbed through the hair to make it go dark and healthy; it makes big hair. It can also be rubbed onto the head of a baby so they grow up with healthy hair. When the rains begin the blanket lizard runs around eating ants. They are cheeky and will chase you and try to bite you.
\cf
\pc frilled_neck_lizard.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 20/Sep/2015

\lx gardanyin
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge stringybark
\de stringybark
\sd M Plants
\re stringybark
\re Eucalyptus tetrodonta
\sy
\va
\sc Eucalyptus tetrodonta
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The bark can be peeled off in large sheets after the wet season when the sap is flowing well. These large sheets of bark are waterproof and can be used for many purposes. In the past they were used for making waterproof humpies in the wet season and large rounded coolamons for carrying food and babies. The bark is also used for bark paintings. 'Gardanyin' only occurs in the far northern areas and is not seen in other areas.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 25/Aug/2015

\lx gardbibarndal
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge buffalo
\de buffalo
\sd H Mammals
\re buffalo
\re Bubalus bubalis
\sy mun.gurru
\sy windurru
\sy windurruyawung
\sy maranji
\sy wumburrurru
\va
\sc Bubalus bubalis
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a word from the northern and western areas.
\ee There are occasionally wild buffalo still seen but most were killed during the BTEC scheme in the 1980s and 1990s. The meat is good to eat, especially from young ones. It has a strong taste. Buffalo are cranky and dangerous in the bush.
\cf

\xv

\lx garil
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge bush.cucumber
\de bush cucumber
\sd M Plants
\re bush cucumber
\re cucumber (bush)
\re Cucumis melo
\sy madawug
\sy gidbany
\va
\sc Cucumis melo
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The fruit may be eaten when they are ripe, light green. The fruit must be rubbed before eating to remove any short hairs that may be on the outside. If these are not removed the lips and tongue can become sore and painful. The fruit have a sweet taste and crispy texture when ripe. When fully ripe they have a strong sweet fruity smell. Sometimes they are found in large numbers.
\cf
\pc gaaril.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 06/Sep/2015

\dt 25/Aug/2005

\lx garlarr
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge spinifex.pigeon
\de spinifex pigeon, Indian-head pigeon
\sd J Birds
\re pigeon (spinifex)
\re spinifex pigeon
\re pigeon (Indian-head)
\re Indian-head pigeon
\re Geophaps plumifera
\sy widijburru
\sy marrawung
\va
\sc Geophaps plumifera
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a word from the northern and western areas.
\ee The spinifex pigeon is sometimes called Indian-head because of the feathers sticking up from its head and it has a stripe on its face similar to war-paint. It has a distinctive call: coo.coo.coo.coo.coo.coo. Sometimes it is called 'gumundunga' in reference to the feathers sticking up on its head. The name 'widijburru' was also the personal name of Bobby Widijburru. The meat can be eaten after roasting and it is tender and tasty.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 08/Sep/2015

\lx garnba
\sf
\ps adv
\sn
\ge fast
\de fast, quick, hurry, do something fast
\sd P Moving
\re fast
\re quick
\sy jirrimana
\sy wirrggarra
\sy burrjib
\va
\ve
\sc
\so NH,MJ,N:CJ:11/5/95, NH,KJ:6/6/95 , NH,KJ,PS:CJ:98
\xv Garnba-rni-lu gaway!
\sfx
\xe Hurry up you mob!
\rf NH,MJ,N:CJ:11/5/95, NH,KJ:6/6/95 , NH,KJ,PS:CJ:98
\xv Garnba, gawayi! Gawayi garnba!
\sfx
\xe Hurry up, come here!
\rf NH,MJ,N:CJ:11/5/95, NH,KJ:6/6/95 , NH,KJ,PS:CJ:98
\xv Garnba gawayi-rla!
\sfx
\xe Hurry up, come here you two!
\rf NH,MJ,N:CJ:11/5/95, NH,KJ:6/6/95 , NH,KJ,PS:CJ:98

\lx garnbanga
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge sugarleaf
\de sugar-leaf, sweet-leaf (lerps)
\sd L Insects and Spiders
\re sugarleaf
\re sweet-leaf
\re lerps
\re Hemiptera
\re Psyllidae
\sy nanjarrgadag
\sy jalyingarna
\va
\sc Hemiptera
\sc Psyllidae
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a Timber Creek word.
\ee These small white scale-like insect-coverings are collected off the bloodwood (jardburra) and the river red gum tree (dimarlan) leaves during the cold weather time and eaten. They are very sweet and tasty. The branches and twigs are broken off and left to dry over a calico sheet. The lerps are then collected and shaped into small balls and eaten. These balls used to be stored in cake-tins for weeks and months. This food has special cultural significance for Ngarinyman people.
\cf
\pc Lerps.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 21/Sep/2015

\lx garnngurinyi
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge waterlily
\de waterlily
\sd M Plants
\re waterlily
\re Nymphaea macrosperma
\sy
\va
\sc Nymphaea macrosperma
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This waterlily is similar to Nymphaea violacea except it has larger seeds and is only found in deeper water in billabongs, not creeks or swampy areas. The large fruit are called 'nardi'. The seeds are ground on stones and the flour made into small dampers, these are wrapped in the large leaves and then cooked and eaten. The yellow tuber is dug out of the mud, roasted and eaten to treat diarrhoea.
\cf
\pc mindaarraj.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 07/Sep/2015

\lx garra
\sf

\sn
\ge spider
\de spider
\sd L Insects and Spiders
\re spider
\re Arachnida, Araneae
\sy marawun
\sy darru
\sy garrada
\sy jamabngarrawu
\va
\sc Arachnida, Araneae
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010

\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a Timber Creek word.
\ee All spiders have the same name although many different types of spider are recognised and some are dangerous. The red-back spider has a painful bite that causes a lot of swelling. The spider web is called 'jambangarrawu' or 'garrada'.

\lx garrada

\sn

\lx garrajgarraj
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge curry.orange
\de curry orange
\sd M Plants
\re curry orange
\re Ziziphus quadrilocularis
\sy
\va
\sc Ziziphus quadrilocularis
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The fruit are eaten when they are ripe, brown. They are tasty although a little bitter. The fruit can also be collected from the ground when they are dry and eaten. If the fruit are bitter they can be boiled in water with sugar to make them sweet. The fruit are ripe during the cold weather time of the year in the middle of the dry season. The leafy, rounded canopy provides dense, cool shade. The timber is good firewood.
\cf
\pc garrajgarraj.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf

\lx garralbinang
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge giant.glassfish
\de giant glassfish, or northwest glassfish
\sd K Water Animals
\re glassfish (giant)
\re glassfish (northwest)
\re Ambassis spp.
\sy
\va
\sc Ambassis spp.
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee These small fish are used as bait to catch larger fish. Larger ones can be eaten after roasting on hot coals and ashes. 'Garralbinang' is a close countryman for the bony bream (buliny) and tarpon (gulayi).

\lx garriwarna
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge wallaroo
\de wallaroo, blue or hill kangaroo, euro
\sd H Mammals
\re wallaroo
\re kangaroo (blue)
\re blue kangaroo
\re kangaroo (hill)
\re hill kangaroo
\re Euro
\re Macropus robustus
\sy yarrangun
\sy minawud
\sy winangburru
\va
\sc Macropus robustus
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a word from the northern and western areas.
\ee These kangaroos are often seen in hilly areas and are good to eat after roasting. They are often called the blue kangaroo due to the dark, woolly fur that is bluish in colour. 'Garriwarna' is a term used in the northern and western areas for the male of this species.

\lx garrmingga
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge dollarbird
\de dollarbird
\sd J Birds
\re
\re Eurystomus orientalis
\sy jabardarrdang
\va
\sc Eurystomus orientalis
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a word from the northern and western areas.
\ee Often seen perching high in a dead tree trying to get a good view of insects to hunt, they are most active at dawn and dusk. They can be heard calling in the wet season. They often tap their beaks on the stick they are perched on.
\cf
\pc Dollarbird.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 08/Sep/2015

\lx garrnggarrng
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge darter
\de darter, cormorant
\sd J Birds
\re darter
\re cormorant
\re Anhinga melanogaster
\re Phalacrocorax spp.
\sy jinggijburru
\sy barragbarrag
\va
\sc Anhinga melanogaster
\sc Phalacrocorax spp.
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The meat can be eaten after roasting; it is good to eat and tastes like chicken. They live near the water and eat fish. They often perch on trees and hold their wings out to dry. These birds have spiritual importance for Ngarinyman people.
\cf
\pc darter.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx

\sd H Mammals
\re bat (micro)
\sy jiniminy
\va

\lx gawugawu
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge nankeen.night.heron
\de nankeen night heron
\sd J Birds
\re night heron (nankeen)
\re Nycticorax caledonicus
\sy gawurlnga
\va
\sc Nycticorax caledonicus
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This bird hides in thick bush near rivers and makes strange noises; it gives a warning that someone is approaching when you hear it call. 'Gawugawu' sleeps during the day and is hard to see because it always hides in thick vegetation. The meat can be eaten after roasting on hot coals and ashes.
\cf
\pc nankeen.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 07/Sep/2015

\lx gid
\sf
\ps cv
\sn
\ge break.up
\de break off, break up
\sd T Impact
\re break up
\sy
\va
\ve
\sc
\so NH:CJ:23/6/95, KJ:JM1-005 2016
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf Bilinarra
\lv gird
\pc
\se gid manan
\de break something (e.g. break a stick in half)
\xv Gid-barna mani.
\sfx
\xe I broke it.
\rf JC?:JM1-012 2016 book 1, p10
\xv Gid-barna mani, nyawa gunyja garu-gari-wu.
\sfx
\xe I broke the lolly in half for the other kid.
\rf JC,CD,MS:CJ:2018
\xv Mangarri na gambala gid-barna mana mangarri-ma jardgarra-wu nalijarra.
\sfx
\xe I cooked damper and I broke it in half and had some with my tea.
\rf KJ:JM1-019 2016 book 2, p48
\se gidgid manan
\de break it up, break it into pieces (as in tearing johnny cakes apart)
\xv Mangarri-ma-n nyila-ma gidgid mani.
\sfx
\xe You broke the damper.
\rf NH:CJ:23/6/95
\xv Mangarri-ma gidgid manan yabayabag.
\sfx
\xe She broke the bread into small pieces.
\rf ES:JM1-012 2016 book 2, p10
\se gid barrany
\de break up (e.g. by throwing a stick that you can't break with your hands against a big log to break it)
\xv Janggarni garndi gid bani.
\sfx
\xe He broke up the big branch.
\rf CD:JM1-017 2016 book 2, p30
\xv Gula-rna gid barru janggarni garndi.
\sfx
\xe I can't break up the big branch.
\rf CD:JM1-017 2016 book 2, p30
\se gidgid barrany
\de break up into pieces, break lots of things
\xv Gidgid-barla barrany.
\sfx
\xe He's throwing it down to break it up.
\rf JC:JM1-017 2016 book 2, p30
\xv Garu-nggu gidgid barrany yabayaba garndi.
\sfx
\xe The kid is breaking the branches into small pieces.
\rf JC:JM1-019 216 book 2, p49
\se gid jayingan
\de break something to share it out
\xv Gid jayingga-yi yabagaru.
\sfx
\xe Break me off a piece.
\rf ES:JM1-012 2016 book 2, p10
\se gid yanan
\de fall apart, split
\xv Gula gid yan.gu nyama garndi-ma.
\sfx
\xe The branch wouldn't split.
\rf CD:JM1-017 2017 book 2, p30
\xv Gula gid yan.gu bandij.
\sfx
\xe The branch couldn't break (because) it was too wet.
\rf JT:JM1-017 2016 book 2, p30
\se gid wandany
\de fall and break
\xv Gid-barna waninya.
\sfx
\xe I fell and broke my leg.
\rf JC:JM1-019 2016 book 2, p46
\xv Gid wanda nyila garndi janggarni mun.gud-jawung.
\sfx
\xe The big tree broke, it has white ants in it.
\rf KJ:JM1-019 2016 book 2, p50
\se gidbari
\de broken
\dt 25/Nov/2008

\re bush cucumber
\re cucumber (bush)
\re Cucumis melo

\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a Yarralin word.
\ee The fruit may be eaten when they are ripe, light green. The fruit must be rubbed before eating to remove any short hairs that may be on the outside. If these are not removed the lips and tongue can become sore and painful. The fruit have a sweet taste and crispy texture when ripe. When fully ripe they have a strong sweet fruity smell. Sometimes they are found in large numbers. 'Gidbany' is the term for a large bush cucumber.
\cf
\pc girdbarn.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 06/Sep/2015

\lx gilibi
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge bush.banana
\de bush banana
\sd M Plants
\re banana (bush)
\re bush banana
\re Marsdenia australis
\re Marsdenia viridiflora
\sy yurrudu
\va
\sc Marsdenia australis
\sc Marsdenia viridiflora
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The fruit and leaves may be eaten. They are sweet and tasty. The young fruit are the best to eat as they are soft and crunchy. Older fruit become hard and chewy and they may be softened by lightly roasting on hot coals. The flowers can also be eaten. The new fruit that are found in the heavy rain time of the wet season are small and round, and contain a lot of juice; they are the tastiest to eat.
\cf
\pc gilibi.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 06/Sep/2015

\lx gininggi
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge coolibah
\de coolibah
\sd M Plants
\re coolibah
\re Eucalyptus microtheca
\sy wulwaji
\sy gunjalng
\va
\sc Eucalyptus microtheca
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee Sugarbag (native bee-hives) can be found in this tree. The timber is good firewood for cooking. Didgeridoos can be made from hollowed stems and branches of a suitable size. The bark can be burnt to a fine white ash which is mixed with chewing tobacco. When 'gininggi' is in flower it indicates that sharks are fat and it is a good time to hunt for them.
\cf
\pc coolibah.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 25/Aug/2015

\lx ginirriny
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge green.tree.snake
\de green tree snake, brown tree snake
\sd I Reptiles
\re tree snake (green)
\re tree snake (brown)
\re Dendrelaphis punctulata
\re Boiga irregularis
\sy jamarlangmarlang
\sy warndawarndang
\va
\sc Dendrelaphis punctulata
\sc Boiga irregularis
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a Yarralin word.
\ee This is a harmless snake that lives in trees, especially pandanus and other trees near rivers and creeks. It cannot hurt you but can give you a fright when it appears close to you when you are fishing. It is considered to be a naughty snake as it does not follow cultural laws. It has a small brain, and it plays up a lot.
\cf
\pc green_tree_snake.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 20/Sep/2015

\lx ginyjiwurnu
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge bamboo
\de bamboo
\sd M Plants
\re bamboo
\re Bambusa arnhemica
\sy milinyin
\va
\sc Bambusa arnhemica
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The flexible stems are used as spear shafts; it is valued for its strength, flexibility and longevity. It is traded from areas to the north as it does not naturally grow in Ngarinyman country.

\lx ginyang
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge eel-tail.catfish
\de eel-tail catfish, Hyrtl's tandan
\sd K Water Animals
\re catfish (eel-tail)
\re eel-tail catfish
\re Hyrtl's tandan
\re Neosilurus hyrtlii
\sy marnba
\va
\sc Neosilurus hyrtlii and other taxa
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The larger ones can be roasted and eaten. The flesh is tasty. The smaller ones are used as bait to catch larger fish such as barramundi. These catfish also have poisonous spines that must be carefully avoided. The spines cause a great deal of pain and swelling and are very dangerous. They are generally caught with nets or spears and do not take bait on hand-lines.
\cf
\pc flat-tailed_catfish.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf

\lx ginyuwurra
\sf
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge bush.onion
\de bush onion
\sd M Plants
\re Cyperus sp.
\sy nyunurrbany
\va
\sc Cyperus sp.
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The small underground tubers are used as medicine. They are chewed in the mouth and are similar to chewing gum as they last for a long time. They are not swallowed but just chewed. This is used to treat colds and general sickness. The small tubers are eaten by brolgas and kangaroos.
\cf
\pc ginyiwurra.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\sn 2
\ge sedge
\de sedge
\sd M Plants
\re Eleocharis sphacelata
\sy
\va
\sc Eleocharis sphacelata
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The thick white lateral roots in the mud are dug up and eaten by kangaroos and brolgas.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx

\lx girrawa
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge sand.goanna
\de sand goanna, plains goanna
\sd I Reptiles
\re goanna (sand)
\re sand goanna
\re goanna (plains)
\re plains goanna
\re Varanus panoptes
\sy jurlumirri
\sy warlgan
\sy dilyarri
\va
\sc Varanus panoptes
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This is the biggest goanna. It can get very large and has a lot of tasty flesh. The language name can also be used to refer to goannas in general, however, they are used for this goanna as it is the largest and best known. 'Girrawa' is the male and 'jurlumirri' is the female of this species.
\cf
\pc sand_goanna.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 21/Sep/2015

\de quiet, not talking

\sy
\va
\ve
\sc
\so SK, NP, ER:ESB , NH,IW:CJ:98, NH:CJ:2005

\xe Be quiet, don't talk!
\rf JK:CM:2008
\xv Girrb garrinya ngajigbarni.
\sfx
\xe He doesn't talk anymore.

\de become quiet

\dt 03/Jul/2017

\lx girribi
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge wild.passionfruit
\de wild passionfruit
\sd M Plants
\re passionfruit (wild)
\re Passiflora foetida
\sy wulungari
\va
\sc Passiflora foetida
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a word from the northern and western areas.
\ee The inner flesh of the yellow-orange fruit can be eaten. It is especially favoured by children. Many birds also eat the fruit. The leaves can be boiled in water and the liquid used as a wash to treat scabies, itchy skin and ringworm. The leaves and stems can also be used as fish poison. They are dragged through the water and this has the effect of stunning the fish so that they float to the surface and can be easily collected, then cooked and eaten. The slightly sticky leaves and stems must not be put near your eyes as the juice can cause very sore eyes.
\cf
\pc passionfruit.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 06/Sep/2015

\lx girribudbuda
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge pheasant.coucal
\de pheasant coucal
\sd J Birds
\re pheasant coucal
\re Centropus phasianinus
\sy durldurl
\sy wubub
\va girribud, girribug
\sc Centropus phasianinus
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee Girribudbuda calls woop...woop...woop in the wet season to make the cheeky yam (jarrwana) grow fat and produce lots of seed. It is a large, dark brown bird that often runs along the ground and then flies up into a tree.
\cf
\pc pheasant.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf

\dt 27/May/2008

\lx gubamarlu
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge water.python
\de water python, rainbow snake
\sd I Reptiles
\re python (water)
\re water python
\re rainbow snake
\re Liasis fuscus
\sy jimurug
\sy gunudjarri
\va
\sc Liasis fuscus
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee These pythons live in waterholes, and can be caught by hand or speared with light spears. They are cooked in the same way as the black-headed python. They can get very large and have a lot of meat that tastes similar to goanna flesh. There is an important Dreamtime story about this snake.
\cf
\pc water_python.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 20/Sep/2015

\dt 20/Feb/2018

\lx gubuwubu
\sf
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge lemon.grass
\de lemon grass
\sd M Plants
\re Cymbopogon bombycinus
\sy guruguruny
\va
\sc Cymbopogon bombycinus
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a Yarralin word.
\ee The leaves and stems are used as medicine. They are boiled in water and the liquid used as a washing medicine to treat colds and influenza. The red gum from Eucalyptus terminalis (dirnung) can be added and a little of the liquid drunk to make the treatment more effective. It is considered an excellent medicine with strong healing properties. It is especially effective for small children. A small amount can be drunk to treat colds and influenza.
\cf
\pc gubuwubu.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\sn 2
\ge lemon.grass
\de lemon grass
\sd M Plants
\re grass (lemon)
\re lemon grass
\re Cymbopogon procerus
\sy guruguruny
\va
\sc Cymbopogon procerus
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a Yarralin word.
\ee The leaves and stems may be chopped and boiled in a little water. The liquid can be used as a wash to treat colds and flu. The woody stems can also be used as toy spears by children.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 06/Sep/2015

\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge sedge
\de sedge like a bush onion
\sd M Plants
\re Cyperus macrostachyos
\sy
\va
\sc
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010

\sfx
\xe She was angry now.

\lx gulinjirri
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge shitwood.tree
\de shitwood tree, helicopter tree
\sd M Plants
\re shitwood tree
\re helicopter tree
\re Gyrocarpus americanus
\sy
\va
\sc Gyrocarpus americanus
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The soft wood is used to make coolamons; it is the best wood for coolamons as it is easy to carve but strong and floats very well. The two-winged fruit are used as toy helicopters by children. The inner bark is used as medicine. It is crushed and boiled in water and the liquid used as a wash to treat ringworm.
\cf
\pc shitwood.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf

\re Gallinula ventralis
\sy gulya

\xv

\lx gulumarrangarna
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge silver.catfish
\de silver catfish
\sd K Water Animals
\re catfish (silver)
\re silver catfish
\re Arius graeffei
\sy warrag
\va
\sc Arius graeffei
\so LR:KH:2007, SK:CJ:4/6/95
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This catfish has a short nose. You can roast and eat it. However, the spines or prickles on the fins are dangerous.  You should break off the spines and burn them on the fire or throw them back in the water. If you step on the spine, you should slap the area with the tail of the fish. This stops the pain and swelling.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 20/Feb/2018

\lx gulun

\de ti-tree
\sd M Plants
\re Melaleuca bracteata
\sy manggalng
\va
\sc Melaleuca bracteata
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This is a small tree that has small leaves. It occurs in bush country and the bark is not used as it is not available in large enough pieces. Trees often contain sugarbag and when they are in flower the sugarbag is full of honey.

\xv

\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The papery bark can be used to light fires and to make small coolamons. This small tree is a favoured host of native bee-hives.

\lx gumbulyu
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge white.currant
\de white currant, white plum
\sd M Plants
\re currant (white)
\re white currant
\re Flueggea virosa
\sy jurrulana
\va
\sc Flueggea virosa
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The white fruit are eaten when they are ripe; they are very sweet and tasty. The fruit are produced in the middle of the wet season. Some people don't like the taste of this fruit. The straight dry stems are used to make fire-sticks or bush matches, or used to light a fire using the traditional drilling or friction method. The bark and the skin of the roots can be scraped off and soaked in water. The liquid is drunk to treat swelling and to increase urine output. It is especially good for people who have walked a long way and who have tired and swollen legs.
\pc gumbulyu.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 25/Aug/2015

\ee This tree has hard dark wood that can be used to make boomerangs. The long narrow beans contain yellow and green seeds. This tree only grows in the most southern areas of Ngarinyman country. It does not occur in the northern areas and is not known to Ngarinyman people from northern areas.

\dt 21/Jul/2012

\lx gundaj
\sf
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge wattle
\de wattle
\sd M Plants
\re wattle
\re Acacia (Vachellia) pallidifolia
\sy
\va
\sc Acacia (Vachellia) pallidifolia
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This is a good shade tree as it provides dense cool shade to sit under. The pale, light timber can be used to make the shaft of a woomera. The bark is chipped off and boiled in water; the liquid is allowed to cool and used as an external wash to treat skin sores. The gum that comes from damage to the branches and trunks can be eaten; it is clear and sweet to taste.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\sn 2
\ge wattle
\de wattle
\sd M Plants
\re Acacia (Vachellia) valida
\sy
\va
\sc Acacia (Vachellia) valida
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This is a good shade tree as it provides dense cool shade to sit under. The gum that comes from damage to the branches and trunks can be eaten; it is clear and sweet to taste. If it is hard it may softened near the hot coals of a fire. The pale, light timber can be used to make the shaft of a woomera.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 17/Aug/2015

\dt 12/Nov/2011

\lx gunggarla
\sf
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge fire-stick.tree
\de fire-stick tree
\sd M Plants
\re firestick tree
\re Clerodendrum floribundum
\sy
\va
\sc Clerodendrum floribundum
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The smooth, straight stems and branches are used to make fire-sticks or bush matches to light a fire using the traditional drilling or friction method. A straight, smooth, narrow stem is cut to about 40 cm long, and a broader heavier piece is cut and a small round hole with a vee carved into it. One end of the narrow stick is placed in the hole of the heavier stick. The narrow stick is then rotated quickly between the palms with a strong downward pressure. This drilling creates friction which in turn produces a very hot, fine dust. This dust pours down the vee carved into the wood onto a clump of fine, dry grass previously placed underneath. The grass and the very hot dust are gently blown upon until flame appears. These fire-sticks were carried everywhere and could be used many times. In the wet season they were wrapped in paperbark to keep them dry. This is one of the best fire-stick trees; the wood is hard and develops heat very quickly.
\cf
\pc gunggarla.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\sn 2
\ge fire-stick.tree
\de fire-stick tree
\sd M Plants
\re
\re Premna acuminata
\sy
\va
\sc Premna acuminata
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The smooth, straight stems and branches are used to make fire-sticks or bush matches, to light a fire using the traditional drilling or friction method, called 'binyinyib' (rubbing them together to make fire).
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\sn 3
\ge tree.species
\de type of tree
\sd M Plants
\re Wrightia saligna
\sy
\va
\sc Wrightia saligna
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This small tree has very thin leaves, straight stems and the wood is smooth and strong. The dry straight stems can be used to make fire-sticks and they are a good shape and size for this purpose.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 20/Aug/2015

\lx gunudjarri
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge water.python
\de water python, rainbow snake
\sd I Reptiles
\re python (water)
\re water python
\re rainbow snake
\re Liasis fuscus
\sy gubamarlu
\sy jimurug
\va
\sc Liasis fuscus
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a Yarralin word.
\ee These are big but non-aggressive and they sun themselves on rocks. These pythons live in waterholes, and can be caught by hand or speared with light spears. They are cooked in the same way as the black-headed python. They can get very large and have a lot of meat that tastes similar to goanna flesh. There is an important Dreamtime story about this snake.
\cf
\pc water_python.jpg

\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf

\dt 07/Sep/2015

\lx gurlinyaga
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge bush.orange
\de bush orange
\sd M Plants
\re bush orange
\re orange (bush)
\re Capparis umbonata
\sy yumarli
\sy juguru
\va
\sc Capparis umbonata
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The fruit are eaten when they are ripe, a slightly orange-yellow colour. The fruit are sweet and very tasty. The unripe fruit can be buried in the sand to help ripen them; sometimes this might take as long as two weeks. The wood can be used as firewood as it lights quickly and easily. When the fruit are ripe they have a strong pleasant smell, which can be noticed from a long way from the plant. It is difficult to stop eating the fruit when you can smell the sweet scent from them. The bark can be boiled in water and used as a washing medicine to treat scabies. When the large flooding rains of the full wet season are coming this plant can be used to chase the rains away. The leaves are placed on a fire to make smoke, and this is waved towards the rain clouds to make them go away.
\cf
\pc gurlardardi.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 19/Aug/2015

\dt 14/Sep/2017

\lx gurndurung
\sf
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge woollybutt
\de woollybutt
\sd M Plants
\re woollybutt
\re Eucalyptus miniata
\sy
\va
\sc Eucalyptus miniata
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The hollow branches and stems can be used to make didgeridoos. Sugarbag (native bee-hives) can be found in this tree. This species is only known from northern areas, where it can be common, but it does not occur in more southern parts of Ngarinyman country.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\sn 2
\ge hill.woollybutt
\de hill woollybutt
\sd M Plants
\re woollybutt (hill)
\re Eucalyptus phoenicea
\sy
\va
\sc Eucalyptus phoenicea
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee Stems of the appropriate diameter that have been hollowed by termites can be used to make didgeridoos. Sugarbag (native bee-hives) can often be found in this tree. It is a good shade tree on the rocky hills where it grows.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 25/Aug/2015

\dt 17/Nov/2011

\lx gurrang
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge mosquito
\de mosquito
\sd L Insects and Spiders
\re mosquito
\re Diptera, Culicidae
\sy bayarnumirralng, miril, wamajngarna
\va
\sc Diptera, Culicidae
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee Mosquitoes are often active at dawn and dusk and they suck your blood. They can be chased away by lighting a smokey fire or by placing dry manure from horses or cattle on the coals. The smoke from burning gutta-percha (manyingila) and conkerberry (ngamanburru) is especially good for repelling mosquitos.
\cf
\pc Mosquito.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 21/Sep/2015

\lx gurrurrungguny
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge nail-tail.kangaroo
\de nail-tail kangaroo, left-hand kangaroo, northern nail-tail wallaby
\sd H Mammals
\re kangaroo (nail-tail)
\re nail-tail kangaroo
\re kangaroo (left-hand)
\re left-hand kangaroo
\re wallaby (northern nail-tail)
\re northern nail-tail wallaby
\re Onychogalea unguifera
\sy ngungungmarna, dugulgul
\va
\sc Onychogalea unguifera
\so RB:ESB
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a Timber Creek word.
\ee This kangaroo has a prickle in the end of its tail and often makes a 'oo..oo..oo' noise when it is hopping. There is a special song that 'ngungungmarna' sings as he hops along. This name refers to the sound it makes. It also holds its left arm up to its chest when hopping. The flesh can be eaten after roasting in a ground oven, but it is not eaten as often as the other kangaroos and wallabies.
\cf
\pc Northern_nailtail_wallaby.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 20/Feb/2018

\lx guru
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge camp.dog
\de camp dog
\sd H Mammals
\re dog
\re Canis familiaris
\sy wangarni
\sy warlagu
\sy miji
\va
\sc Canis familiaris
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv Guru marrug wandinyang bili-ngga birala.
\xe The dog hid behind a rock.
\rf BFF: ES96_A07_02_Ngar_Frog.139
\ue
\ee These dogs are like dingoes but are quieter and easier to train to be pets and hunting companions, however, they do not have the bush skills and savvy of dingoes. 'Miji' is the term for female.

\lx gurugudug
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge Chara
\de type of water plant
\sd M Plants
\re Chara sp.
\sy
\va
\sc Chara sp.
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This plant grows in water and fish and turtles often hide under it. If you handle it your skin can become itchy and irritated.
