\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 07/Sep/2015

\lx guruguruny
\sf
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge lemon.grass
\de lemon grass
\sd M Plants
\re Cymbopogon bombycinus
\sy gubuwubu
\va
\sc Cymbopogon bombycinus
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a word from the northern and western areas.
\ee The leaves and stems are used as medicine. They are boiled in water and the liquid used as a washing medicine to treat colds and influenza. The red gum from Eucalyptus terminalis (dirnung) can be added and a little of the liquid drunk to make the treatment more effective. It is considered an excellent medicine with strong healing properties. It is especially effective for small children. A small amount can be drunk to treat colds and influenza.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\sn 2
\ge lemon.grass
\de lemon grass
\sd M Plants
\re grass (lemon)
\re lemon grass
\re Cymbopogon procerus
\sy gubuwubu
\va
\sc Cymbopogon procerus
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a word from the northern and western areas.
\ee The leaves and stems may be chopped and boiled in a little water. The liquid can be used as a wash to treat colds and flu. The woody stems can also be used as toy spears by children.
\cf
\pc gubuwubu.jpg

\sfx

\lx guyamalinggi
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge magpie.goose
\de magpie goose
\sd J Birds
\re goose (magpie)
\re magpie goose
\re Anseranas semipalmata
\sy marnawirri
\sy munama
\va
\sc Anseranas semipalmata
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a Yarralin word.
\ee The meat is really good to eat. They occur in large numbers on the floodplains in northern areas, such as Bradshaw Station. The eggs are also very good to eat. They are collected from the floodplains in the wet season when they are nesting. 'Guyamalinggi' eats the water chestnut and their crops are sometimes full of the small yams. A fan can be made from the wings.
\cf
\pc magpie_goose.jpg
\se
\de

\sfx

\lx jabardardang
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge dollarbird
\de dollarbird
\sd J Birds
\re dollarbird
\re Eurystomus orientalis
\sy garrmingga
\sy derrderr
\sy darrdag

\lx jabawi
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge river.fig
\de fig (river)
\sd M Plants
\re river fig
\re Ficus coronulata
\sy
\va
\sc Ficus coronulata
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The white milky sap is dabbed directly onto skin sores to help heal them. The bark of the stems and leaves are boiled in water and the liquid is used as external wash to treat colds and itchy skins. The fruit are eaten when they are ripe, brown in colour; some people do not eat the fruit. Fish and turtles also eat the fruit. The straight dry stems are used to make fire-sticks or bush matches to light a fire using the traditional drilling or friction method. These fire-sticks were carried everywhere and could be used many times. In the wet season they were wrapped in paperbark to keep them dry. A straight, smooth, narrow stem is cut to about 40 cm long, and a broader heavier piece is cut and a small round hole with a vee carved into it. One end of the narrow stick is placed in the hole of the heavier stick. The narrow stick is then rotated quickly between the palms with a strong downward pressure. This drilling creates friction which in turn produces a very hot, fine dust. This dust pours down the vee carved into the wood onto a clump of fine, dry grass previously placed underneath. The grass and the very hot dust are gently blown upon until flame appears.
\cf
\pc jawawing.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 25/Aug/2015

\lx jabuju
\sf
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge type.of.herb
\de type of herb
\sd M Plants
\re Triumfetta sp.
\sy
\va
\sc Triumfetta sp.
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The leaves are boiled in water and the liquid used as an external wash to treat skin sores and boils.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\sn 2
\ge whirlygig.beetle
\de whirlygig beetle
\sd L Insects and Spiders
\re beetle (whirlygig)
\re Coleoptera, Macrogyrus spp.
\sy ngabilyibilyi
\va
\sc Coleoptera, Macrogyrus spp. and others
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a Timber Creek word.
\ee These small black beetles swim around in circles on the top of water in quiet pools in creeks. They are considered to be the mother of the freshwater turtles and are not harmed in any way.
\cf
\pc
\se

\dt 17/Nov/2011

\lx jardburru
\sf
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge bloodwood
\de bloodwood
\sd M Plants
\re bloodwood
\re Corymbia bleeseri, Corymbia terminalis
\sy
\va jardburru
\sc Corymbia bleeseri
\sc Corymbia terminalis
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The timber is good firewood. Sugarbag (native bee-hive) is often found in this tree. These contain honey, pollen and wax. The outer bark can be chipped off and burnt to a fine white ash to mix with chewing tobacco. Sugar-leaf or lerps (jalyingarna) are found on the leaves of this tree in the hot weather before the rains. These lerps can be eaten straight from the leaves or collected and made into small cakes and eaten later. They are sweet and tasty. The red sap is called 'nganyuwan' and it is used as medicine. It is boiled in water and the liquid used as a wash to treat skin sores or itchy skin. It can also be placed directly onto an aching tooth and it stops the pain. In the past it was also used to treat burns on the feet. The bush coconut (dardaga) is often found in this tree. It is an insect gall that has a hard brown or grey outer skin. The apple is broken open to expose the small grub (larvae) which can be eaten and is very sweet and tasty. The fruit are called 'jirdbiyirdbi) and they can be made into beads, by threading them onto fishing line or string. They can also be used as a spinning toy like a top, by spinning them between the fingers.
\cf nganyiwan
\pc jardburru.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\sn 2
\ge bloodwood
\de bloodwood
\sd M Plants
\re
\re Corymbia latifolia, Corymbia polycarpa
\sy
\va
\sc Corymbia latifolia
\sc Corymbia polycarpa
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The timber is good firewood. Boomerangs may be made from the hard wood. The bark is chipped off and boiled in water and the liquid is used as external wash to treat any skin problems. Sugarbag (native bee-hives) can be found in this tree. In northern areas 'jardburru' also includes Eucalyptus foelscheana.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 07/Sep/2018

\lx jadgala
\sf
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge cluster.fig
\de cluster fig
\sd M Plants
\re fig (cluster)
\re cluster fig
\re Ficus congesta
\sy nambula
\sy jalwarra
\va
\sc
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The fruit are eaten when they are red to brown in colour; they are tasty. Flying-foxes, fish and turtles also eat the fruit.
\cf
\pc nambula.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\sn 2
\ge cluster.fig
\de cluster fig
\sd M Plants
\re Ficus racemosa
\sy nambula
\va
\sc Ficus racemosa
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The fruit are eaten when they are ripe, red to brown. The fruit that fall into the river are eaten by fish and turtles. It is generally a good place to go fishing because the fish are already there waiting for food. The dried fruit can be collected from under the tree and then mixed with hot water and sugar and eaten. The wood can be used to make coolamons. In the past the logs were used as floats when crossing large rivers, sometimes children were sat on the logs to cross the rivers. Flying-foxes also eat the fruit. This tree is spiritually important for Ngarinyman people and is associated with the Dreaming story of the black-headed python (walujabi).
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 25/Aug/2015

\lx jag
\sf

\sn

\de drop, fall, lose
\sd U Holding and Taking

\re lose
\re fall
\sy

\sfx

\lx jaggij
\sf
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge bush-honey.grass
\de bush-honey grass
\sd M Plants
\re grass (bush-honey)
\re bush-honey grass
\re Alloteropsis semialata
\sy
\va
\sc Alloteropsis semialata
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The leaves and stems can be crushed into a ball and used as a pad to dip honey out of sugarbag. The honey can then be sucked off. The stem base can also be pulled out of the ground and it comes out nice and clean. This can be used as a dip to get honey out of sugarbag that is too hard to chop out of the tree. This grass grows early in the wet season and produces seed earlier than the other grasses. The seeds are eaten by finches.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\sn 2
\ge white.grass
\de white grass
\sd M Plants
\re grass (white)
\re white grass
\re Sehima nervosum
\sy
\va
\sc Sehima nervosum
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This grass is used as medicine to 'cook babies'. The grass is mixed with crushed antbed and water on a surface that has been heated by a fire. This causes steam to rise and the baby is moved through the steam and allowed to lay upon the grass so that it is heated by the steam. This cooking of the baby improves its health and allows it to grow up mentally and physically strong. This grass can also be used to dip honey out of sugarbags and it was also put in coolamons to stop water sloshing out and to keep it cool.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 06/Sep/2015

\sy

\sc Atalaya hemiglauca
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This tree is a good tree to sit under as it provides cool dense shade. Birds are attracted to the flowers to get nectar. The leaves can be used as fish poison. They are crushed and thrown into small waterholes; this causes the fish to float to the surface where they can be collected, cooked and eaten.

\dt 08/Sep/2015

\lx jalarlga
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge black.catfish
\de black catfish
\sd K Water Animals
\re catfish (black)
\re black catfish
\re Arius leptaspis
\sy
\va
\sc Arius leptaspis
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This is a catfish that is often quite dark in colour. The flesh and fat can be eaten after roasting in hot coals. The spines or prickles on the fins are dangerous. They contain poison and cause severe pain and swelling. The spines are broken off and burnt on the fire, thrown in the water or placed in a safe place. If the spine pokes into you, you must slap the area with the tail of the fish. This stops the pain and swelling.
\cf
\pc jalarlga.jpg

\ge centipede

\sd L Insects and Spiders
\re centipede
\re Chilopoda
\re Myriapoda
\sy lirrimi
\va
\sc Chilopoda
\sc Myriapoda
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a Yarralin word.
\ee They have a sting that causes pain and swelling, but it is not deadly and not too painful. There is a special song to stop the pain and reduce the swelling. There is a Dreaming site for 'Lirrimi' near the township of Timber Creek. Sometimes children play with them after they have pulled off the biting nippers at the front.

\dt 10/May/2016

\lx jalgaji
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge corkwood
\de corkwood
\sd M Plants
\re corkwood
\re Erythrina vespertilio
\sy gajuwa
\va
\sc Erythrina vespertilio
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The light wood is used to make coolamons and woomera shafts; it is light-weight wood but quite strong. The swollen tap root of young plants can be dug up, then cooked and eaten. The soot from the burnt bark can be rubbed onto the skin to make it look darker. In the past this was rubbed onto the skin of pale-skinned children. The bright red flowers indicate that freshwater crocodiles (warrija) are laying eggs and that they will be ready to collect and eat soon. The red seeds can be used to make necklaces. There are special sacred trees at Barrak Barrak, linked to the diver duck creation period story and song-line. These trees are often referred to by their Jaminjung name (julgirr) which also means woomera.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\sn 2
\ge
\de woomera
\sd D Things
\re
\sy
\va jalygaji
\ve
\sc
\so NH, ES, JT, NA:CS12
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf Jaminjung
\lv julgirr
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 23/Jul/2012

\lx jalyingarna
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge sugarleaf
\de sugar-leaf, sweet-leaf (lerps)
\sd L Insects and Spiders
\re sugarleaf
\re sweet-leaf
\re lerps
\re Hemiptera
\re Psyllidae
\sy nanjarrgadag
\sy garnbanga
\va
\sc Hemiptera
\sc Psyllidae
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee These small white scale-like insect-coverings are collected off the bloodwood (jardburra) and the river red gum tree (dimarlan) leaves during the cold weather time and eaten. They are very sweet and tasty. The branches and twigs are broken off and left to dry over a calico sheet. The lerps are then collected and shaped into small balls and eaten. These balls used to be stored in cake-tins for weeks and months. This food has special cultural significance for Ngarinyman people.
\cf
\pc Lerps.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 21/Sep/2015

\lx jaman.gula
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge frill-necked.lizard
\de frill-necked lizard, blanket lizard
\sd I Reptiles
\re lizard (frill-necked)
\re frill-necked lizard
\re lizard (blanket)
\re blanket lizard
\re Chlamydosaurus kingi
\sy ngarranginy
\sy gardan.ga
\sy garaga
\va
\sc Chlamydosaurus kingi
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a Yarralin word.
\ee The flesh can be eaten after roasting. The flesh and fat are tasty. The frill or blanket is burnt on ashes until it turns black and it is then rubbed with fat. This is in turn rubbed through the hair to make it go dark and healthy; it makes big hair. It can also be rubbed onto the head of a baby so they grow up with healthy hair. When the rains begin the blanket lizard runs around eating ants. They are cheeky and will chase you and try to bite you.
\cf
\pc frilled_neck_lizard.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 20/Sep/2015

\lx jamarlangmarlang
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge green.tree.snake
\de green tree snake, brown tree snake
\sd I Reptiles
\re tree snake (green)
\re tree snake (brown)
\re Dendrelaphis punctulata
\re Boiga irregularis
\sy warndawarndang
\sy ginirriny
\va
\sc Dendrelaphis punctulata
\sc Boiga irregularis
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a word from the northern and western areas.
\ee This is a harmless snake that lives in trees, especially pandanus and other trees near rivers and creeks. It cannot hurt you but can give you a fright when it appears close to you when you are fishing. It is considered to be a naughty snake as it does not follow cultural laws. It has a small brain, and it plays up a lot.

\lx jamba
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge leichhardt.tree
\de Leichhardt tree
\sd M Plants
\re Leichhardt tree
\re Nauclea orientalis
\sy nyimili, mulij
\va
\sc Nauclea orientalis
\so RB, NR:ESB, PMC+
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This is a good shade tree. You can eat the fruit when it goes brown. Fish and turtles eat the fruit too. You can use the wood to make woomera shafts, light shields, coolamons and canoes.
\cf
\pc jamba.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 20/Feb/2018

\lx jamud
\sf
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge Australian.bustard
\de Australian bustard, bush turkey
\sd J Birds
\re bustard (Australian)
\re turkey (bush)
\re bush turkey
\re Ardeotis australis
\sy jandura
\va
\sc Ardeotis australis
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee Bush turkeys are one of the best bush meats. They were hunted with boomerangs in the past. Now shotguns and rifles are used. You can boil or roast the meat in a ground oven. It tastes like chicken. They are common in areas with large grassy plains. They like to eat grasshoppers (janyima), and various bush fruits. 'Jamud' has special cultural significance for Ngarinyman people.
\cf
\pc bush_turkey.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\sn 2
\ge turkey
\de turkey
\sd J Birds
\re turkey
\re Ardeotis australis
\sy jandura
\sy gabalgabal
\va
\sc Ardeotis australis
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee Turkeys were kept for food on many stations and missions in the past. They are given the same names as the bush turkey and the Kriol name is based on the sound of their call.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 04/Sep/2018

\lx jamulang
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge boab
\de boab, bottle tree
\sd M Plants
\re boab
\re bottle tree
\re Adansonia gregorii
\sy
\va
\sc Adansonia gregorii
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The inner soft part of the fruit is called 'jangi' and it can be eaten; it is especially favoured by children. Sometimes it is mixed with sugar and water. The large kidney-shaped seeds can be roasted and then eaten. The fruit can be carved and sold as artifacts to tourists. The wood from large branches and trunks can be used to carve coolamons. The middle part of the large flowers, the staminal tube, can be used as a paint-brush, and is especially good for applying body paint. The swollen tap-root of young trees can be dug up, roasted in hot coals and ashes and then eaten. They are fairly large and quite tasty. As the yams get older they become more fibrous and are not as nice to eat. 'Jamulang' has an important creation period story that strongly relates it to the sand or plains goanna (girrawa) and the mythical Dreamtime goanna (malajagu). 'Jamulang' has the 'Jangala' skin.
\pc jamulang.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 17/Aug/2015

\ue
\ee This fish is very similar to the black bream, above, but has larger pointy lips and the skin and flesh are firmer. It is also very tasty and good to eat.

\lx jamurru
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge green.plum
\de green plum
\sd M Plants
\re plum (green)
\re green plum
\re Buchanania obovata
\sy ngaringari
\sy barrarraj
\va
\sc Buchanania obovata
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The fruit are eaten when they are ripe, green but soft to touch. They are produced at the beginning or early in the wet season and are very tasty. They are generally collected once they have fallen to the ground. In the past the fruit and seed were crushed and mixed into a paste that was good for small children and old people. 'Barrarraj' are the larger trees with large woody trunks, and these are considered to be the mother of 'ngaringari' and 'jamurru', the smaller trees with thinner trunks.
\cf
\pc barrarraj2.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf

\dt 06/Jul/2017

\lx Jangarla
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge Sesbania.formosa
\de spring corkwood
\sd M Plants
\re Sesbania formosa
\re spring corkwood
\sy
\va
\sc Sesbania formosa
\so NH,KJ:CJ:98, NH,KJ,JK:CJ:2005
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The bark and leaves can be boiled in water and the cooled liquid used as a wash to itchy skin, boils and bad colds. The outer bark is burnt to form a fine black soot. This can be rubbed through the hair to make it look it darker. In the past the soot was rubbed onto the skin of pale-skinned babies so that the welfare officers would not take them away. The wood can be used to make the shafts of woomeras. The large white flowers tell the freshwater crocodile (warrija) and turtles (guwarlambarla) to get up on the banks and lay their eggs. Consequently when you see these flowers you know that it is a good time to collect these eggs ready to eat. The flowers also indicate that the hot weather of the build-up is about to begin.
\cf
\pc jangarla.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 28/Aug/2015

\lx jangarna
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge brush-tailed.possum
\de brush-tailed possum
\sd H Mammals
\re possum (brush-tailed)
\re Trichosurus vulpecula
\sy jagulaji
\sy ngurrgudi
\va
\sc Trichosurus vulpecula
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The meat can be eaten after roasting in a ground oven with paperbark. It is very tasty. Jangarna lives in hollow trees and the tracks can be seen on the trunks of trees that they live in. They were more common in the past than they are now.
\cf
\pc Brushtail_possum.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 09/Sep/2015

\lx jangarra

\sd L Insects and Spiders

\dt 22/Feb/2018

\lx jangawa
\sf
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge river.pandanus
\de river pandanus
\sd M Plants
\re pandanus (river)
\re Pandanus aquaticus
\sy
\va
\sc Pandanus aquaticus
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The fruit are eaten by black bream (gambajawung) and turtles (guwarlambarla) when they break into small pieces and fall into the water. The roots and dried stems are put on the fire until they are hot. They are then formed into a bed with warm sand and water and a small baby is placed on it. This has the effect of making the baby strong and healthy.
\cf
\pc pandanus.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\sn 2
\ge spring.pandanus
\de spring pandanus
\sd M Plants
\re pandanus (spring)
\re Pandanus spiralis
\sy
\va
\sc Pandanus spiralis
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The seed can be chopped out of the woody fruit and eaten; it is tasty like a peanut. The leaves can be used to make baskets. The thorny edges are stripped off and the leaves are split down the middle, these pale strips are placed in the sun to dry prior to being dyed and used for fibre-crafts. Two types are recognised, one that grows along drainage lines and the other grows on sandy flats. The prop-roots from the type that grows along drainage lines are boiled in water and the liquid used as a wash to treat scabies. It is a powerful medicine and it can burn the skin if it is made too strong. The basal sections of the type that grows on sandy flats are chopped up and boiled in water and the liquid used as eye medicine. A few drops are put into tired or sore eyes and it relieves the pain.
\cf
\pc spring_pandanus.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 28/Aug/2015

\lx janggarni
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge big
\de big, large, adult, strong, a lot
\sd N Description
\re big
\re strong
\re many
\re large
\re adult
\sy barayi
\va
\ve
\sc
\so SK, RB:ESB, MW:CJ:94
\xv Malang-barnalu garrab garrinyang, janggarni bamarr.
\xe We were looking across the river, at a big rock.
\rf ER: ES08_A03_01.292-3
\xv Janggarni-warla-yi bagarli-rla.
\sfx
\xe (I can't book-down anymore because) I'm over the limit.
\rf NH:CJ:7/6/95
\xv Janggarni jaru birrga mana.
\sfx
\xe He's telling big stories, boasting (and not telling the truth).
\rf NH,KJ:CJ:98
\xv Janggarni-gijag gambarlan-barna.
\sfx
\xe I treat (the baby) with heat so he gets strong.
\rf ER, ES99_V01_01.042
\ue
\ee

\lf Gurindji

\lx jardugarl
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge plains.kangaroo
\de plains kangaroo, antilopine wallaroo
\sd H Mammals
\re kangaroo (plains)
\re plains kangaroo
\re Macropus antilopinus
\sy ngalijirri
\sy bunggiyin
\sy wawirri
\va
\sc Macropus antilopinus
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a word from the northern and western areas.
\ee This kangaroo generally lives on grassy plains, often on red soil country. It is tall and thin compared to the hill kangaroo. Plains kangaroos have special significance for Ngarinyman people. It is a Dreaming for some people. 'Jardugarl' is a term used for the male of this species in the northern and western areas.

\xv

\lx jarlardu
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge snake.vine
\de snake vine
\sd M Plants
\re vine (snake)
\re Tinospora smilacina
\sy
\va
\sc Tinospora smilacina
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This climbing plant often grows around the trunks of trees. The leaves and fruit are boiled in water and the water used as a wash to treat any boils, any sickness or general pain. The red fruit can be rubbed in the hair to make it healthy and dark. The stems can be used as bush rope to tie things up, like bundles of firewood. There is a special song about this plant and the rains of the wet season.

\xv

\lx jarnbiny
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge smoke.tree
\de smoke tree
\sd M Plants
\re smoke tree
\re Eucalyptus pruinosa
\sy yalyirra
\va
\sc Eucalyptus pruinosa
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee Stems and branches that have been hollowed by termites and are of the appropriate diameter can be made into didgeridoos. Sugarbag (native bee-hives) can be found in this tree. Timber from young plants can be used to make fighting sticks or nulla-nullas. The inner bark is chopped off the trunk and boiled in a little water. This liquid is drunk to treat colds, flu and fever and for general sickness. It also relieves pain of sore muscles and general soreness.
\cf
\pc jarnbij.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 25/Aug/2015

\ue
\ee 'Jarrabaly' means a 'tree fork' in Gurindji. Traditionally corpses were put on tree platforms.

\dt 10/Jun/2018

\lx jarrbungu
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge silver.catfish
\de silver catfish
\sd K Water Animals
\re catfish (silver)
\re silver catfish
\re Arius graeffei
\sy warrag
\va
\sc Arius graeffei
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a word from the northern and western areas.
\ee This is a catfish that has a shorter nose than other species. The flesh and fat can be eaten after roasting in hot coals. Sometimes when they are pulled up on the bank they make an oinking noise a bit like a pig. The spines or prickles on the fins are dangerous. They contain poison which causes severe pain and swelling. The spines are broken off and burnt on the fire, thrown in the water or placed in a safe place. If the spine pokes into you, you must slap the area with the tail of the fish; this stops the pain and swelling.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 09/Sep/2015

\sf

\lx jarri
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge wallaby.grass
\de wallaby grass
\sd M Plants
\re grass (wallaby)
\re wallaby grass
\re Chrysopogon fallax
\sy burndung
\va
\sc Chrysopogon fallax
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The stem base is eaten by kangaroos and wallabies. The sharp leaf edges can cut your feet when you walk through it, or your hands if you try to pull it out. The stem base and new shoots can also be used as medicine. The yellow root is dug up and cleaned off, then smashed up and boiled in water. The cooled liquid is drunk to treat bad colds.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 06/Sep/2015

\lx jarrinygal
\sf
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge red.flowered.kurrajong
\de red flowered kurrajong
\sd M Plants
\re kurrajong (red flowered)
\re red flowered kurrajong
\re Brachychiton megaphyllus
\sy ginyjirrga
\va
\sc Brachychiton megaphyllus
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This plant has the same Ngarinyman name as Brachychiton spectabilis, below, however it is a smaller tree that grows in a different habitat.
\cf
\pc ginyjirrga.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\sn 2
\ge red.flowered.kurrajong
\de red flowered kurrajong
\sd M Plants
\re kurrajong (red flowered)
\re red flowered kurrajong
\re Brachychiton spectabilis
\sy
\va
\sc Brachychiton spectabilis
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The seeds can be eaten and are excellent food. They taste like a peanut. The fruit are collected and the cheeky hairs removed by smashing up the seeds and hairs and then winnowing out the hairs on a coolamon. The hairs can also be burnt off the fruit by putting them in the fire for a little while. The seeds can be eaten straight up or they are ground up and mixed with a little water to form Johnny-cakes which are lightly cooked before eating. The swollen tap root of young plants can be dug up, roasted and then eaten. When the red streaky sunsets of the mid dry season can be seen it indicates that the fruit are ready to collect so the seeds can be eaten. This plant has special cultural significance for Ngarinyman people.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 17/Aug/2015

\lx jarrinymawu
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge bush.tobacco
\de bush tobacco
\sd M Plants
\re bush tobacco
\re tobacco (bush)
\re Lobelia arnhemica
\sy warlayarra
\sy lambalambarla
\sy marlmarlmaj
\va
\sc Lobelia arnhemica
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The dried plant can be chewed as bush tobacco; it is often mixed with commercial tobacco and some ash. In the past the old people chewed this before commercial tobacco was available. The plants are collected and dried in the sun for a period; they are then crushed before chewing. The Ngarinyman name 'jarrinymawu' means cave-dweller and refers to the fact that it grows in shaded areas under overhangs and generally near permanent water.
\cf
\pc walmawalmag.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 28/Aug/2015

\lx jarrwana
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge cheeky.yam
\de cheeky yam, round yam
\sd M Plants
\re yam (cheeky)
\re cheeky yam
\re yam (round)
\re round yam
\re Dioscorea bulbifera
\sy
\va
\sc Dioscorea bulbifera
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The round, hairy yam can be dug up and eaten after extensive preparation. The flesh is salty or cheeky unless it is properly prepared. The flesh is boiled in water with ashes, taken out and washed and cut into slices. These slices are soaked in running water overnight to leach out the poisons and it is then ready to eat. It is common around Timber Creek and when it is well cooked it tastes like commercial potato. This plant is considered to be related to Dioscorea transversa.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 07/Sep/2015

\dt 03/Jul/2017

\lx jawalyarri
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge river.red.gum
\de river red gum
\sd M Plants
\re gum (river red)
\re river red gum
\re Eucalyptus camaldulensis
\sy dimarlan
\sy marlarn
\va
\sc Eucalyptus camaldulensis
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a Yarralin word.
\ee The new leaves are called 'jawalyarri' and are boiled in water until the water becomes slightly milky. The liquid is used as a wash to treat bad colds, skin problems and coughs. A small amount may also be drunk to treat coughing. This liquid has a good smell like Vicks. The leaves may also be used by placing them on a fire to produce smoke. The patient is then rubbed with fat and wafted with the smoke. This heals the person by passing the smell of the tree to them. The leaves can be used as fish poison. Small branches and twigs are thrown onto small waterholes, or the branches are dragged through the water. The fish become drunk and float to the surface, where they can be easily collected. They are then cooked and eaten. The leaves can also be added to any meat being cooked in a ground oven. It keeps the meat moist and adds a good flavour to the meat. Sugarbag (native bee-hives) can be found in this tree. The wood is good firewood. Sugar-leaf (jalyingarna) or sweet edible lerps, are found on the leaves of this tree. Witchetty grubs (lamawud) can also be found in the lower trunk of this tree. There is a special song about this tree and its relationship with goannas (girrawa).
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 25/Aug/2015

\lx jawardirla
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge tomorrow
\de tomorrow
\sd V Space and Time
\re tomorrow
\sy

\sc
\so IAD-, SK:ESB:93, MW:CJ:94

\lx jawinbiny
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge water.rat
\de water rat
\sd H Mammals
\re rat (water)
\re Hydromys chrysogaster
\sy
\va
\sc Hydromys chrysogaster
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee In the past the the old people used to catch them and eat them. They live in creeks and rivers near permanent water and dig a burrow in the bank. They eat fish, mussels and crabs.
\cf
\pc Water_Rat.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 09/Sep/2015

\dt 06/11/2011

\lx jawinyin
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge saltwater.crocodile
\de saltwater crocodile, alligator
\sd I Reptiles
\re crocodile (saltwater)
\re saltwater crocodile
\re alligator
\re Crocodylus porosus
\sy lalamag
\va
\sc Crocodylus porosus
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee These large man-eating crocodiles are common in large rivers and billabongs; they are very dangerous and are carefully avoided. In the past they were hunted with big shovel-nosed spears. They were aimed at the kidneys between the front and back legs. When killed they were cut into pieces using a stone axe. Sometimes men would swim out into large rivers with a log to get close to the crocodile and then spear the crocodile with a short spear with a steel head. The eggs (gambij) were also collected from the large nests, but this was very dangerous as the mother would hide near the nest to guard it and chase away hunters. The large female would try to knock the person over with her tail.
\cf
\pc saltwater_croc.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 20/Sep/2015

\lx jawulwara
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge king.brown.snake
\de king brown snake
\sd I Reptiles
\re snake (king brown)
\re king brown snake
\re Pseudechis australis
\sy lingga
\va
\sc Pseudechis australis
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a Yarralin word.
\ee This is a very dangerous snake. You cannot get close to them as they are fast moving and aggressive; the poison is strong and deadly. There is a special song which will stop the poison from killing them. There is an important creation period story about this snake and a sacred site near the Timber Creek race course. If it is touched, thousands of king brown snakes will appear.
\cf
\pc king_brown_snake.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 20/Sep/2015

\dt 07/May/2016

\lx jawurrany
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge bowerbird
\de bowerbird, stealing bird
\sd J Birds
\re bowerbird
\re stealing bird
\re Chlamydera nuchalis
\sy juwayurru
\va
\sc Chlamydera nuchalis
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a Yarralin word.
\ee 'Jawurrany' will steal anything. They especially like silver things such as spoons, marbles, coins and rings, hence their nickname 'jawurrag-ngarna' (stealing-one). They like to make their bowers under conkerberry bushes (ngamanburru). There is a creation period story for 'jawurrany' and Dreaming places. They can mimick the call of other birds and other sounds that they hear.
\cf
\pc Bowerbird.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 08/Sep/2015

\lx jayinyburru
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge agile.wallaby
\de agile wallaby, river wallaby
\sd H Mammals
\re wallaby (agile)
\re agile wallaby
\re Notamacropus agilis
\sy walbawung
\sy magiliwarn
\va
\sc Notamacropus agilis
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a Yarralin word.
\ee These small kangaroos live in areas near rivers and creeks. They are common in some areas and there are a lot near the Victoria River. The flesh can be eaten after roasting and is very good to eat. 'Jayinyburru' is the Yarralin term for the male of this species.
\cf
\pc agile_wallaby2.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 09/Sep/2015

\lx jibibiny
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge kerosene.wood
\de kerosene wood
\sd M Plants
\re kerosene wood
\re Erythroxylum ellipticum
\sy jimbarin
\va
\sc Erythroxylum ellipticum
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The hard wood is used to make clap-sticks, nulla-nullas, coolamons and boomerangs. It is also very good firewood, especially in the wet season when it burns very well even if it is wet. The small bright red fruit are eaten by various birds. Sugarbag can be found in the older large trees. The clear gum can be warmed and placed on boils to draw out the infection.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 25/Aug/2015

\lx jibilyuman
\sf

\sn

\sd J Birds

\re Tachybaptus novae-hollandiae
\re Poliocephalus poliocephalus
\sy

\sc Poliocephalus poliocephalus
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a Yarralin word.
\ee These birds are like little ducks. They are gutted, the feathers singed off and then roasted on hot coals. In the old days 'jibilyuman' were hunted by throwing a rock or stick at them.

\rf

\ee This name refers to the animal's big nose. The flesh can be eaten after roasting. It is very good meat which tastes like porcupine. Pigs do a lot of damage near rivers and creeks where they dig up yams and eat them.
\cf
\pc pig.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 22/Sep/2015

\sf
\ps n
\sn

\de rainbow bee-eater
\sd J Birds
\re bee-eater (rainbow)
\re rainbow bee-eater
\re Merops ornatus
\sy jinbardbard
\sy durrudurrud
\va
\sc Merops ornatus
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a word from the northern and western areas.
\ee They often sit on high perches looking for insects to eat. They make a burrow in the banks of creeks or in termite mounds. The long tail feathers represent the woomeras that this bird always carries with it. There is an important creation period story about this bird and the woomera.

\lx jigamuru
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge waterlily
\de waterlily
\sd M Plants
\re waterlily
\re Nymphaea violacea
\sy
\va
\sc Nymphaea violacea
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The fruit (mindaarraj) are collected from the bottom of the water and the skin peeled off to expose the seeds which can be eaten. The seeds are very tasty and somewhat oily. The fruit may be roasted before the seeds are eaten or they may be eaten uncooked. The stem of the flower is called 'gulgurdugurdu'. It may also be eaten after the green outer skin has been peeled off. The tuber in the mud is called 'jalgi' and it may also be eaten after it has been roasted.
\cf mindaarraj

\dt 03/Jul/2017

\lx jilinbug
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge bush.tea-leaf
\de bush tea-leaf
\sd M Plants
\re bush tea-leaf
\re Ocimum tenuiflorum
\sy nalija
\sy wayildi
\va
\sc Ocimum tenuiflorum
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The leaves are boiled in water to make tea to drink. It has a strong smell and pleasant taste. The tea made from this plant also has medicinal qualities and is good to treat colds and congestion. In the past this plant was used a lot by old people as tea. There is a lot of it growing on Waterloo Station. The liquid can also be used as a wash to treat itchy sores and skin. The drink is also good for providing sustenance when walking a long way, especially if there is no food to be found. The tea can keep you going until food is found. It makes you strong when you are feeling weak. The word 'nalija' is also used to refer to commercial tea that is available from shops.
\cf
\pc juminjumin.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf

\xe
\rf

\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf

\ee They often sit on high perches looking for insects to eat. They make a burrow in the banks of creeks or in termite mounds. The long tail feathers represent the woomeras that this bird always carries with it. There is an important creation period story about this bird and the woomera.

\lx jirri
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge love.potion
\de white powder used to attract a person of the opposite sex, love potion
\sd C Language and Culture
\re love potion
\sy
\va jirriyi
\ve
\sc
\so ER:ESB; NH,JC:CJ,JM:2015
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee A type of white substance found at Victoria River crossing (Jurrjurrarralarni). It is used by women to attract men or to bring luck, e.g when playing cards. It can be rubbed on the chest with oil, sprinkled in the desired man's tea, or put under the fingernails for luck (e.g. playing cards).

\lx jiwug

\ge black.bream
\de black bream, sooty grunter
\sd K Water Animals
\re bream (black)
\re black bream
\re grunter (sooty)
\re sooty grunter
\re Hephaestus fuliginosus
\sy gambajawung
\va
\sc Hephaestus fuliginosus
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This is one of the most favoured fish to eat because the flesh is very tasty. They are quite common and are easy to catch on hand-lines in waterholes and creeks. The flesh is roasted on hot coals or cooked on the stove. Butler's grunter is very similar to the black bream and has the same names and uses.
\cf

\xv
\sfx

\xv

\xe

\se

\sy

\ve
\sc
\so LR:CM:07, NH:CJ:1/1/95, ER:ESB:99
\xv Ngawa-wu jiyalan nyila garu.
\sfx
\xe That kid is really thirsty.
\xv Ngawa-wu-rna jiyalan.
\sfx
\xe I'm really thirsty.
\rf NH:CJ:1/1/95, ER:ESB:99
\xv Warlayarra barlarr jiyalan-bayi.
\sfx
\xe The tobacco will dry out on me.
\rf ER: ES08_A06_01.009
\xv Yuga burduj jiyalan jawi-lu.
\sfx
\xe Fire is burning the grass.
\rf CS12_a144_01
\ue
\ee

\lx jiyil
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge paperbark
\de paperbark
\sd M Plants
\re paperbark
\re Melaleuca viridiflora
\sy
\va
\sc Melaleuca viridiflora
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a word from the northern and western areas.
\ee The timber is durable and can be used as fence posts, railings and for building shelters. Sugarbag, native bee-hives, are often found in this tree. The bark can be used to wrap food when cooking in ground ovens. The leaves are thick and dark green. They have a strong smell when crushed and can be inhaled to treat congestion and headaches.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 26/Aug/2015

\dt 12/Sep/2008

\lx juguru
\sf
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge bush.orange
\de bush orange
\sd M Plants
\re bush orange
\re orange (bush)
\re Capparis umbonata
\sy gurlinyaga
\sy yumarli
\va
\sc Capparis umbonata
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The fruit are eaten when they are ripe, a slightly orange-yellow colour. The fruit are sweet and very tasty. The unripe fruit can be buried in the sand to help ripen them; sometimes this might take as long as two weeks. The wood can be used as firewood as it lights quickly and easily. When the fruit are ripe they have a strong pleasant smell, which can be noticed from a long way from the plant. It is difficult to stop eating the fruit when you can smell the sweet scent from them. The bark can be boiled in water and used as a washing medicine to treat scabies. When the large flooding rains of the full wet season are coming this plant can be used to chase the rains away. The leaves are placed on a fire to make smoke, and this is waved towards the rain clouds to make them go away.
\cf
\pc gurlardardi.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\sn 2
\ge freshwater.longtom
\de freshwater longtom
\sd K Water Animals
\re freshwater longtom
\re Strongylura krefftii
\sy jurrgunduj
\va
\sc Strongylura krefftii
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a word from the northern and western areas. The word 'jurrgunduj' is used at Yarralin.
\ee The flesh from larger fish can be roasted and eaten; it is tasty but has a lot of bones. The smaller fish are used as bait to catch larger fish. This fish is a Dreaming for some people.
\cf
\pc longtom.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 09/Sep/2015

\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge chicken
\de chicken
\sd J Birds
\re chicken
\re Gallus gallus
\sy guluju
\sy bawurl
\va
\sc Gallus gallus
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee Bawurl and Jugjug are Kriol names for Guluju. Many people used to have chickens for the tasty meat and eggs.
\cf
\pc chicken.jpg

\ge freshwater.longtom
\de freshwater longtom
\sd K Water Animals
\re longtom (freshwater)
\re Strongylura krefftii
\sy jurrgunduj
\va
\sc
\so SK:ESB
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The flesh from larger fish can be roasted and eaten; it is tasty but has a lot of bones. The smaller fish are used as bait to catch larger fish. This fish is a Dreaming for some people.
\cf
\pc longtom.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 22/Feb/2018

\lx jungguwurru
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge porcupine
\de porcupine, echidna
\sd H Mammals
\re porcupine
\re echidna
\re Tachyglossus aculeatus
\sy bagabaga
\sy bagayawung
\sy nyinyiwurdu
\sy
\va
\sc Tachyglossus aculeatus
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee They often live in rocky country and are most active at night when they walk around looking for food. They are most active during full moon periods in the cold weather of the dry season. When they walk they leave a little track where the prickles drag along the ground. When approached they roll into a tight ball to protect themselves. They are often found in crevices in rocks and can be pulled out with a hooked branch or piece of wire. The prickles and feet are chopped off with a tomahawk prior to cooking the whole body in a ground oven. The meat is sweet and tastes like pork. There is a powerful creation period story about 'jungguwurru' that relates to how he got his prickles. It is a Dreaming animal for some people.
\cf
\pc echidna.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 09/Sep/2015

\lx junjunung
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge striated.pardalote
\de striated pardalote
\sd J Birds
\re pardalote (striated)
\re Pardalotus striatus
\sy gunjununug
\va
\sc Pardalotus striatus
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a Yarralin word.
\ee This small bird digs a burrow in banks of creeks and road edges where it lays its eggs. The small ones can be used as bait when fishing with a handline.
\cf
\pc Striated_pardalote.jpg
\se
\de
\xv

\lx jurlumirri
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge sand.goanna
\de sand goanna, plains goanna
\sd I Reptiles
\re goanna (sand)
\re sand goanna
\re goanna (plains)
\re plains goanna
\re Varanus panoptes
\sy girrawa
\sy warlgan
\sy dilyarri
\va
\sc Varanus panoptes
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This is the biggest goanna. It can get very large and has a lot of tasty flesh. The language name can also be used to refer to goannas in general, however, they are used for this goanna as it is the largest and best known. 'Girrawa' is the male and 'jurlumirri' is the female of this species.
\cf
\pc sand_goanna.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf

\lx jurrulana
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge white.currant
\de white currant, white plum
\sd M Plants
\re currant (white)
\re white currant
\re Flueggea virosa
\sy gumbulyu
\va
\sc Flueggea virosa
\so DB, DR, CP, JM, JoJ, JJ, ERa, IP, EH: GW, CS: 2007
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The white fruit are eaten when they are ripe; they are very sweet and tasty. The fruit are produced in the middle of the wet season. Some people don't like the taste of this fruit. The straight dry stems are used to make fire-sticks or bush matches, to light a fire using the traditional drilling or friction method. The bark and the skin of the roots can be scraped off and soaked in water. The liquid is drunk to treat swelling and to increase urine output. It is especially good for people who have walked a long way and who have tired and swollen legs. The straight dry stems are used to make fire-sticks or bush matches to light a fire using the traditional drilling or friction method. These fire-sticks were carried everywhere and could be used many times. In the wet season they were wrapped in paperbark to keep them dry. The bark and the skin of the roots can be scraped off and soaked in water. The liquid is drunk to treat swelling and to increase urine output. It is especially good for people who have walked a long way and who have tired and swollen legs.
\cf
\pc gumbulyu.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 22/Feb/2018

\lx juwag
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge common.koel
\de common koel, stormbird
\sd J Birds
\re koel (common)
\re Eudynamis scolopacea
\sy
\va duwag
\sc Eudynamis scolopacea
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue The Yarralin form of this word is 'duwag'.
\ee This bird occurs in thick bush near rivers and creeks. When it calls it indicates that the first storms of the wet season will start soon and that black plums (muying) will soon be ripe and ready to eat.
\cf
\pc common_koel.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf

\lx juwayurru
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge bowerbird
\de bowerbird, stealing bird
\sd J Birds
\re bowerbird
\re stealing bird
\re Chlamydera nuchalis
\sy jawurrany
\va
\sc Chlamydera nuchalis
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee 'Juwayurru' will steal anything. They especially like silver things such as spoons, marbles, coins and rings, hence their nickname 'jawurrag-ngarna' (stealing-one). They like to make their bowers under conkerberry bushes (ngamanburru). There is a creation period story for 'juwayurru' and Dreaming places. They can mimick the call of other birds and other sounds that they hear.
\cf
\pc Bowerbird.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 08/Sep/2015

\dt 15/Jul/2003

\lx lab
\sf
\ps cv
\sn
\ge pick.up
\de pick up, collect, take
\sd U Holding and Taking
\re pick up
\sy
\va
\ve
\sc
\so RB: ESB, NH:CJ:1/1/95
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf Jaminjung
\lv durd, lab
\lf Bilinarra
\lv lab
\lf Jaminjung
\lv lab
\pc
\se lab manan
\de pick up, take (take someone, or take a plane), collect
\xv Garndi-n lab mani?
\sfx
\xe Did you pick up a stick
\rf NH:CJ:21/06/1995
\xv Nyamba-n lab mani, garu?
\sfx
\xe What did you pick up, kid?
\rf NH:CJ:21/06/1995
\xv Lab-barna mana murlugun ngawa-yawung.
\sfx
\xe I'm picking up the bottle with water in it.
\rf JC:JM1-007 2016 book 1, p64
\xv Ngugu-rla lab mani.
\sfx
\xe He got some water for him.
\rf NH:CJ:95
\xv Ngawa lab mani gardag-jawung.
\sfx
\xe He got some water with a cup.
\rf NH, KJ:JM1-008 2016 book 1, p82
\xv Lab-bangali manani Nangala-rlu.
\sfx
\xe Nangala picked up us two.
\rf
\xv Yandarla-rni lab-bangayirra manda-rla.
\sfx
\xe Let her come pick us up.
\rf NH:CJ:95
\xv Garndi-walija lab-barna mani.
\sfx
\xe I picked up lots of sticks.
\rf JT:JM1-009 2016 book 1, p83.

\ue This is a Yarralin word.

\lx ladaj
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge rough-tailed.goanna
\de rough-tailed goanna
\sd I Reptiles
\re goanna (rough-tailed)
\re rough-tailed goanna
\re Varanus acanthurus
\sy
\va
\sc Varanus acanthurus
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This small goanna has a rough tail like a rasp. It lives in rocky country. The meat is good to eat.
\cf
\pc Varanus_acanthurus.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 21/Sep/2015

\lx laging
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge freshwater.crocodile
\de hatchling freshwater crocodile
\sd I Reptiles
\re crocodile (hatchling)
\re Crocodylus johnstoni
\sy darrmard
\sy warrija
\va
\sc Crocodylus johnstoni
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a Wurlayi word.
\ee The meat can be eaten after roasting on hot coals or cooking in a ground oven like a goanna. They are often caught on hand-lines when fishing, and they can be hit over the head with a crowbar to kill them. In the past the men used to hunt them with spears, and they were eaten more commonly than they are now. The eggs are also eaten after boiling; they are good to eat. The tracks of the mother are followed to the nest and the sand dug out and the eggs collected. 'Laging' is a small freshwater crocodile and 'darrmard' is a large one.
\cf
\pc freshwater_croc.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 07/Sep/2018

\lx lajabali
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge wedge-tailed.eagle
\de wedge-tailed eagle
\sd J Birds
\re eagle (wedge-tailed)
\re wedge-tailed eagle
\re Aquila audax
\sy jardarra
\sy garawa
\sy warlawurru
\va
\sc Aquila audax
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a Yarralin word.
\ee This large eagle is an excellent hunter; it can catch small wallabies and kangaroos. It takes them high in the air and drops them to kill them. It is often seen by the side of the road eating road-kill.

\dt 22/Feb/2018

\lx lalamag
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge saltwater.crocodile
\de saltwater crocodile, alligator
\sd I Reptiles
\re crocodile (saltwater)
\re saltwater crocodile
\re alligator
\re Crocodylus porosus
\sy jawinyin
\va
\sc Crocodylus porosus
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee These large man-eating crocodiles are common in large rivers and billabongs; they are very dangerous and are carefully avoided. In the past they were hunted with big shovel-nosed spears. They were aimed at the kidneys between the front and back legs. When killed they were cut into pieces using a stone axe. Sometimes men would swim out into large rivers with a log to get close to the crocodile and then spear the crocodile with a short spear with a steel head. The eggs (gambij) were also collected from the large nests, but this was very dangerous as the mother would hide near the nest to guard it and chase away hunters. The large female would try to knock the person over with her tail.
\cf
\pc saltwater_croc.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 20/Sep/2015

\dt 09/Dec/2011

\lx lamawud
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge witchetty.grub
\de witchetty grub
\sd L Insects and Spiders
\re witchetty grub
\re Lepidoptera
\sy
\va
\sc Lepidoptera
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee These white grubs are the larval stage of many taxa and live in tree trunks; they can be eaten raw or lightly cooked in ashes. They are tasty and much sought after. The entrance hole is looked for in the trunk and branches, and then the wood is chopped open and the grub pulled out with a piece of thin hooked wire. They can also be used as bait when fishing. They mainly occur in wattle (birrbuny), bloodwoods (narrga) and river red gum trees (dimarlan). There are lots around Barragbarrag.
\cf
\pc Witchetty_grub.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 21/Sep/2015

\lx lambalambarla
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge bush.tobacco
\de bush tobacco
\sd M Plants
\re bush tobacco
\re tobacco (bush)
\re Lobelia arnhemica
\sy jarrinymawu
\sy warlayarra
\sy marlmarlmaj
\va
\sc Lobelia arnhemica
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a Yarralin word.
\ee The dried plant can be chewed as bush tobacco; it is often mixed with commercial tobacco and some ash. In the past the old people chewed this before commercial tobacco was available. The plants are collected and dried in the sun for a period; they are then crushed before chewing. The Ngarinyman name 'jarrinymawu' means cave-dweller and refers to the fact that it grows in shaded areas under overhangs and generally near permanent water.
\cf
\pc walmawalmag.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 01/Sep/2015

\lx langajuwal
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge donkey
\de donkey
\sd H Mammals
\re donkey
\re Equus asinus
\sy man.girrgirrbarayi
\sy man.girrgirrngamanyan
\sy ngangginganggi
\va
\sc Equus asinus
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The Ngarinyman word refers to their distinctive long ears. In the past they were used to carry heavy loads and pull carts. They are stronger and longer working than horses.

\va
\sc Hymenoptera, Vespidae, Polistes spp.

\xe

\ee These large black and yellow wasps make a nest from mud collected from the edge of puddles, creeks and waterholes. They are cheeky and can sting you. They sing when they find sugarbag.

\lx lawa
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge lemonwood
\de lemonwood
\sd M Plants
\re lemonwood
\re Dolichandrone heterophylla
\sy
\va
\sc Dolichandrone heterophylla
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The leaves and bark are boiled in water and the liquid used as a medicinal wash to treat itchy skin, sores and general pain. It is good medicine for small children. If you wash with it everyday for three days it will heal skin sores. The hard wood is used make nulla-nullas. The white flowers indicate that sharks are getting fat and it is a good time to hunt them.
\cf
\pc lawa.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 20/Aug/2015

\lx lawarra
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge riflefish
\de riflefish, archerfish
\sd K Water Animals
\re riflefish
\re archerfish
\re Toxotes chatareus
\sy
\va luwarra
\sc Toxotes chatareus
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue The Yarralin word is 'luwarra'.
\ee This fish is mainly used as bait to catch other fish, although children like to catch them, cook them on hot coals and then eat the flesh. 'Lawarra' has distinctive spots on its side and it spits water at insects to knock them into the water, so that it can eat them.

\xv

\lx lingga
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge king.brown.snake
\de king brown snake
\sd I Reptiles
\re snake (king brown)
\re king brown snake
\re Pseudechis australis
\sy jawulwarra
\va
\sc Pseudechis australis
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a word from the northern and western areas.
\ee This is a very dangerous snake. You cannot get close to them as they are fast moving and aggressive; the poison is strong and deadly. There is a special song which will stop the poison from killing them. There is an important creation period story about this snake and a sacred site near the Timber Creek race course. If it is touched, thousands of king brown snakes will appear.
\cf
\pc king_brown_snake.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf

\lx lirrimi
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge centipede
\de centipede
\sd L Insects and Spiders
\re centipede
\re Chilopoda, Myriapoda
\sy jalarriny
\va
\sc Chilopoda, Myriapoda
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee They have a sting that causes pain and swelling, but it is not deadly and not too painful. There is a special song to stop the pain and reduce the swelling. There is a Dreaming site for 'Lirrimi' near the township of Timber Creek. Sometimes children play with them after they have pulled off the biting nippers at the front.
\cf
\pc Centipede.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf

\lx lumbang
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge yellow.jacket
\de yellow jacket
\sd M Plants
\re yellow jacket
\re Terminalia canescens
\sy
\va
\sc Terminalia canescens
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This tree grows on stony slopes and has grey coloured leaves. The wood is used for nulla-nullas. The gum can be eaten; it is quite tasty and lasts for a long time. The gum can also be used to treat leather to make it go red and last longer.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 28/Aug/2015

\lx lumbu
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge fish-poison tree
\de fish-poison.tree
\sd M Plants
\re fish-poison tree
\re Tephrosia procera
\sy
\va
\sc Tephrosia procera
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This small tree or shrub grows in the Timber Creek and Yarralin areas on sandstone country. The leaves and twigs can be used as fish poison. The leaves are thrown into small waterholes and after a period the fish float to the surface and can be easily collected. They are then cooked and eaten. This works really well for black bream.
\cf
\lf Gurindji
\lv lumpung
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 28/Aug/2015

\lx lunggura
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge northern.blue-tongue.lizard
\de northern blue-tongue lizard
\sd I Reptiles
\re
\re Tiliqua scincoides
\sy
\va
\sc Tiliqua scincoides
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The flesh can be eaten after roasting in a ground oven in the same way as a goanna; it is very tasty and has tasty fat similar to that of a goanna. They are easy to catch as they cannot run quickly and can be picked up by grabbing them firmly around the neck. They can be caught all year round.
\cf
\pc blue_tongue_lizard.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf

\lx lunyja
\sf
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge salmon.gum
\de salmon gum
\sd M Plants
\re gum (salmon)
\re salmon gum
\re Eucalyptus bigalerita
\sy dugbarugba
\va
\sc Eucalyptus bigalerita
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This tree has orange coloured smooth bark. The wood is not good firewood as it does not burn well and makes a lot of smoke.
\cf
\pc lunyja.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\sn 2
\ge salmon.gum
\de salmon gum
\sd M Plants
\re gum (salmon)
\re salmon gum
\re Eucalyptus tintinnans
\sy dugbarugba
\va
\sc Eucalyptus tintinnans
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The timber is good firewood. Boomerangs may be made from the hard wood. The bark is chipped off and boiled in water and the liquid is used as external wash to treat any skin problems. Sugarbag (native bee-hives) can be found in this tree.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx

\lx madawug
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge bush.cucumber
\de bush cucumber
\sd M Plants
\re bush cucumber
\re cucumber (bush)
\re Cucumis melo
\sy garil
\sy gidbany
\va
\sc Cucumis melo
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The fruit may be eaten when they are ripe, light green. The fruit must be rubbed before eating to remove any short hairs that may be on the outside. If these are not removed the lips and tongue can become sore and painful. The fruit have a sweet taste and crispy texture when ripe. When fully ripe they have a strong sweet fruity smell. Sometimes they are found in large numbers.
\cf
\pc gaaril.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf

\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue Northern and western areas.
\ee These small kangaroos live in areas near rivers and creeks. They are common in some areas and there are a lot near the Victoria River. The flesh can be eaten after roasting and is very good to eat.
\cf
\pc agile_wallaby2.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 09/Sep/2015

\dt 08/Dec/2011

\lx maguriny
\sf
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge bush.grape
\de bush grape
\sd M Plants
\re grape (bush)
\re bush grape
\sy
\va
\sc Ampelocissus frutescens
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The fruit can be eaten when they turn black. However, if they are not properly ripe they can leave a strong aftertaste in the mouth.
\cf
\pc garranggil.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\sn 2
\ge bush.grape
\de bush grape
\sd M Plants
\re Ampelocissus acetosa
\sy
\va
\sc Ampelocissus acetosa
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The fruit can be eaten when they turn black; however, if they are not properly ripe they can leave a strong aftertaste in the mouth. Some people do not like to eat the fruit because it leaves a funny taste in the mouth. Blue-tongue lizards (lunggura) also like to eat the fruit. The tuber can be eaten after it has been cooked in coals or boiled in water; it is very fibrous and has not been eaten much in recent times.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 17/Aug/2015

\lx mali
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge mother.in.law
\de man's mother-in-law (and her brothers), woman's son-in-law.
\sd B People
\re mother-in-law (man's)
\re son-in-law (woman's)
\sy
\va
\ve
\sc
\so NH:CJ:2/1/95; JH:CJ:4/1/95, ER, LD:ESB:93; NH,KJ:CJ:98
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee In Kriol, this is called poison cousin. This is an avoidance relationship. You cannot talk to a person you call 'mali', or look at them (though you can talk to them through someone else). You can't sit next to them. You have to keep your distance. If you're a woman, you can eat the same food but your daughter has to give it to the 'mali'.
\cf
\lf Bilinarra
\lv mali
\lf Gurindji
\lv mali
\pc son_in_law-mali.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf

\lx manbilyi
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge dragonfly
\de dragonfly
\sd I Reptiles
\re dragonfly
\re Odonata
\sy bulmirimiri
\va
\sc Odonata
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a Timber Creek word.
\ee These insects are similar to helicopters or old biplanes. There is a special Dreaming site near Kildurk and if it is damaged everyone will get skin sores. Sometimes children use them for bait for fishing, but this can cause a headache or sickness.

\xv
\sfx

\lx manggalng
\sf
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge ti-tree
\de ti-tree
\sd M Plants
\re Melaleuca bracteata
\sy gulun
\va
\sc Melaleuca bracteata
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This is a small tree that has small leaves. It occurs in bush country and the bark is not used as it is not available in large enough pieces. Trees often contain sugarbag and when they are in flower the sugarbag is full of honey.
\cf
\pc gurlun.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\sn 2
\ge ti-tree
\de ti-tree
\sd M Plants
\re ti-tree
\re Melaleuca minutifolia
\sy gulun
\va
\sc Melaleuca minutifolia
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The papery bark can be used to light fires and to make small coolamons. This small tree is a favoured host of native bee-hives.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
