\dt 11/Oct/2016

\lx mangurlu
\sf
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge pigweed
\de pigweed, purslane
\sd M Plants
\re pigweed
\re Portulaca oleracea
\sy
\va
\sc Portulaca oleracea
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The small black seeds look like sand, and in the past the seeds were made into small dampers. This small plant grows along the ground. It has yellow flowers, reddish stems and fleshy green leaves. The whole plant can be placed onto a coolamon and the seeds are winnowed out and collected. When enough are available they are ground up using a grinding stone. The flour is then mixed with water and made into small dampers. These are lightly cooked then eaten. The dampers are very good food and in the past it was an important food source, however making the food was hard work. The fleshy leaves were eaten as a green vegetable by the members of the Gregory Expedition in the 1850s and proved a very valuable sourcee of food.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\sn 2
\ge type.of.plant
\de type of plant
\sd M Plants
\re Fimbristylis oxystachya
\sy
\va
\sc Fimbristylis oxystachya
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\so (Rose 1992)
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This small grass-like plant has edible seeds.  In the past it was an important food resource but has now become rare. The seeds can be winnowed out and collected. When enough are collected they are ground up using a grinding stone. The flour is then mixed with water and made into small dampers. These are lightly cooked then eaten. The dampers are very good food and in the past it was an important food source, however making the food was hard work. There is a Dreaming site near Lingara for this plant.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 19/Mar/2018

\dt 03/Jul/2017

\lx manyanyi
\sf
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge type.of.herb
\de type of herb
\sd M Plants
\re Blumea axillaris
\sy
\va
\sc Blumea axillaris
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This small plant has a strong pleasant smell and is good medicine. The plant is boiled in water and the liquid used as a wash for congestion, itchy skin, sores, or general pain. It is a very effective healing medicine. It is used for keeping insects away from the camp at night. One species is found in sandground, one in river country. There is a special women's song for this plant but it cannot be sung when men are present.
\cf
\pc manyanyi.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\sn 2
\ge type.of.herb
\de type of herb
\sd M Plants
\re Pterocaulon globuliflorus
\re Pterocaulon verbascifolium
\sy jumunyjumuny
\sy ngurnungurnungu
\va
\sc Pterocaulon globuliflorus
\sc Pterocaulon verbascifolium
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The leaves and foliage are boiled in water and the cooled liquid used as a wash to treat colds, skin sores, scabies and itchy skin. This plant has a strong pleasant odour.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\sn 3
\ge type.of.herb
\de type of herb
\sd M Plants
\re Stemodia lythrifolia
\re Stemodia viscosa
\sy
\va
\sc Stemodia lythrifolia
\sc Stemodia viscosa
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This small plant has a pleasant smell and is good medicine. The plant is boiled in water and the liquid used as a wash for congestion, itchy skin or general pain.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\sn 4
\ge type.of.herb
\de type of herb
\sd M Plants
\re Streptoglossa bubakii
\sy
\va
\sc Streptoglossa bubakii
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This small plant has a strong pleasant smell and is very good medicine. The plant is boiled in water and the liquid used as a wash for bad colds, itchy skin or general pain. It is a very effective healing medicine.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\sn 5
\ge type.of.herb
\de type of herb
\sd M Plants
\re Streptoglossa odora
\sy
\va
\sc Streptoglossa odora
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This small plant has a very strong smell and the leaves are often sticky. It is considered to be the most potent medicine. The plant is boiled in water and the liquid used as a wash for bad colds, itchy skin or general pain. It is a very effective healing medicine. This species is often referred to as 'bush manyanyi' and is quite different from the other plants called 'manyanyi'.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 19/Mar/2018

\dt 12/Sep/2008

\lx manyin
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge
\de barramundi
\sd K Water Animals
\re barramundi
\re Lates calcarifer
\sy manyirrgila
\sy yinarrwa
\sy marna
\va
\sc Lates calcarifer
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a word from the northern and western areas.
\ee The flesh can be eaten after roasting on hot coals. It is very tasty. Barramundi can get large and are hard to catch as they fight hard to get off the line. They are common in billabongs and the big rivers. They are mostly caught using live bait on hand-lines, although visiting fishermen often catch them with lures and rods. There is an important creation period story about the barramundi, the shark and the stingray. Barramundi are totems or Dreaming animals for some people. 'Yinarrwa' and 'manyirrgila' refer to large-sized fish; 'manyin' and 'marna' refer to small fish.
\cf
\pc barramundi.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 09/Sep/2015

\lx manyingila
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge gutta-percha
\de gutta-percha
\sd M Plants
\re gutta-percha
\re Excoecaria parviflora
\sy
\va
\sc
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This tree has small leaves and has white sap; it grows on plains and creeklines. The leaves are boiled in water and the liquid used as a wash to treat colds, sores on the scalp and nits. When the wood is burnt on a fire the smoke keeps away mosquitoes (gurrang). It has a nice smell when burnt. The timber is good for making boomerangs and clap-sticks. The white milk-like sap should not be allowed to get near your eye as it can cause blindness. Sugarbag (native bee-hives) can be found in this tree. This tree is often called milk-tree or milk-wood because of the white sap.
\cf
\pc manyingila.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 25/Aug/2015

\lx manyirrgila
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge
\de barramundi
\sd K Water Animals
\re barramundi
\re Lates calcarifer
\sy yinarrwa
\sy manyin
\sy marna
\va
\sc Lates calcarifer
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a Yarralin word.
\ee Barramundi can get large and are hard to catch as they fight hard to get off the line. They are common in billabongs and the big rivers. They are mostly caught using live bait on hand-lines, although visiting fishermen often catch them with lures and rods. There is an important creation period story about the barramundi, the shark and the stingray. Barramundi are totems or Dreaming animals for some people. 'Yinarrwa' and 'manyirrgila' refer to large-sized fish; 'manyin' and 'marna' refer to small fish.
\cf
\pc barramundi.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 09/Sep/2015

\lx maranyji
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge buffalo
\de buffalo
\sd H Mammals
\re buffalo
\re Bubalus bubalis
\sy mun.gurru
\sy windurru
\sy windurruyawung
\sy gardbibarndal
\sy wumburrurru
\va
\sc Bubalus bubalis
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a word from the northern and western areas.
\ee There are occasionally wild buffalo still seen but most were killed during the BTEC scheme in the 1980s and 1990s. The meat is good to eat, especially from young ones. It has a strong taste. Buffalo are cranky and dangerous in the bush.
\cf
\pc Buffalo.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx

\dt 07/Sep/2018

\lx marawun
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge spider
\de spider
\sd L Insects and Spiders
\re spider
\re Arachnida, Araneae
\sy darru
\sy garra
\sy garrada
\sy jamabngarrawu
\va
\sc Arachnida, Araneae
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a Yarralin word.
\ee All spiders have the same name although many different types of spider are recognised and some are dangerous. The red-back spider has a painful bite that causes a lot of swelling. The spider web is called 'jambangarrawu' or 'garrada'.
\cf
\pc spider.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf

\lx marda
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge termite.mound
\de termite mound
\sd L Insects and Spiders
\re termite mound
\re antbed
\re Isoptera
\sy mardumardu
\sy damarra
\va
\sc Isoptera
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The fine soil from inside termite mounds (also known as 'ant hills') can be eaten to treat diarrhoea. It dries up 'runny-tummy'. It is also used when smoking babies to make them strong. The ant hill is placed over a fire with water sprinkled on top, and the baby is held in the smoke and steam. This makes the baby spiritually and physically strong in later life.
\cf
\pc Antbed.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 22/Sep/2015

\lx mardumardu
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge termite.mound
\de termite mound, antbed
\sd L Insects and Spiders
\re termite mound
\re antbed
\re Isoptera
\sy marda
\sy damarra
\va
\sc Isoptera
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The fine soil from inside termite mounds (also known as 'ant hills') can be drunk mixed with water to treat diarrhoea. It dries up 'runny-tummy'. It is also used when smoking babies to make them strong. The ant hill is placed over a fire with water sprinkled on top, and the baby is held in the smoke and steam. This makes the baby spiritually and physically strong in later life.
\cf
\pc antbed.jpg

\lx marlamayawung
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge hand-yam
\de hand-yam
\sd M Plants
\re hand-yam
\re Chlorophytum laxum
\sy
\va
\sc Chlorophytum laxum
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The name comes from the Ngarinyman word finger (marlamirriny). The yams look like fingers on a hand. They are easy to dig up and the yams hang down like fingers. This small plant often grows near rivers. The stems and leaves grow in the wet season. It only occurs in northern areas.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 07/Sep/2015

\lx marlamirriny
\sf
\ps n
\sn

\dt 13/Oct/2016

\lx marlan
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge river.red.gum
\de river red gum
\sd M Plants
\re river red gum
\re Eucalyptus camaldulensis
\sy dimarlan
\sy jawalyarri
\va
\sc Eucalyptus camaldulensis
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The new leaves are called 'jawalyarri' and are boiled in water until the water becomes slightly milky. The liquid is used as a wash to treat bad colds, skin problems and coughs. A small amount may also be drunk to treat coughing. This liquid has a good smell like Vicks. The leaves may also be used by placing them on a fire to produce smoke. The patient is then rubbed with fat and wafted with the smoke. This heals the person by passing the smell of the tree to them. The leaves can be used as fish poison. Small branches and twigs are thrown onto small waterholes, or the branches are dragged through the water. The fish become drunk and float to the surface, where they can be easily collected. They are then cooked and eaten. The leaves can also be added to any meat being cooked in a ground oven. It keeps the meat moist and adds a good flavour to the meat. Sugarbag (native bee-hives) can be found in this tree. The wood is good firewood. Sugar-leaf (jalyingarna) or sweet edible lerps, are found on the leaves of this tree. Witchetty grubs (lamawud) can also be found in the lower trunk of this tree. There is a special song about this tree and its relationship with goannas (girrawa).
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 25/Aug/2015

\lx dimarlan
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge river.red.gum
\de river red gum
\sd M Plants
\re gum (river red)
\re river red gum
\re Eucalyptus camaldulensis
\sy marlan
\sy jawalyarri
\va
\sc Eucalyptus camaldulensis
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The new leaves are called 'jawalyarri' and are boiled in water until the water becomes slightly milky. The liquid is used as a wash to treat bad colds, skin problems and coughs. A small amount may also be drunk to treat coughing. This liquid has a good smell like Vicks. The leaves may also be used by placing them on a fire to produce smoke. The patient is then rubbed with fat and wafted with the smoke. This heals the person by passing the smell of the tree to them. The leaves can be used as fish poison. Small branches and twigs are thrown onto small waterholes, or the branches are dragged through the water. The fish become drunk and float to the surface, where they can be easily collected. They are then cooked and eaten. The leaves can also be added to any meat being cooked in a ground oven. It keeps the meat moist and adds a good flavour to the meat. Sugarbag (native bee-hives) can be found in this tree. The wood is good firewood. Sugar-leaf (jalyingarna) or sweet edible lerps, are found on the leaves of this tree. Witchetty grubs (lamawud) can also be found in the lower trunk of this tree. There is a special song about this tree and its relationship with goannas (girrawa).

\dt 21/Sep/2015

\lx marlmarlmaj
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge bush.tobacco
\de bush tobacco
\sd M Plants
\re bush tobacco
\re tobacco (bush)
\re Lobelia arnhemica
\sy jarrinymawu
\sy warlayarra
\sy lambalambarla
\va
\sc Lobelia arnhemica
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a Yarralin word.
\ee The dried plant can be chewed as bush tobacco; it is often mixed with commercial tobacco and some ash. In the past the old people chewed this before commercial tobacco was available. The plants are collected and dried in the sun for a period; they are then crushed before chewing. The Ngarinyman name 'jarrinymawu' means cave-dweller and refers to the fact that it grows in shaded areas under overhangs and generally near permanent water.
\cf
\pc walmawalmaj.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf

\dt 24/Jul/2008

\lx marluna
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge spinifex
\de spinifex
\sd M Plants
\re spinifex
\re Triodia sp.
\sy galanarrang
\va
\sc Triodia sp.
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The sticky leaves and stems can be used for medicine. They are boiled in water and the liquid used as a wash to treat bad colds and itchy skin. A wax (darla or gajarrang) may be obtained by burning the sticky leaves and stems. This resin is soft when it is hot but as it cools it sets very hard and is used as glue. It may be used to attach spear heads, axe heads and woomera hooks. Burning the leaves also produces smoke that repels mosquitoes. This type of spinifex grows on sandstone and limestone areas.
\cf
\pc 1Warrwa.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 07/Sep/2015

\lx marna
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge
\de barramundi
\sd K Water Animals
\re barramundi
\re Lates calcarifer
\sy manyirrgila
\sy manyin
\sy yinarrwa
\va
\sc Lates calcarifer
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a Yarralin word.
\ee The flesh can be eaten after roasting on hot coals. It is very tasty. Barramundi can get large and are hard to catch as they fight hard to get off the line. They are common in billabongs and the big rivers. They are mostly caught using live bait on hand-lines, although visiting fishermen often catch them with lures and rods. There is an important creation period story about the barramundi, the shark and the stingray. Barramundi are totems or Dreaming animals for some people. 'Yinarrwa' and 'manyirrgila' refer to large-sized fish; 'manyin' and 'marna' refer to small fish.
\cf
\pc barramundi.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 09/Sep/2015

\va
\sc Scatophagus argus
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This small pretty fish often swims with its head down and its tail up. It is not eaten as it is usually too small.
\cf

\lx marnawirri
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge magpie.goose
\de magpie goose
\sd J Birds
\re goose (magpie)
\re magpie goose
\re Anseranas semipalmata
\sy munama
\sy guyamalinggi
\va
\sc Anseranas semipalmata
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The meat is really good to eat. They occur in large numbers on the floodplains in northern areas, such as Bradshaw Station. The eggs are also very good to eat. They are collected from the floodplains in the wet season when they are nesting. 'Marnawirri' eats water chestnuts and their crops are sometimes full of the small yams. A fan can be made from the wings.
\cf
\pc magpie_goose.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 07/Sep/2015

\lx marnba
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge eel-tail.catfish
\de eel-tail catfish, Hyrtl's tandan
\sd K Water Animals
\re catfish (eel-tail)
\re eel-tail catfish
\re Hyrtl's tandan
\re Neosilurus hyrtlii
\sy ginyang
\va
\sc Neosilurus hyrtlii and other taxa
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The larger ones can be roasted and eaten. The flesh is tasty. The smaller ones are used as bait to catch larger fish such as barramundi. These catfish also have poisonous spines that must be carefully avoided. The spines cause a great deal of pain and swelling and are very dangerous. They are generally caught with nets or spears and do not take bait on hand-lines.
\cf
\pc flat-tailed_catfish.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 09/Sep/2015

\dt 08/Aug/2008

\lx marndalyji
\sf
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge military.dragon
\de military dragon, tata lizard
\sd I Reptiles
\re military dragon
\re lizard (tata)
\re tata lizard
\re Ctenophorus isolepis
\re Diporiphora spp.
\re Lophognathus spp.
\sy wulngawulngarn, ligarda
\va
\sc Ctenophorus isolepis
\sc Diporiphora spp.
\sc Lophognathus spp.
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a word from the northern and western areas.
\ee These small lizards often wave their front leg in the air. There are many different types. They are used in some ceremonies and there is a special site for them. The name 'wulngawulngarn' is based on the word for sun (wulngarn) because this lizard often looks at the sun.
\cf
\pc tata_lizard.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\sn 2
\ge ring-tailed.dragon
\de ring-tailed dragon
\sd I Reptiles
\re ring-tailed dragon
\re Ctenophorus caudicinctus
\sy bele
\va
\sc Ctenophorus caudicinctus
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a Yarralin word.
\ee This lizard is like a small goanna but it has a long tail. It lives in rocky country but has no particular use.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 20/Sep/2015

\lx marndayang
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge pear.tree
\de pear tree
\sd M Plants
\re pear tree
\re Terminalia platyphylla
\sy
\va
\sc Terminalia platyphylla
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This large tree grows in creeks and river beds. It is an excellent shade tree. The gum that exudes from damaged trunks and branches can be eaten. It is called 'mardiya' or 'marnda' and is a highly sought after delicacy. The gum is also good medicine to treat diarrhoea and to strengthen the digestive tract. The wood can be used as firewood. The fruit can be eaten when they turn red. They do not have much flesh but are sweet; they are also eaten by black cockatoos (walugbiny). This tree is spiritually important for Ngarinyman people and is associated with the Dreaming story of the black-headed python (walujabi).
\cf
\pc marndayag.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 28/Aug/2015

\lx marndula
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge bottle
\de bottle, glass
\sd D Things
\re bottle
\re glass
\sy murlugun
\va marndurla
\ve
\sc
\so NH, ES, JT, NA:CS12
\xv Marndula gurlurl garrany bamarra.
\sfx
\xe The bottle is on top of the rock.
\rf ER:KH:2006
\ue This is a Timber Creek word. Yarralin speakers consider that it is from Jaminjung or Ngaliwurru.
\ee
\cf
\lf Gurindji
\lv murlukun
\lf Jaminjung
\lv mawud 'quartz, glass, bottle'
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 20/Jul/2012

\lx marngilg
\sf
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge black.wattle
\de black wattle
\sd M Plants
\re wattle (black)
\re black wattle
\re Acacia auriculiformis
\sy
\va
\sc Acacia auriculiformis
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This tree is a good shade tree and it grows quite large. The leaves and fruit can be rubbed with water to produce a soapy lather. The fruit and leaves can also be used as fish poison. They are crushed and thrown into small waterholes and the fish float to the surface and can be collected, cooked and eaten.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\sn 2
\ge wattle
\de wattle
\sd M Plants
\re wattle
\re Acacia humifusa
\sy
\va
\sc Acacia humifusa
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The leaves can be used to make a soapy lather; it can be used to clean clothes.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf

\lx marrajmarraj
\sf

\de seagull
\sd J Birds
\re seagull
\re Larus novaehollandiae
\sy

\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010

\dt 07/Sep/2015

\lx marralung
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge black.plum
\de black plum
\sd M Plants
\re plum (black)
\re black plum
\re Vitex glabrata
\sy muying
\va
\sc Vitex glabrata
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The black fruit are eaten when they are ripe. They are very sweet and tasty. Often they are collected from the ground. The fruit can also be pounded on a flat rock and made into small dampers, which are lightly roasted and are highly regarded as a food source. The fruit are generally produced around the early wet season, but sometimes available later in the year. When you hear stormbird (duwag), calling out with its distinctive call, it signals that the black fruit are ripe and ready to be collected. The ripe black fruit are also a favoured food for emus (nangurrungurru) and dingos (ngurragin). The straight dry side stems are used to make fire-sticks or bush matches, to light a fire using the traditional drilling or friction method.
\cf
\pc muying.jpg
\se
\de
\dt 6/Aug/2018

\lx marraman
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge cypress.pine
\de cypress pine
\sd M Plants
\re cypress pine
\re Callitris intratropica
\sy
\va
\sc Callitris intratropica
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This tree mainly grows in sandstone areas. The timber is excellent firewood which burns well in the wet season. The fragrant smoke repels mosquitoes when the timber is burnt. The wood can be used to make boomerangs and nulla-nullas. The timber was used by settlers to build houses and stockyards, and was also used to build the boat landing at the original Timber Creek depot.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 17/Aug/2015

\dt 27/Nov/2008

\lx marrawung
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge spinifex.pigeon
\de spinifex pigeon, Indian-head pigeon
\sd J Birds
\re pigeon (spinifex)
\re spinifex pigeon
\re pigeon (Indian-head)
\re Indian-head pigeon
\re Geophaps plumifera
\sy widijburru
\sy garlawarra
\sy garlarr
\va
\sc Geophaps plumifera
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a word from the northern and western areas.
\ee The Spinifex Pigeon is sometimes called Indian-head because of the feathers sticking up from its head and it has a stripe on its face similar to war-paint. It has a distinctive call: coo.coo.coo.coo.coo.coo. Sometimes it is called 'gumundunga' in reference to the feathers sticking up on its head. The name 'widijburru' was also the personal name of Bobby Widijburru. The meat can be eaten after roasting and it is tender and tasty.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf

\lx marrud
\sf
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge river.grass
\de river grass
\sd M Plants
\re grass (river)
\re river grass
\re Mnesithea rottboellioides
\sy
\va
\sc Mnesithea rottboellioides
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The leaves and stems are boiled in water and the liquid used as a wash for treating skin sores. The young stems are chewed as they are sweet and tasty. The older stems are used by children to make toy spears.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\sn 2
\ge cane.grass
\de cane grass
\sd M Plants
\re grass (cane)

\sy

\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This large grass has thick stems that are used as toy spears by children. It has sharp new stems that poke up through the ground and you need to be careful when you walk through it.
\cf

\lx midayi
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge mate
\de mate, friend
\sd B People
\re mate
\re friend
\sy jimarri
\va
\ve
\sc
\so ER:ESB, NH:CJ:2/1/95; NH,JC:CJ,JM:2015
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a Kriol word which comes from 'mate'.
\ee A woman can use this term to refer to her brother's wife, or distant family like sister-in-law, as a term of respect. A man can similarly use this word for his sister's brother.

\lx mijirr
\sf
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge hill.billy.goat.plum
\de hill billy goat plum
\sd M Plants
\re plum (hill billy goat)
\re hill billy goat plum
\re Terminalia carpentariae
\sy
\va
\sc Terminalia carpentariae
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This tree grows on sandstone areas and in sandy country. It can get quite large. The fruit are eaten when they turn pale yellow. Sometimes they are produced in large quantities. Some people consider them to be only kangaroo tucker and do not eat them.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf

\sd M Plants
\re plum (billy goat)
\re billy goat plum

\sy
\va
\sc Terminalia latipes
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The fruit are eaten when they turn pale yellow. Sometimes they are produced in large quantities. They are considered to be kangaroo tucker by some people.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de

\sfx

\lx milyung
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge water.goanna
\de water goanna
\sd I Reptiles
\re goanna (water)
\re water goanna
\re Varanus mertensi
\sy jabungarna, wigama, judja, warndingu
\va
\sc Varanus mertensi

\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a word from the northern and western areas.
\ee This goanna lives in water and is very good to eat. They are sometimes caught on a hand-line while fishing. The meat tastes like fish and has a nice clean taste. 'Milyung' is the female of this species.

\lx minawud
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge wallaroo
\de wallaroo, blue or hill kangaroo, euro
\sd H Mammals
\re wallaroo
\re kangaroo (blue)
\re blue kangaroo
\re kangaroo (hill)
\re hill kangaroo
\re Euro
\re Osphranter robustus
\sy yarrangun
\sy garriwarna
\sy winangburru
\va
\sc Osphranter robustus
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee These kangaroos are often seen in hilly areas and are good to eat after roasting. They are often called the blue kangaroo due to the dark, woolly fur that is bluish in colour. 'Minawud' is a term used for the male of this species.

\dt 06/Jul/2017

\lx mindiwirri
\sf
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge wattle
\de wattle
\sd M Plants
\re wattle
\re Acacia hemignosta
\sy
\va
\sc Acacia hemignosta
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The dark heartwood can be used to make boomerangs. It is also a good shade tree.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\sn 2
\ge boomerang.tree
\de boomerang tree
\sd M Plants
\re boomerang tree
\re Hakea arborescens
\sy
\va
\sc Hakea arborescens
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The hard timber is used to make boomerangs. The fruit are used as medicine to treat small children. The fruit are scraped and the scrapings mixed with water and this is applied to children and it makes them strong and helps them to walk. The wood may be burnt to ash and the ash mixed with water to form a warm, fairly dry but slightly moist mix. A baby is then sat down on a layer of this mix and more is piled around the baby and firmly pressed against the arms, chest, throat, hips, back and legs. This has the effect of strengthening the baby both physically and mentally. It takes some time before the benefits of 'burning' a baby are noticed. The bark is boiled in water and the liquid used as a medicinal wash to treat skin complaints. In the past the ashes from the leaves were mixed with chewing tobacco. In recent times different bark burnt to ashes from different plants have been used.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 17/Aug/2015

\dt 03/Jul/2017

\lx minirrminirr
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge swamp.lignum
\de swamp lignum
\sd M Plants
\re lignum (swamp)
\re Muehlenbeckia florulenta
\sy
\va
\sc Muehlenbeckia florulenta
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This plant indicates a good place to hunt for long-necked turtle (wirringunany) sometimes crocodiles also hide under the stems of these plants. The larger straight stems can be used to make the shaft of the small bullet-spears. These light spears flew very fast and could skip off the ground. They were used in man-to-man fighting. The hollow stems can also be used as toy pipes (larrwa). The flowers are eaten by ducks and turtles; flowering indicates a good time to hunt these animals as they will be fat.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 27/Aug/2015

\ee These small insects have horns like a buffalo; they catch other insects and ants in the traps they dig in the ground.

\dt 23/07/2012

\lx miyaliny
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge freshwater.mangrove
\de freshwater mangrove
\sd M Plants
\re mangrove (freshwater)
\re freshwater mangrove
\re Barringtonia acutangula
\sy
\va
\sc Barringtonia acutangula
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The leaves may be used as fish poison. Small branches and twigs are broken off and dragged around in the water of a billabong; this has the effect of stunning the fish and causing them to float on the surface. They can then be easily collected and cooked before eating. This tree also provides excellent shade in areas near rivers and billabongs. Much time may be spent in this shade fishing and relaxing. Fish and turtles eat the flowers and fruit when they fall into the water.
\cf
\pc jilaminy.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 17/Aug/2015

\sd M Plants
\re rosewood
\re Terminalia volucris
\sy

\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This small tree grows in bush country and often on black soil areas. The gum may be eaten; it is sweet and tasty and lasts in the mouth for a long period. The gum is also eaten to treat diarrhoea. The gum is eaten by bush turkeys (jamud) who love it. This is a good shade tree.

\dt 07/Nov/2017

\lx mugaj
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge rubber-yam
\de rubber-yam
\sd M Plants
\re rubber-yam
\re Typhonium liliifolium
\sy
\va
\sc Typhonium liliifolium
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This small plant grows in the wet season. It has large purple flowers near the ground. They grow in flat areas near rivers and creeks. The tubers were eaten in the past after repeated crushing and cooking. The yams were crushed and then cooked and the process repeated again, until the flesh lost its rubbery texture. If not properly prepared they would burn the lips and tongue. 'Mugaj' is a countryman for 'dagirriny' (Crinum angustifolium), the onion-lily yam that also has a rubbery texture when it is prepared.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 07/Sep/2015

\lx mugmug
\sf
\ps n

\re owl (barking)

\re Ninox connivens
\sy
\va
\sc Ninox connivens
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The name 'mugmug' is based on the sound of the call. They call at night and sound like a dog barking.
\cf
\pc barking_owl.jpg

\de
\xv
\sfx

\dt 15/Jul/2003

\lx mulguwurru
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge little.egret
\de little egret
\sd J Birds
\re egret (little)
\re little eel
\re Ardea ibis
\sy
\va
\sc Ardea ibis
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee In the past the meat was eaten after roasting on hot coals.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 07/Sep/2015

\lx mulij
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge leichhardt.tree
\de Leichhardt tree
\sd M Plants
\re Leichhardt tree
\re Nauclea orientalis
\sy nyimili, jamba
\va
\sc Nauclea orientalis
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This is a large tree that grows on rivers and near springs. It is a good shade tree. The fruit can be eaten when they are ripe, brown. The fruit that have fallen in the water are eaten by turtles (guwarlambarla) and black bream (gambajawung). When this tree has fruit it is a good time to go fishing. The yellow wood is light and relatively soft; however it can be used to make woomera shafts, light shields, coolamons and canoes. In the past it was used on stations to make gates. The wood was sawn on large circular saws driven by machines; the timber was left to dry for a month before it was sawn to allow the sap to dry out. The planks were doubled-up on the gates to make them stronger.
\cf
\pc jamba.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 27/Aug/2015

\sn

\sy gajirri

\lx mun.gud
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge termite
\de termite
\sd L Insects and Spiders
\re termite
\re Isoptera
\re Coptotermes
\sy
\va
\sc Isoptera
\sc Coptotermes
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee These termites (also known as white ants) eat the wood on the inside of trees, allowing didgeridoos to be made from the hollow trunks and branches. There is a creation or Dreaming story about 'mun.gud'.
\cf
\pc Termite.jpg

\dt 21/Sep/2015

\lx mun.gurru
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge buffalo
\de buffalo
\sd H Mammals
\re buffalo
\re Bubalus bubalis
\sy windurruyawung
\sy windurru
\sy maranji
\sy gardbibarndal
\sy wumburrurru
\va
\sc Bubalus bubalis
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a word from the northern and western areas.
\ee There are occasionally wild buffalo still seen but most were killed during the BTEC scheme in the 1980s and 1990s. The meat is good to eat, especially from young ones. It has a strong taste. Buffalo are cranky and dangerous in the bush.
\cf
\pc Buffalo.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 22/Sep/2015

\lx munama
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge magpie.goose
\de magpie goose
\sd J Birds
\re goose (magpie)
\re magpie goose
\re Anseranas semipalmata
\sy marnawirri
\sy guyamalinggi
\va
\sc Anseranas semipalmata
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a word from the northern and western areas.
\ee The meat is really good to eat. They occur in large numbers on the floodplains in northern areas, such as Bradshaw Station. The eggs are also very good to eat. They are collected from the floodplains in the wet season when they are nesting. 'Munama' eats the water chestnut and their crops are sometimes full of the small yams. A fan can be made from the wings.
\cf
\pc magpie_goose.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf

\dt 28/Nov/2008

\lx mungamunga
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge spirit.women
\de spirit women
\sd C Language and Culture
\sd B People
\re spirit women
\re woman (spirit)
\sy
\va
\ve
\sc
\so NH,IW:CJ:98
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The Mungamunga are spirit women who appear to women in dreams and give them new songs. These songs are called 'jarrarda' and are secret women's songs. The Mungamunga also steal husbands and children. The Mungamunga passed through Bilinarra country visiting many places created by the Nangangari. There are Mungamunga songs associated with these places. These days, Mungamunga women are sighted frequently at Cattle Creek.
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 28/Nov/2008

\lx munggu
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge yellow-faced.turtle
\de yellow-faced turtle
\sd I Reptiles
\re turtle (yellow-faced)
\re yellow-faced turtle
\re Emydura victoriae
\sy ningal
\va
\sc Emydura victoriae
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This turtle is generally caught on hand-lines when fishing. The meat is very tasty and highly sought after. They can also be caught by feeling around in the water in billabongs and slow moving parts of rivers. They are quite common. Sometimes they get very large swollen heads which are called 'munggu'.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 20/Sep/2015

\lx munmunung
\sf
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge mud.wasp
\de mud wasp, hornet
\sd L Insects and Spiders
\re wasp (mud)
\re mud wasp
\re hornet
\re Hymenoptera, Vespidae, Delta spp.
\sy burrmarri
\va
\sc Hymenoptera, Vespidae, Delta spp.
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a Yarralin word.
\ee These large black and yellow wasps make a nest from mud collected from the edge of puddles, creeks and waterholes. They are cheeky and can sting you. They sing when they find sugarbag.

\de
\xv

\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a Yarralin word.
\ee These large black and yellow wasps make a nest from mud collected from the edge of puddles, creeks and waterholes. They are cheeky and can sting you. They sing when they find sugarbag.

\lx munngarna
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge rock.cod
\de rock cod, sleepy cod, giant gudgeon
\sd K Water Animals
\re cod (rock)
\re rock cod
\re cod (sleepy)
\re sleepy cod
\re gudgeon (giant)
\re Oxyeleotris lineolata
\re Oxyeleotris selheimi
\sy nyagurnang
\sy warn.guya
\sy dalwag
\va
\sc Oxyeleotris lineolata
\sc Oxyeleotris selheimi
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee These slow moving fish live in the deep waterholes; they sleep all day on the bottom. The flesh can be eaten after roasting on hot coals. Sometimes they can be caught in large numbers and they can get quite big.

\sn

\pc

\de here, at this place
\xv Murlangga gala.
\sfx
\xe Leave it here (don't move it).
\rf KJ:CJ:2005
\xv Murlangga-da garru, jawardirla?
\sfx
\xe Are you mob going to be here tomorrow?
\rf NH:CJ:21/06/1995
\xv Girr-warna ganga murlangga walyag yuwani dan.gu.
\sfx
\xe I remember where I put my food inside.
\rf JT:JM1-022 2016 book 2, p85
\se murlanggurra
\de hither, to this place
\se murlangurlung
\de from here
\xv Gula-rna yan.gu wanyjiga murlangurlung. Murlangga ngayiny-ja.
\sfx
\xe I can't go anywhere away from here. This is where my people are.
\rf NH:CJ:1/1/95

\sfx
\xe We eat honey and pollen from this tree.

\lx murlud
\sf
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge wattle
\de wattle
\sd M Plants
\re wattle
\re Acacia monticola
\sy
\va
\sc Acacia monticola
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This plant is a very good medicine tree. The leaves are boiled in water and the liquid used as a wash to treat any illness.
\cf
\pc
\se

\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\sn 2
\ge shrub.species
\de type of shrub
\sd M Plants
\re Dodonaea polyzyga
\sy

\xv
\sfx

\ue
\ee This small plant often grows in rocky areas. The leaves and branches are very sticky and strong smelling. They are used as medicine by boiling in water and using the liquid as a washing medicine to treat skin sores, headache, colds, congestion, flu and itchy skin.

\lx murrulumbu
\sf
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge prickly.wattle
\de prickly wattle
\sd M Plants
\re wattle (prickly)
\re prickly wattle
\re Acacia (Vachellia) farnesiana
\sy
\va
\sc Acacia (Vachellia) farnesiana
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This plant has sharp hard prickles. In the past the flowers were crushed and sprinkled on ladies' hair for decoration and perfume. The sharp prickles can be poked into the base of warts. This slowly kills the wart and after a while they fall off.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\sn 2
\ge prickle.bush
\de prickle bush
\sd M Plants
\re prickle bush
\re Dichrostachys spicata
\sy baga
\va
\sc Dichrostachys spicata
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This plant has sharp hard prickles. It grows in open areas and is a good shade tree. Bullocks eat the leaves when grass becomes scarce in the late dry season. The term 'baga' can be used generally to refer anything that is prickly.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\sn 3
\ge parkinsonia
\de parkinsonia
\sd M Plants

\sfx

\sfx
\xe

\lx muunggaji
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge cattle
\de cattle, bullock, cow
\sd H Mammals
\re cattle
\re bullock
\re Bos taurus
\re Bos indicus
\sy burruna
\sy barrayarna
\sy bulugi
\sy ngarin
\va
\sc Bos taurus
\sc Bos indicus
\so NH:CJ:2/6/95
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This name refers to the sound 'muung' that they make. The meat is very good to eat after roasting. In recent times brahmans have become very common and shorthorns have become less common. Shorthorns are generally easier to handle in yards and are less likely to charge, while brahmans are more dangerous. The meat from shorthorns has better flavour and is more tender. The term 'ngarin' refers to the meat. 'Bulngayarri' refers to the bull and 'burruna' refers to a young bull.
\cf
\pc cow.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf

\lx najuna
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge black.flying-fox
\de black flying-fox
\sd H Mammals
\re flying-fox (black)
\re black flying-fox
\re Pteropus alecto
\sy yiburru, warrba, dijuna
\va
\sc Pteropus alecto
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a word from the northern and western areas.
\ee The flesh can be eaten after roasting. It has a strong distinctive smell and taste. In the past they were killed by throwing hunting sticks into the roosting colonies. Crocodiles eat them when they roost in paperbark trees hanging over rivers and billabongs. They are larger and more common than the red flying-fox. Flying-foxes have special cultural significance for Ngarinyman people.
\cf
\pc Black_flying_fox.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 09/Sep/2015

\lx nalij
\sf
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge celtis
\de celtis
\sd M Plants
\re celtis
\re Celtis philippensis
\sy
\va
\sc Celtis philippensis
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The reddish fruit are eaten by birds but not by people. This small tree grows in rocky areas. The bark can be boiled in water and the liquid used as a wash to treat itchy skin and leprosy. It dries out the sores but does not cure it. The inner bark is scraped off and soaked in cold water. The liquid is drunk to treat loss of appetite and lung congestion.
\cf
\pc jurrunggij.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\sn 2
\ge native.cherry
\de native cherry
\sd M Plants
\re cherry (native)
\re Exocarpos latifolius
\sy
\va
\sc Exocarpos latifolius
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The fruit are eaten when they turn red. The inner bark is boiled in water and the liquid used as a medicinal wash to treat colds and flus. A small amount may also be sipped. Bad spirits sometimes live near these small rounded trees. It is generally best to keep away from them and not to walk close to them.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\sn 3
\ge tree.species
\de type of tree
\sd M Plants
\re Pouteria sericea
\sy
\va
\sc Pouteria sericea
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The fruit is eaten when it is ripe, dark red to black. This small rounded tree grows on rocky hillsides.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\sn 4
\ge strychnine.tree
\de strychnine tree
\sd M Plants
\re strychnine tree
\re Strychnos lucida
\sy
\va
\sc Strychnos lucida
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This tree is considered to be poisonous, however the dense canopy provides cool shade. It grows on rocky hillsides and in jungle areas near rivers and creeks.
\cf
\pc jurrunggij2.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 20/Aug/2015

\lx nalija
\sf
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge bush.tea-leaf
\de bush tea-leaf
\sd M Plants
\re bush tea-leaf
\re Ocimum tenuiflorum
\sy jilinbug
\sy wayildi
\va
\sc Ocimum tenuiflorum
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The leaves are boiled in water to make tea to drink. It has a strong smell and pleasant taste. The tea made from this plant also has medicinal qualities and is good to treat colds and congestion. In the past this plant was used a lot by old people as tea. There is a lot of it growing on Waterloo Station. The liquid can also be used as a wash to treat itchy sores and skin. The drink is also good for providing sustenance when walking a long way, especially if there is no food to be found. The tea can keep you going until food is found. It makes you strong when you are feeling weak. The word 'nalija' is also used to refer to commercial tea that is available from shops.
\cf
\pc juminjumin.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\sn 2
\ge tea
\de tea
\sd E Food and Cooking
\re tea
\sy
\va
\ve
\sc
\so MW:CJ:94, RB:ESB
\xv Mangarri na gambala gid-barna mana mangarri-ma jardgarra-wu nalijarra.
\sfx
\xe I cooked damper and I broke it in half and had some with my tea.
\rf KJ:JM1-019 2016 book 2, p48
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc tea-lalija.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 22/Oct/2011

\dt 06/Jul/2017

\lx namawurru
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge sugarbag
\de sugarbag, native bee-hive
\sd L Insects and Spiders
\re sugarbag
\re native bee-hive
\re Apoidea, Apidae, Trigona spp.
\sy ngarlu
\sy namawurru
\va namawurru
\sc Apoidea, Apidae, Trigona spp.
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee Native bee-hives or sugarbag contain sweet dark honey that is very tasty and much sought after. The hives also contain wax, pollen and eggs. The small bees (lanu) have no sting and are harmless. Sugarbag has special cultural significance for Ngarinyman people. The general terms for sugarbag are 'ngunjung', 'namawurru' and 'ngarlu'. They can also refer to the sweet dark honey. Sugarbag occurs in three main places. One is found in hollows in trees, another occurs in the ground and the third in termite mounds. Ground sugarbag is called 'gujbulurru' and 'nanggaliny'. The ground sugarbag that has its honey all mixed up and cannot be eaten is called 'jarndirrang'. Tree sugarbag is called 'ngidiwiny' (small), 'yaramarrgu' (big) or 'janganggu' (smaller tree sugarbag found in some paperbark trees). The door to the hive is called 'jigala'. The small stingless bee is called 'munuwi' or 'lanu'. The yellow eggs and pollen in the hive are called 'gundarri', 'jawurrga' and 'jawurru'. The really strong wax is called 'darla'. The general term for sugarbag wax is 'biyanag' or 'ngarningburru'.
\cf
\pc sugarbag.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 21/Sep/2015

\lx Nambijina
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge skin.name
\de skin name for a woman
\sd B People
\re skin name (woman)
\sy
\va Nambijin
\ve
\sc
\so NH:CJ:2/1/95
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee Nambijin is the Ngaliwurru version of this name, and Nampin is a Gurindji version.
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 06/Jul/2017

\lx nambula
\sf
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge cluster.fig
\de cluster fig
\sd M Plants
\re Ficus congesta
\sy jadgala
\sy jalwarra
\va
\sc Ficus congesta
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The fruit are eaten when they are ripe, a red to brown colour; they are tasty. Flying-foxes, fish and turtles also eat the fruit.
\cf
\pc nambula.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\sn 2
\ge cluster.fig
\de cluster fig
\sd M Plants
\re fig (cluster)
\re cluster fig
\re Ficus racemosa
\sy jadgala
\va
\sc Ficus racemosa
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The fruit are eaten when they are ripe, red to brown. The fruit that fall into the river are eaten by fish and turtles. It is generally a good place to go fishing as the fish are already there waiting for food. The dried fruit can be collected from under the tree and then mixed with hot water and sugar and eaten. The wood can be used to make coolamons. In the past the logs were used as floats when crossing large rivers, sometimes children were sat on the logs to cross the rivers. Flying-foxes also eat the fruit. This tree is spiritually important for Ngarinyman people and is associated with the Dreaming story of the black-headed python (walujabi).
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 25/Aug/2015

\lx namijnamij
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge black-headed.python
\de black-headed python
\sd I Reptiles
\re python (black-headed)
\re black-headed python
\re Aspidites melanocephalus
\sy walujabi
\sy waluru
\va
\sc Aspidites melanocephalus
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This python has a distinctive black shiny head. It is roasted in a ground oven with hot rocks and paperbark and the flesh eaten. There is a very important creation period or Dreaming story for this snake and a number of sacred and significant sites associated with this story. It has the 'Namij' skin and is sometimes referred by this name, although 'Walujabi' is the most commonly used name. 'Walujabi' has a long and powerful Dreaming line that travels across many language areas from saltwater country in the north across the Top End and down through the desert areas of central Australia.
\cf
\pc black_headed_python.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 20/Sep/2015

\lx nanguba
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge cat
\de cat
\sd H Mammals
\re cat
\re pussycat
\re Felis catus
\sy nyawunyawu
\sy nyirrinyirri
\sy walumumba
\sy warlugurda
\sy wilirumawu
\sy ngaya
\sy bujigat
\va
\sc Felis catus
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a Yarralin word.
\ee In the past people used to roast and eat the meat; it is tasty. Feral cats are good hunters and eat a lot of small native animals. The males, tom cats, can get very large and aggressive.

\lx nangurrungurru
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge emu
\de emu
\sd J Birds
\re emu
\re Dromaius novae-hollandiae
\sy yibarrardu
\sy wanyayawung
\va
\sc Dromaius novae-hollandiae
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The meat is good to eat, although it is dark red and has a strong smell. Some people don't like the taste of the meat. There is lot of meat on one bird and they are usually cooked in a ground oven. The small chicks have stripes on their bodies and are called 'winini' and 'wididij'. In the past they were hunted with spears and boomerangs, now they are hunted with shotguns. They eat various bush-tucker fruit, especially the black plum (muying). This bird has special cultural significance for Ngarinyman people.
\cf
\pc emu.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 07/Sep/2015

\lx nanjarrgadag
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge sugarleaf
\de sugar-leaf, sweet-leaf (lerps)
\sd L Insects and Spiders
\re sugarleaf
\re sweet-leaf
\re lerps
\re Hemiptera
\re Psyllidae
\sy garnbanga
\sy jalyingarna
\va nanjarrnga
\sc Hemiptera
\sc Psyllidae
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee These small white scale-like insect-coverings are collected off the bloodwood (jardburra) and the river red gum tree (dimarlan) leaves during the cold weather time and eaten. They are very sweet and tasty. The branches and twigs are broken off and left to dry over a calico sheet. The lerps are then collected and shaped into small balls and eaten. These balls used to be stored in cake-tins for weeks and months. This food has special cultural significance for Ngarinyman people.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 21/Sep/2015

\de rusty bloodwood
\sd M Plants

\lx narubu

\lx ngabilyibilyi
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge whirlygig.beetle
\de whirlygig beetle
\sd L Insects and Spiders
\re beetle (whirlygig)
\re Coleoptera, Macrogyrus spp.
\sy jabuju
\va
\sc Coleoptera, Macrogyrus spp. and others
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a Timber Creek word.
\ee These small black beetles swim around in circles on the top of water in quiet pools in creeks. They are considered to be the mother of the freshwater turtles and are not harmed in any way.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 21/Sep/2015

\dt 12/Sep/2008

\lx ngalijirri
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge female.plains.kangaroo
\de female plains kangaroo or antilopine wallaroo
\sd H Mammals
\re kangaroo (plains, female)
\re plains kangaroo (female)
\re Osphranter antilopinus
\sy jardugarl, bunggiyin, wawirri
\va
\sc Osphranter antilopinus
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a word from the northern and western areas.
\ee This kangaroo generally lives on grassy plains, often on red soil country. It is tall and thin compared to the hill kangaroo. Plains kangaroos have special significance for Ngarinyman people. It is a Dreaming for some people. 'Ngalijirri' is a term used for the male of this species in the northern and western areas.
\cf jaliny
\pc Antilopine_Wallaroo.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 20/Feb/2018

\lx ngalyja
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge green.tree.frog
\de green tree frog
\sd I Reptiles
\re frog (green tree)
\re green tree frog
\re Litoria caerulea
\sy ngagbarn
\sy balngawung
\va
\sc Litoria caerulea
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a word from the northern and western areas.
\ee This large green frog is commonly heard calling during the heavy rains of the wet season. They are often seen around toilets and laundry areas of houses.

\dt 18/Jul/2018

\lx ngamanburru
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge conkerberry
\de conkerberry
\sd M Plants
\re conkerberry
\re Carissa lanceolata
\sy budbara
\va
\sc Carissa lanceolata
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The fruit are eaten when they are black; they are sweet and very tasty. When the fireflies are active at night in the wet season, it indicates the fruit are ripe and ready to eat. Many different birds also eat the fruit, especially emus (nangurrungurru). The inner wood of the roots and stems is bright orange in colour. The wood can be used to make boomerangs, and these boomerangs fly faster and further than other boomerangs. When the wood is sanded and polished it becomes very glossy and flies through the air really well. The roots are used to cure toothaches. The roots are dug up and the inner orange wood is scraped off in fine shavings. This is pushed into the hole in a tooth and it stops the pain.
\cf
\pc ngamanburru.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 20/Aug/2015

\lx nganyiwan
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge bloodwood.sap
\de sap from 'jardburru' (bloodwood)
\sd M Plants
\re sap (bloodwood)
\sy
\va
\sc
\so Ngarinyman Ethnobotany-, PMC-, LR:ESB:95
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This sap is used in bush medicine. You can place the red sap directly onto an aching tooth and it stops the pain. You can also boil it in water and use the liquid to wash skin sores.

\lx ngarin

\lf Jaminjung

\dt 07/Sep/2018

\lx ngaringari
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge green.plum
\de green plum
\sd M Plants
\re plum (green)
\re green plum
\re Buchanania obovata
\sy jamurru
\sy barrarraj
\va
\sc Buchanania obovata
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The fruit are eaten when they are ripe, green but soft to touch. They are produced at the beginning or early in the wet season and are very tasty. They are generally collected once they have fallen to the ground. In the past the fruit and seed were crushed and mixed into a paste that was good for small children and old people. 'Barrarraj' are the larger trees with large woody trunks, and these are considered to be the mother of 'ngaringari' and 'jamurru', the smaller trees with thinner trunks.
\cf
\pc barrarraj2.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 04/Sep/2018

\dt 03/Jul/2017

\lx ngarlu
\sf
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge rosella
\de rosella
\sd M Plants
\re rosella
\re Hibiscus sabdariffa
\sy
\va
\sc Hibiscus sabdariffa
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The bright red fruit can be eaten. They have a sharp taste; they can also be made into jam. This is an introduced plant that has become a weed in some areas. The language name is the same name that is used for sugarbag.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\sn 2
\ge sugarbag
\de sugarbag, native bee-hive
\sd L Insects and Spiders
\re sugarbag
\re native bee-hive
\re Apoidea, Apidae, Trigona spp.
\sy ngunjung
\sy namawurru
\va
\sc Apoidea, Apidae, Trigona spp.
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee Native bee-hives or sugarbag contain sweet dark honey that is very tasty and much sought after. The hives also contain wax, pollen and eggs. The small bees (lanu) have no sting and are harmless. Sugarbag has special cultural significance for Ngarinyman people. The general terms for sugarbag are 'ngunjung', 'namawurru' and 'ngarlu'. They can also refer to the sweet dark honey. Sugarbag occurs in three main places. One is found in hollows in trees, another occurs in the ground and the third in termite mounds. Ground sugarbag is called 'gujbulurru' and 'nanggaliny'. The ground sugarbag that has its honey all mixed up and cannot be eaten is called 'jarndirrang'. Tree sugarbag is called 'ngidiwiny' (small), 'yaramarrgu' (big) or 'janganggu' (smaller tree sugarbag found in some paperbark trees). The door to the hive is called 'jigala'. The small stingless bee is called 'munuwi' or 'lanu'. The yellow eggs and pollen in the hive are called 'gundarri', 'jawurrga' and 'jawurru'. The really strong wax is called 'darla'. The general term for sugarbag wax is 'biyanag' or 'ngarningburru'.
\cf
\pc sugarbag.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 21/Sep/2015

\lx ngarmarndingamarndi
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge butterfly
\de butterfly, moth
\sd L Insects and Spiders
\re butterfly
\re moth
\re Lepidoptera
\sy marlimarli
\va
\sc
\sc Lepidoptera
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a Timber Creek word.
\ee There are many different types of butterflies and moths in various colours and sizes. Caterpillars are called 'wanbura' or 'milgurru' (Yarralin).
\cf
\pc butterfly.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 21/Sep/2015

\rf ER: ES99_N02_Ngar.005
\ue

\lx ngarranginy
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge frill-necked.lizard
\de frill-necked lizard, blanket lizard
\sd I Reptiles
\re lizard (frill-necked)
\re frill-necked lizard
\re lizard (blanket)
\re blanket lizard
\re Chlamydosaurus kingi
\sy garaga
\sy gardan.ga
\sy jaman.gula
\va
\sc Chlamydosaurus kingi
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a word from the northern and western areas.
\ee The flesh can be eaten after roasting. The flesh and fat are tasty. The frill or blanket is burnt on ashes until it turns black and it is then rubbed with fat. This is in turn rubbed through the hair to make it go dark and healthy; it makes big hair. It can also be rubbed onto the head of a baby so they grow up with healthy hair. When the rains begin the blanket lizard runs around eating ants. They are cheeky and will chase you and try to bite you.
\cf
\pc frilled_neck_lizard.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 20/Sep/2015

\lx ngarriyu
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge wild.rice
\de wild rice
\sd M Plants
\re wild rice
\re Oryza australiensis
\sy
\va ngarruyu
\sc Oryza australiensis
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The seeds of this grass are eaten by magpie geese (marnawirri) and ducks (jibilyugu). In the past old people used to collect the seeds and grind them into flour. This was made into johnny-cakes that were roasted and eaten. Sometimes the Johnny-cakes were eaten raw and they were sweet and tasty. This food was health promoting and was like a form of medicine as well.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv Ngarriyu man.gu-li gan.gula barlwan-jirri yudurrb garrawu-li.
\sfx
\xe Let's get wild rice and grind it on top of a flat rock.
\rf ER:ESB:94
\dt 07/Sep/2018

\lx ngulumarra
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge itchy.grubs
\de itchy grubs
\sd L Insects and Spiders
\re grubs (itchy)
\re Lepidoptera, Lymantriidae, Euproctis lutea
\sy
\va
\sc Lepidoptera, Lymantriidae, Euproctis lutea
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee These grubs often feed on the leaves of freshwater mangrove (Barringtonia acutangula) trees and can cause severe itchiness and swelling. They are quite dangerous and must be avoided at all times. They can cause temporary blindness.

\lx ngungungmarna
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge nail-tail.kangaroo
\de nail-tail kangaroo, left-hand kangaroo, northern nail-tail wallaby
\sd H Mammals
\re kangaroo (nail-tail)
\re nail-tail kangaroo
\re kangaroo (left-hand)
\re left-hand kangaroo
\re wallaby (northern nail-tail)
\re northern nail-tail wallaby
\re Onychogalea unguifera
\sy dugulgul, gurrurrungguny
\va
\sc Onychogalea unguifera
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a Yarralin word.
\ee This kangaroo has a prickle in the end of its tail and often makes a 'oo..oo..oo' noise when it is hopping. There is a special song that 'ngungungmarna' sings as he hops along. It also holds its left arm up to its chest when hopping. The flesh can be eaten after roasting in a ground oven, but it is not eaten as often as the other kangaroos and wallabies.
\cf
\pc Northern_nailtail_wallaby.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 09/Sep/2015

\lx ngungungub

\rf JC,CD:CJ:2018
\se ngunggarra yanan
\de come humming or puttering
\xv Ngunggarra yanarnin

\xe He's coming up humming.

\va
\sc Apoidea, Apidae, Trigona spp.
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee Native bee-hives or sugarbag contain sweet dark honey that is very tasty and much sought after. The hives also contain wax, pollen and eggs. The small bees have no sting and are harmless. Sugarbag has special cultural significance for Ngarinyman people. The general terms for sugarbag are 'ngunjung', 'namawurru' and 'ngarlu'. They can also refer to the sweet dark honey, when used in general conversation. Sugarbag occurs in three main places. One is found in hollows in trees, another occurs in the ground and the third in termite mounds. Ground sugarbag is called 'gujbulurru' and 'nanggaliny'. The ground sugarbag that has its honey all mixed up and cannot be eaten is called 'jarndirrang'. Tree sugarbag is called 'ngidiwiny' (small), 'yaramarrgu' (big) or 'janganggu' (smaller tree sugarbag found in some paperbark trees). The door to the hive is called 'jigala'. The small stingless bee is called 'munuwi' or 'lanu'. The yellow eggs and pollen in the hive are called 'gundarri', 'jawurrga' and 'jawurru'. The really strong wax is called 'darla'. The general term for sugarbag wax is 'biyanag' or 'ngarningburru'.
\cf namawurru
\pc sugarbag.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 21/Sep/2015

\lx ngunjungunjung
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge gardenia
\de gardenia
\sd M Plants
\re gardenia
\re Gardenia megasperma
\sy
\va
\sc Gardenia megasperma
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The stipules at the growing point of each branch can be eaten; it is like chewing gum as it lasts in the mouth for a long time. It is mainly eaten by children. The inner bark is boiled in water and the liquid used as a wash to treat skin disorders and itchy skin.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 26/Aug/2015

\lx ngurlgurna
\sf
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge sand.frog
\de sand frog
\sd I Reptiles
\re frog (sand)
\re sand frog
\re Limnodynastes ornatus
\sy nawurla
\va
\sc Limnodynastes ornatus
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a Yarralin word.
\ee This frog lives in burrows in the ground during the dry season and comes out in the wet season. It has an important Dreamtime story that relates to billabongs and water.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\sn 2
\ge giant.frog
\de giant frog
\sd I Reptiles

\re giant frog

\sy wagugwagug
\va
\sc Cyclorana australis
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a Yarralin word.
\ee This large frog is brown and lives in holes in the ground, during the wet season it calls out 'wagug..wagug..wagug'.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\sn 3
\ge cane.toad
\de cane toad
\sd I Reptiles
\re toad (cane)
\re Rhinella marina
\sy warnayag ngagbarn, warnayag ngalyja, jalgarni
\va
\sc Rhinella marina
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a Yarralin word.
\ee This large toad has been in the area for a few years and it has large poison glands near the ears. They are dangerous. When they first arrived many goannas disappeared but now they are starting to come back. The language names refer to a strange or new frog.
\cf

\lx ngurnungurnu

\de bush tobacco
\sd M Plants

\re Trichodesma zeylanica
\sy

\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv

\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This small plant has blue flowers and greyish leaves. It often grows in open areas. In old times the leaves were used as bush tobacco. They were dried in the sun and smoked in long-stemmed pipes called 'larrwa'. They can also be chewed like commercial tobacco.

\lx ngurragin
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge dingo
\de dingo
\sd H Mammals
\re dingo
\re Canis familiaris dingo
\sy warrayin
\va
\sc Canis familiaris dingo
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee 'Ngurragin' is used during certain ceremonies, and is a Dreaming for some people. In the past the scalps were collected and sold to the police as part of the control program. Old people used them as hunting companions, but they were always a bit wild and cheeky.

\re Trichosurus vulpecula

\xv

\ue
