\ge red-backed fairy-wren
\de red-backed fairy-wren
\sd J Birds
\re fairy-wren (red-backed)
\re red-backed fairy-wren
\re Malurus melanocephalus
\sy ninibing
\va
\sc Malurus melanocephalus
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This little bird often occurs in pandanus areas. Small children call it the devil-devil bird and they are told stories about how it used to be a man.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe

\lx ningal
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge yellow-faced.turtle
\de yellow-faced turtle
\sd I Reptiles
\re turtle (yellow-faced)
\re yellow-faced turtle
\re Emydura victoriae
\sy munggu
\va
\sc Emydura victoriae
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This turtle is generally caught on hand-lines when fishing, the meat is very tasty and highly sought after. They can also be caught by feeling around in the water in billabongs and slow moving parts of rivers. They are quite common. Sometimes they get very large swollen heads. These are called 'munggu'.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf

\lx nunggulma
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge freshwater.whipray
\de freshwater whipray
\sd K Water Animals
\re whipray (freshwater)
\re Himantura dalyensis
\sy
\va
\sc Himantura dalyensis
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The flesh can be eaten. It is very tasty as is the fat. The barb on the tail and body is very dangerous and must be broken off and thrown in the water or burnt on a fire as soon as it is caught. They can be speared or caught on a hand-line. When caught on a hand-line they must be pulled in quickly. If they settle down on the bottom of the river they cannot be pulled in.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 09/Sep/2015

\lx nuniny
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge bull.shark
\de bull shark
\sd K Water Animals
\re shark (bull)
\re bull shark
\re Carcharhinus leucas
\sy bernang
\sy gambarrngany
\va
\sc Carcharhinus leucas
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The flesh can be eaten and is very tasty. The fat is also good to eat. The large ones are hard to catch and pull ashore, when landed they must be hit hard and quickly on the head to kill them. When they thrash on the bank they are very dangerous.
\cf

\xv

\lx nyagurnang
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge rock.cod
\de rock cod, sleepy cod, giant gudgeon
\sd K Water Animals
\re cod (rock)
\re rock cod
\re cod (sleepy)
\re sleepy cod
\re gudgeon (giant)
\re Oxyeleotris lineolata
\re Oxyeleotris selheimi
\sy warn.guya
\sy munngarna
\sy dalwag
\va
\sc Oxyeleotris lineolata
\sc Oxyeleotris selheimi
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a word from the northern and western areas.
\ee These slow moving fish live in the deep waterholes; they sleep all day on the bottom. The flesh can be eaten after roasting on hot coals. Sometimes they can be caught in large numbers and they can get quite big.

\lx nyawunyawu
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge cat
\de cat
\sd H Mammals
\re cat
\re pussycat
\re Felis catus
\sy nyirrinyirri
\sy walumumba
\sy warlugurda
\sy wilirumawu
\sy nanguba
\sy ngaya
\sy bujigat
\va
\sc Felis catus
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a word from the northern and western areas.
\ee In the past people used to roast and eat the meat; it is tasty. Feral cats are good hunters and eat a lot of small native animals. The males, tom cats, can get very large and aggressive.
\cf
\pc cat.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf

\dt 09/Sep/2008

\lx nyimili
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge leichhardt.tree
\de Leichhardt tree
\sd M Plants
\re Leichhardt tree
\re Nauclea orientalis
\sy mulij, jamba
\va
\sc Nauclea orientalis
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This is a large tree that grows on rivers and near springs. It is a good shade tree. The fruit can be eaten when they are ripe, brown. The fruit that have fallen in the water are eaten by turtles (guwarlambarla) and black bream (gambajawung). When this tree has fruit it is a good time to go fishing. The yellow wood is light and relatively soft; however it can be used to make woomera shafts, light shields, coolamons and canoes. In the past it was used on stations to make gates. The wood was sawn on large circular saws driven by machines; the timber was left to dry for a month before it was sawn to allow the sap to dry out. The planks were doubled-up on the gates to make them stronger.
\cf
\pc jamba.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 27/Aug/2015

\xv Nyiny mani Nangala-rlu.

\sfx
\xe I'm going to blow that snot out, my nose is blocked.
\rf JC,CD:CJ:2018
\dt 15/Jul/2003

\lx nyinyiwurdu
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge porcupine
\de porcupine, echidna
\sd H Mammals
\re porcupine
\re echidna
\re Tachyglossus aculeatus
\sy bagabaga
\sy bagayawung
\sy jungguwurru
\sc Tachyglossus aculeatus
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee They often live in rocky country and are most active at night when they walk around looking for food. They are most active during full moon periods in the cold weather of the dry season. When they walk they leave a little track where the prickles drag along the ground. When approached they roll into a tight ball to protect themselves. They are often found in crevices in rocks and can be pulled out with a hooked branch or piece of wire. The prickles and feet are chopped off with a tomahawk prior to cooking the whole body in a ground oven. The meat is sweet and tastes like pork. There is a powerful creation period story about 'jungguwurru' that relates to how he got his prickles. It is a Dreaming animal for some people.
\cf
\pc echidna.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 09/Sep/2015

\lx nyinyji
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge lower.back
\de lower back, backbone, tail end, bum, rump of horse, abdomen (of insect)
\sd A Body
\re back (lower)
\re rump
\sy
\va
\ve
\sc
\so NH,MJ,DN:CJ:12/5/95, NH,KJ:CJ:5/6/95; NH,KJ:CJ:98, SK, RB, BW:ESB:93; ER:ESB:95; GC,CC:CJ,JM:2015
\xv Gula wirri banin nyinyji bani.
\sfx
\xe She didn't hit its neck, she hit its bottom.
\rf ER:JD:23/03/04
\xv Wagwag-gurlu-ma bani nyinyji-ga.
\sfx
\xe The crow hit him on his tail end.
\rf
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf Bilinarra
\lv nyinyji, larndi
\lf Gurindji
\lv maru
\lf Jaminjung
\lv mulurung
\lf Ngaliwurru
\lv jawul
\pc
\se
\de

\dt 06/Jul/2017

\lx nyirri
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge cicada
\de cicada
\sd L Insects and Spiders
\re cicada
\re Hemiptera, Cicadidae
\sy
\va
\sc Hemiptera, Cicadidae
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee These insects sit on the trunks and branches of trees and call very loudly during the hot weather of the build up, indicating that turtles (guwarlambarla) will be starting to move around again. They will be getting fat and begin laying their eggs. The hard skin cases are left on the trunks of trees when the adult insect emerges. Kids play with them sometimes.
\cf
\pc Cicada.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 21/Sep/2015

\lx nyirrili
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge spear.grass
\de spear grass
\sd M Plants
\re grass (spear)
\re spear grass
\re Sarga (Sorghum) intrans
\sy
\va
\sc Sarga (Sorghum) intrans
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This grass forms large stands during the wet season, when the rains stop the stems dry off and become brown. When this grass is burnt during the early dry season it cleans the country up and makes it healthy again.
\cf
\pc gilirrwarla.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 07/Sep/2015

\lx nyirrinyirri
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge cat
\de cat
\sd H Mammals
\re cat
\re pussycat
\re Felis catus
\sy nyawunyawu
\sy walumumba
\sy warlugurda
\sy wilirumawu
\sy nanguba
\sy ngaya
\sy bujigat
\va
\sc Felis catus
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a word from the northern and western areas.
\ee In the past people used to roast and eat the meat; it is tasty. Feral cats are good hunters and eat a lot of small native animals. The males, tom cats, can get very large and aggressive.
\cf
\pc cat2.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 22/Sep/2015

\lx nyulba
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge wild.coconut
\de wild coconut
\sd M Plants
\re coconut (wild)
\re wild coconut
\re Livistona victoriae
\sy walmad
\va
\sc Livistona victoriae
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The inner cabbage can be eaten. It is sweet and tasty. The cabbage is generally collected from younger palms and is obtained by chopping open the leaf bases to expose the pale cabbage. The cabbage is eaten raw and has a crisp, moist texture. The leaves can be used as coverings for food when cooking in ground ovens and as mats and plates for keeping food clean when serving it out.
\cf
\pc walmad.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 28/Aug/2015

\lx nyunurrbany
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge bush.onion
\de bush onion
\sd M Plants
\re bush onion
\re Cyperus bulbosus
\sy ginyuwurra
\va
\sc Cyperus bulbosus
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The small bulbs can be eaten. They are very tasty. They are easy to dig out of the ground as they are close to the surface and can often be collected in large amounts. In the past it was an important food source. They are lightly cooked in hot sand and then rubbed between the palms to loosen the dark papery skin. This is then blown away from the little yams. Brolgas and kangaroos also eat the small yams.
\cf
\pc ginyuwurra.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 04/Sep/2018

\lx nyurijman
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge shining.flycatcher
\de shining flycatcher, or grey fantail
\sd J Birds
\re flycatcher (shining)
\re grey fantail
\re Myiagra alecto
\sy
\va
\sc Myiagra alecto
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This bird is bit like a willie wagtail but it lives near creeks and rivers. It sings out nyurij...nyurij...nyurij. The grey fantail has the same name and is considered a countryman for the shining flycatcher.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 18/Mar/2018

\lx wajibad
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge bush.potato
\de bush potato
\sd M Plants
\re potato (bush)
\re bush potato
\re Brachystelma glabriflorum
\sy
\va
\sc Brachystelma glabriflorum
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The disc-shaped tuber is dug up, cleaned and eaten. It may also be lightly roasted. It is juicy and has a very pleasant starchy taste and is considered excellent food. The shoots appear in the early wet season after the first rains, however the yams are best later in the wet season when they are biggest and most juicy.

\lx warlayarra
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge bush.tobacco
\de bush tobacco
\sd M Plants
\re bush tobacco
\re tobacco (bush)
\re Lobelia arnhemica
\sy jarrinymawu
\sy lambalambarla
\sy marlmarlmaj
\va
\sc Lobelia arnhemica
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The dried plant can be chewed as bush tobacco; it is often mixed with commercial tobacco and some ash. In the past the old people chewed this before commercial tobacco was available. The plants are collected and dried in the sun for a period; they are then crushed before chewing. The Ngarinyman name 'jarrinymawu' means cave-dweller and refers to the fact that it grows in shaded areas under overhangs and generally near permanent water.
\cf
\pc warlayarra.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf

\dt 29/Nov/2011

\lx walmung
\sf
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge bush.paperbark
\de bush paperbark
\sd M Plants
\re paperbark (bush)
\re bush paperbark
\re Melaleuca nervosa
\sy
\va
\sc Melaleuca nervosa
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The papery bark can be used to light fires, although it is hard to pull off the trunk. The timber is good firewood. Sugarbag (native bee-hives) can be found in this tree.
\cf
\pc MelaleucaNervosa.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\sn 2
\ge paperbark
\de paperbark
\sd M Plants
\re paperbark
\re Melaleuca sericea
\re Melaleuca stenostachya
\sy
\va
\re Melaleuca sericea
\re Melaleuca stenostachya
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The papery bark can be used to make coolamons. The odorous leaves can be used as medicine. They may be crushed in the hands and inhaled, or boiled in water and the liquid used as an external wash to treat colds and congestion. The leaves can also be burnt on a fire and the smoke allowed to waft around. This has the effect of chasing away bad spirits and making you feel a lot better.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 26/Aug/2015

\lx walu
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge head
\de head
\sd A Body
\re head
\sy ngarlaga, gulaga
\va
\ve
\sc
\so RB,MP,ER:ESB:93, NH,MJ,DN:CJ:12/5/95, MW:CJ:94; NH,KJ,JK,ES:CJ,JM:8/7/15

\lx -warlug
\sf
\ps adv
\sn
\ge first
\de first

\rf ER:CM:2008

\dt 12/Sep/2008

\lx walugbiny
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge red-tailed.black-cockatoo
\de red-tailed black-cockatoo
\sd J Birds
\re black-cockatoo (red-tailed)
\re Calyptorhynchus banksi
\sy
\va
\sc Calyptorhynchus banksi
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The red feathers are used in ceremony. The meat can be eaten and is tasty. They were eaten in the past but have not been eaten in recent times. They like to eat the fruit from 'marndayang' (bush pear).
\cf
\pc red_tailed_black_cockatoo.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 08/Sep/2015

\lx walujabi
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge black-headed.python
\de black-headed python, piebald snake
\sd I Reptiles
\re python (black-headed)
\re black-headed python
\re Aspidites melanocephalus
\sy namijnamij
\sy waluru
\va
\sc Aspidites melanocephalus
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This python has a distinctive black shiny head. It is roasted in a ground oven with hot rocks and paperbark and the flesh eaten. There is a very important creation period or Dreaming story for this snake and a number of sacred and significant sites associated with this story. It has the 'Namij' skin and is sometimes referred by this name, although 'walujabi' is the most commonly used name. 'Walujabi' has a long and powerful Dreaming line that travels across many language areas from saltwater country in the north across the Top End and down through the desert areas of central Australia.
\cf
\pc black_headed_python.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 11/Oct/2016

\lx walumumba
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge cat
\de cat
\sd H Mammals
\re cat
\re pussycat
\re Felis catus
\sy nyawunyawu
\sy nyirrinyirri
\sy warlugurda
\sy wilirumawu
\sy nanguba
\sy ngaya
\sy bujigat
\sy nyudinyudi
\va
\sc Felis catus
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee In the past people used to roast and eat the meat; it is tasty. Feral cats are good hunters and eat a lot of small native animals. The males, tom cats, can get very large and aggressive.
\cf
\pc cat3.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 22/Sep/2015

\lx waluru
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge black-headed.python
\de black-headed python
\sd I Reptiles
\re python (black-headed)
\re black-headed python
\re Aspidites melanocephalus
\sy namijnamij
\sy walujabi
\va
\sc Aspidites melanocephalus
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a Yarralin word.
\ee This python has a distinctive black shiny head. It is roasted in a ground oven with hot rocks and paperbark and the flesh eaten. There is a very important creation period or Dreaming story for this snake and a number of sacred and significant sites associated with this story. It has the 'Namij' skin and is sometimes referred by this name, although 'Walujabi' is the most commonly used name. 'Walujabi' has a long and powerful Dreaming line that travels across many language areas from saltwater country in the north across the Top End and down through the desert areas of central Australia.
\cf
\pc black_headed_python.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf

\lx wambana
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge spectacled.hare-wallaby
\de spectacled hare-wallaby
\sd H Mammals
\re hare-wallaby (spectacled)
\re Lagorchestes conspicillatus
\sy
\va
\sc Lagorchestes conspicillatus
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This short, solid wallaby has distinctive orange fur around its eyes. It sleeps in a tunnel in grass or under dense shade in the day and feeds at night. In the past they were eaten and the meat was tasty. They have not been seen as much in recent times but sometimes are seen in the southern Ngarinyman areas.
\cf
\pc wambana.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf

\sfx

\rf

\ge blind-snake
\de blind-snake
\sd I Reptiles

\xv

\re Corvus orru
\sy wagwag
\sy wanggina
\va
\sc Corvus bennetti
\sc Corvus orru
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx

\ee There is an important creation period story about 'wangguriny'.

\lx wanya
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge sweetheart
\de boyfriend, girlfriend, sweetheart
\sd B People

\sy bulyab

\lf Jaminjung
\lv juwud
\pc

\xv
\sfx
\xe

\dt 03/Jul/2017

\lx wanyarri
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge bauhinia.tree
\de bauhinia tree
\sd M Plants
\re bauhinia tree
\re Bauhinia cunninghamii
\sy
\va
\sc Bauhinia cunninghamii
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The inner red bark makes good medicine. It is boiled in water and the liquid is used as a wash and a little is drunk to treat headaches, colds and skin sores. The outer bark is burnt to a fine white ash which is then added to chewing tobacco. The leaves can be chewed to treat colds. Sugarbag (native bee-hives) can be found in this tree. The red flowers can be sucked to get the sweet nectar. When the flowers are produced it indicates that the hot weather of the build-up will begin soon. The fruit are called 'gurrubardu' because when they are young they are bright red and are shaped like a boomerang. The leaves can be chewed when you are thirsty and in need of water. This helps to produce saliva and stops the feeling of intense thirst. The wood is good firewood as it burns evenly for a long time and the coals last for a long time. It is good for cooking dampers and was used in the stock camps commonly in the past.
\cf
\pc wanyarri.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 17/Aug/2015

\lx wanyarringarna
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge cattle
\de cattle, bullock
\sd H Mammals
\re cattle
\re bullock
\re Bos taurus
\re Bos indicus
\sy burruna
\sy barrayarna
\sy bulugi
\va
\sc Bos taurus
\sc Bos indicus
\so NH,KJ,PS:CJ:98
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The meat is very good to eat after roasting. In recent times brahmans have become very common and shorthorns have become less common. Shorthorns are generally easier to handle in yards and are less likely to charge, while brahmans are more dangerous. The meat from shorthorns has better flavour and is more tender. This name refers to how these cattle are often found in stands of 'wanyarri' trees.
\cf
\pc cow.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 22/Feb/2018

\lx wanyayawung
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge emu
\de emu
\sd J Birds
\re emu
\re Dromaius novae-hollandiae
\sy nangurrungurru
\sy yibarrardu
\va
\sc Dromaius novae-hollandiae
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The meat is good to eat, although it is dark red and has a strong smell. Some people don't like the taste of the meat. There is lot of meat on one bird and they are usually cooked in a ground oven. The small chicks have stripes on their bodies and are called 'winini' and 'wididij'. In the past they were hunted with spears and boomerangs, now they are hunted with shotguns. They eat various bush-tucker fruit, especially the black plum (muying). This bird has special cultural significance for Ngarinyman people.
\cf
\pc emu.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 07/Sep/2015

\lx wanymirra
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge bush.yam
\de bush yam
\sd M Plants
\re yam (bush)
\re bush yam
\re Vigna lanceolata var. lanceolata
\sy
\va
\sc Vigna lanceolata var. lanceolata
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The tubers are similar to sweet potatoes and they can be about as big as your hand. They are dug up and lightly roasted or boiled before eating. The yam is fairly stringy and needs to be chewed a lot. This yam grows in dark sandy soils, when you see the leaves and stems drying out it means it is time to start harvesting the yams as they will be at their tastiest full of juicy flesh. The flowers are yellow in colour and it often grows on red loamy soils. It is closely related to 'wayida', but is larger and grows on different country. It has longer, thinner yams that taste quite different.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 07/Sep/2015

\lx warugngarna
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge worker
\de worker, a working person
\sd B People
\re worker
\sy
\va
\ve
\sc
\so NH:CJ:3/6/95; NH,JC:CJ,JM:2015
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This word derives from the English word for 'work'. It was a term used to describe Aboriginal people who did hard domestic or stock work on stations.

\lx wardaba
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge Gould's.goanna
\de Gould's goanna
\sd I Reptiles
\re goanna (Gould's)
\re Gould's goanna
\re Varanus gouldi
\sy bawayangarna
\va
\sc Varanus gouldi
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The flesh can be eaten after roasting. It is very tasty. This goanna often digs deep holes and can be tracked to the holes and then dug out. Often the holes have to be dug very deep and a lot of work is required to get the goanna out. 'Bawayangarna' is the female of this species, 'wardaba' is the male.
\cf
\pc Varanus_gouldii.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 21/Sep/2015

\re pussycat

\sy nyirrinyirri
\sy walumumba
\sy warlugurda
\sy nanguba
\sy ngaya
\sy bujigat
\sy wilirumawu
\va
\sc Felis catus
\so DR,LR:GW,KH:2007
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a Timber Creek word.
\ee In the past people used to roast and eat the meat; it is tasty. Feral cats are good hunters and eat a lot of small native animals. The males, tom cats, can get very large and aggressive. This name refers to its big head.

\dt 07/Sep/2018

\lx warlagarri
\sf
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge tree.species
\de type of tree
\sd M Plants
\re Ehretia saligna
\sy
\va
\sc Ehretia saligna
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The dry, straight stems can be used for fire-sticks. The hard heavy timber can be used to make weapons such as boomerangs and fighting-sticks.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\sn 2
\ge supplejack
\de supplejack
\sd M Plants
\re supplejack
\re Ventilago viminalis
\sy
\va
\sc Ventilago viminalis
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This tree has very hard wood. The timber of large trees can be used to make boomerangs. The straight stems of young trees can be used to make nulla-nullas and shields. The timber is good to work with as it is hard, but relatively easy to shape and sand. When it is sanded back and polished it becomes very shiny and looks nice; it is similar to the wood to the conkerberry (ngamanburru).
\cf
\pc warlagarri.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 07/Sep/2018

\sy wangarni
\sy guru
\sy miji

\sc Canis familiaris

\lx warlarri
\sf
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge white.gum
\de white gum
\sd M Plants
\re gum (white)
\re white gum
\re Corymbia grandifolia
\sy
\va
\sc Corymbia grandifolia
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The timber is good firewood. Didgeridoos may be made from straight, hollow branches and stems. Sugarbag (native bee-hives) can be found in this tree.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\sn 2
\ge ghost.gum
\de ghost gum
\sd M Plants
\re gum (ghost)
\re ghost gum
\re Eucalyptus papuana (Corymbia bella)
\sy
\va
\sc Eucalyptus papuana (Corymbia bella)
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The timber is good firewood as it burns slowly and evenly. The timber is good for making stockyards and gates as it splits well and evenly. The outer smooth white bark is burnt to form a fine white ash which is added to chewing tobacco. Sugarbag (native bee-hives) can be found in this tree.
\cf
\pc walarri.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf

\lx warlgan
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge sand.goanna
\de sand goanna, plains goanna
\sd I Reptiles
\re goanna (sand)
\re sand goanna
\re goanna (plains)
\re plains goanna
\re Varanus panoptes
\sy girrawa
\sy jurlumirri
\sy dilyarri
\va
\sc Varanus panoptes
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a Yarralin word.
\ee This is the biggest goanna. It can get very large and has a lot of tasty flesh. The language name can also be used to refer to goannas in general, however, they are used for this goanna as it is the largest and best known. 'Girrawa' is the male of this species. 'Warlgan' is the term used in Yarralin for the female of this species.
\cf
\pc Varanus_panoptes.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx

\rf

\lx warnayag ngagbarn
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge cane.toad
\de cane toad
\sd I Reptiles
\re toad (cane)
\re Rhinella marina
\sy ngurlgurna, warnayag ngalyja, jalgarni
\va
\sc Rhinella marina
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This large toad has been in the area for a few years and it has large poison glands near the ears. They are dangerous. When they first arrived many goannas disappeared but now they are starting to come back. The language names refer to a strange or new frog.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf

\lx warndawarndang
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge green.tree.snake
\de green tree snake, brown tree snake
\sd I Reptiles
\re tree snake (green)
\re tree snake (brown)
\re Dendrelaphis punctulata
\re Boiga irregularis
\sy jamarlangmarlang
\sy ginirriny
\va
\sc Dendrelaphis punctulata
\sc Boiga irregularis
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a word from the northern and western areas.
\ee This is a harmless snake that lives in trees, especially pandanus and other trees near rivers and creeks. It cannot hurt you but can give you a fright when it appears close to you when you are fishing. It is considered to be a naughty snake as it does not follow cultural laws. It has a small brain, and it plays up a lot.
\cf
\pc green_tree_snake.jpg

\de
\xv
\sfx

\rf

\lx warnmala
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge pencil.yam
\de pencil yam
\sd M Plants
\re yam (pencil)
\re pencil yam
\re Vigna lanceolata var. latifolia
\sy wayida
\va
\sc Vigna lanceolata var. latifolia
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The small yams are dug up and may be eaten raw or lightly boiled or roasted. They are very tasty and can be collected in large quantities although the yams are quite small. In the past they were collected in large numbers and were an important food resource. The younger, smaller yams have a very pleasant, clean taste. The older yams become a little fibrous and are less tasty although still edible. This yam grows on red ground or sandy country. It often occurs in large numbers in a fairly small area.
\cf
\pc wayida.jpg
\se
\de
\xv Warnmala mangarri bunyu.
\sfx
\xe Pencil yam is good food.
\rf ER:ESB:94
\dt 6/Aug/2018

\dt 07/Sep/2015

\lx warrag
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge silver.catfish
\de silver catfish
\sd K Water Animals
\re catfish (silver)
\re silver catfish
\re Arius graeffei
\sy jarrbungu
\va
\sc Arius graeffei
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This is a catfish that has a shorter nose than other species. The flesh and fat can be eaten after roasting in hot coals. Sometimes when they are pulled up on the bank they make an oinking noise a bit like a pig. The spines or prickles on the fins are dangerous. They contain poison and if they prick the skin it causes severe pain and swelling. The spines are broken off and burnt on the fire, thrown in the water or placed in a safe place. If the spine pokes into you, you must slap the area with the tail of the fish; this stops the pain and swelling.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 09/Sep/2015

\lx warrayin
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge dingo
\de dingo
\sd H Mammals
\re dingo
\re Canis familiaris dingo
\sy ngurragin
\va
\sc Canis familiaris dingo
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a Timber Creek word.
\ee 'Ngurragin' is used during certain ceremonies, and is a Dreaming for some people. In the past the scalps were collected and sold to the police as part of the control program. Old people used them as hunting companions, but they were always a bit wild and cheeky.

\lx warrija
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge freshwater.crocodile
\de freshwater crocodile, little crocodile
\sd I Reptiles
\re crocodile (freshwater)
\re freshwater crocodile
\re crocodile (little)
\re Crocodylus johnstoni
\sy laging
\sy darrmard
\va
\sc Crocodylus johnstoni
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The meat can be eaten after roasting on hot coals or cooking in a ground oven like a goanna. They are often caught on hand-lines when fishing, and they can be hit over the head with a crowbar to kill them. In the past the men used to hunt them with spears, and they were eaten more commonly than they are now. The eggs are also eaten after boiling; they are good to eat. The tracks of the mother are followed to the nest and the sand dug out and the eggs collected.
\cf
\pc freshwater_croc.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 22/Sep/2015

\sy ngalijirri

\sy jardugarl

\sc Macropus antilopinus
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe

\ue This is a Yarralin word.
\ee This kangaroo generally lives on grassy plains, often on red soil country. It is tall and thin compared to the hill kangaroo. Plains kangaroos have special significance for Ngarinyman people. It is a Dreaming for some people.

\lx wawurru

\lx wayida
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge pencil.yam
\de pencil yam
\sd M Plants
\re yam (pencil)
\re pencil yam
\re Vigna lanceolata var. latifolia
\sy warnmala
\va
\sc Vigna lanceolata var. latifolia
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The small yams are dug up and may be eaten raw or lightly boiled or roasted. They are very tasty and can be collected in large quantities although the yams are quite small. In the past they were collected in large numbers and were an important food resource. The younger, smaller yams have a very pleasant, clean taste. The older yams become a little fibrous and are less tasty although still edible. This yam grows on red ground or sandy country. It often occurs in large numbers in a fairly small area.
\cf
\pc wayida.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 07/Sep/2015

\lx wayildi
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge bush.tea-leaf
\de bush tea-leaf
\sd M Plants
\re bush tea-leaf
\re Ocimum caryophyllinum
\sy jilinbug
\sy nalija
\va
\sc Ocimum caryophyllinum
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a Yarralin word.
\ee The leaves are boiled in water to make tea to drink. It has a strong smell and pleasant taste. The tea made from this plant also has medicinal qualities and is good to treat colds and congestion. In the past this plant was used a lot by old people as tea. There is a lot of it growing on Waterloo Station. The liquid can also be used as a wash to treat itchy sores and skin. The drink is also good for providing sustenance when walking a long way, especially if there is no food to be found. The tea can keep you going until food is found. It makes you strong when you are feeling weak. The word 'nalija' is also used to refer to commercial tea that is available from shops.
\cf
\pc juminjumin.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 04/Sep/2018

\lx wayiningan
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge cattle
\de cattle, bullock
\sd H Mammals
\re cattle
\re bullock
\re Bos taurus
\re Bos indicus
\sy burruna
\sy barrayarna
\sy bulugi
\sy wanyarringarna
\va
\sc Bos taurus
\sc Bos indicus
\so ER:ESB
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a Timber Creek word.
\ee The meat is very good to eat after roasting. In recent times brahmans have become very common and shorthorns have become less common. Shorthorns are generally easier to handle in yards and are less likely to charge, while brahmans are more dangerous. The meat from shorthorns has better flavour and is more tender.
\cf
\pc cow.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 23/Feb/2018

\lx widijburru
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge spinifex.pigeon
\de spinifex pigeon, Indian-head pigeon
\sd J Birds
\re pigeon (spinifex)
\re spinifex pigeon
\re pigeon (Indian-head)
\re Indian-head pigeon
\re Geophaps plumifera
\sy garlarr
\sy garlawarra
\sy marrawung
\va
\sc Geophaps plumifera
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The Spinifex Pigeon is sometimes called Indian-head because of the feathers sticking up from its head and it has a stripe on its face similar to war-paint. It has a distinctive call: coo.coo.coo.coo.coo.coo. Sometimes it is called 'gumundunga' in reference to the feathers sticking up on its head. The name 'widijburru' is also the personal name of Bobby Widijburru. The meat can be eaten after roasting and it is tender and tasty.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 07/Sep/2018

\sn

\de freshwater mussel
\sd K Water Animals

\re freshwater mussel
\re Velesunio wilsoni
\sy dugu
\sy narubu
\sy daga

\xv

\ue
\ee This big, solid mussel is found in the sand and mud at the edges of billabongs, creeks and rivers. They are eaten after roasting on hot coals or boiling in water. They are tasty. 'Wijalngarniny' occur in stony areas, not sandy or muddy areas.

\sd M Plants
\re Phyllanthus reticulatus
\sy
\va
\sc Phyllanthus reticulatus

\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf

\lx wirlid
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge plum
\de plum
\sd M Plants
\re plum
\re Grewia breviflora
\sy
\va
\sc Grewia breviflora
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The fruit can be eaten when they turn brown. They are sweet and very tasty. Spears can be made from the straight stems. The outer bark is removed and the shaft straightened over hot coals. Small smooth straight stems and branches can be used as firesitcks to create fire using the traditional drilling and friction method.
\cf

\lx wirriwurnany
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge northern.long-necked.turtle
\de northern long-necked turtle
\sd I Reptiles
\re turtle (northern long-necked)
\re northern long-necked turtle
\re Chelodina oblonga
\sy burdunburru
\va
\sc Chelodina oblonga
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee These turtles have long necks and are very good to eat. They can be caught on hand-lines when fishing, but are also found in the drying mud around billabongs when the water retreats in the dry season. The drying mud is poked with crowbars until the turtles are found and then they can be dug out of the mud with a crowbar. They only occur in the more northern areas of Ngarinyman country.
\cf
\pc long_neck_turtle.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf

\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf Bilinarra
\lv wiwarlb

\de swish, flick from side to side (of e.g. crocodile's, horse's tail)

\dt 11/Sep/2005

\lx wubgaji
\sf
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge willings.tree
\de Willing's tree
\sd M Plants
\re Willing's tree
\re Grevillea dimidiata
\sy duwiman
\va
\sc Grevillea dimidiata
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee When the fruit turn black they have a shiny resinous coating. This substance can cause blistering if it is allowed get in contact with skin. In the past the fruit were rubbed on the body to cause scarring when participating in ceremonies.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\sn 2
\ge beefwood
\de beefwood
\sd M Plants
\re beefwood
\re Grevillea striata
\sy
\va
\sc Grevillea striata
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The hard, dark wood is used to make boomerangs, clap-sticks and nulla-nullas. It is also good firewood. This type of 'wubgaji' is considered to be the mother of 'mindiwirri'.
\cf
\pc jawilyi.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 26/Aug/2015

\lx wubub
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge pheasant.coucal
\de pheasant coucal
\sd J Birds
\re pheasant coucal
\re Centropus phasianinus
\sy durldurl
\sy girribudbuda
\va
\sc Centropus phasianinus
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee 'Wubwub' calls woop...woop...woop in the wet season to make the cheeky yam (jarrwana) grow fat and produce lots of seed. It is a large, dark brown bird that often runs along the ground and then flies up into a tree.
\cf
\pc pheasant.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 08/Sep/2015

\lx wuduyawung
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge sandstone.bush.cucumber
\de sandstone bush cucumber
\sd M Plants
\re bush cucumber (sandstone)
\re cucumber (sandstone)
\re Cucumis melo
\sy gayinbarla
\va
\sc Cucumis melo
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This type of bush cucumber grows on sandstone areas and has fruit that are bitter and are only eaten by rock-wallabies (wugardij) and hill kangaroos (minawud).
\cf
\pc gaaril.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 06/Sep/2015

\lx wugardij
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge rock-wallaby
\de rock-wallaby, short-eared rock-wallaby
\sd H Mammals
\re rock-wallaby
\re rock-wallaby (short-eared)
\re Petrogale brachyotis
\sy
\va
\sc Petrogale brachyotis
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The meat can be eaten after roasting. This small kangaroo lives in rocky areas and moves around very quickly. It is too fast to be speared and in the past they were hunted by finding the paths they travel on and setting a hunter with a stick to wait. Other hunters would scare the rock-wallaby so that it hopped down the track towards the other waiting hunter who would hit it hard with the stick. They could also be caught by the tail by the waiting hunter and cracked like a whip to kill them. They could also be hunted into caves by lighting a fire and they would hide in the caves to avoid the fire. They could then be chased out and hit with a stick as they hopped out of the cave. Rock pythons (baninggula) often hunt them in caves and crevices in sandstone country.
\cf
\pc short_eared_rock_wallaby.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 09/Sep/2015

\dt 6/Aug/2018

\lx wulungari
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge wild.passionfruit
\de wild passionfruit
\sd M Plants
\re passionfruit (wild)
\re Passiflora foetida
\sy girribi
\va
\sc Passiflora foetida
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a word from the northern and western areas.
\ee The inner flesh of the yellow-orange fruit can be eaten. It is especially favoured by children. Many birds also eat the fruit. The leaves can be boiled in water and the liquid used as a wash to treat scabies, itchy skin and ringworm. The leaves and stems can also be used as fish poison. They are dragged through the water and this has the effect of stunning the fish so that they float to the surface and can be easily collected, then cooked and eaten. The slightly sticky leaves and stems must not be put near your eyes as the juice can cause very sore eyes.
\cf
\pc passionfruit.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 06/Sep/2015

\lx wurlurr

\ee

\rf BB:CM:2007
\xv Gula-n-jini wulurr barru!
\xe Don't kill those (dogs)!
\rf ER:ESB:94

\lx wuluyung
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge black.ant
\de black ant
\sd L Insects and Spiders
\re ant (black)
\re Hymenoptera; Formicidae, Ochetellus spp.
\sy
\va
\sc Hymenoptera; Formicidae, Ochetellus spp.
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee These small black ants are attracted to sweet foods, such as sugar and honey; they are often seen in kitchens and around areas where food is prepared.
\cf
\pc ants.jpg
\se

\dt 21/Sep/2015

\lx wulwaji
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge coolibah
\de coolibah
\sd M Plants
\re coolibah
\re Eucalyptus microtheca
\sy gininggi
\sy gunjalng
\va
\sc Eucalyptus microtheca
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a Yarralin word.
\ee Sugarbag (native bee-hives) can be found in this tree. The timber is good firewood for cooking. Didgeridoos can be made from hollowed stems and branches of a suitable size. The bark can be burnt to a fine white ash which is mixed with chewing tobacco. When 'wulwaji' is in flower it indicates that sharks are fat and it is a good time to hunt for them.
\cf
\pc coolibah.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 25/Aug/2015

\lx wumburrurru
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge buffalo
\de buffalo
\sd H Mammals
\re buffalo
\re Bubalus bubalis
\sy mun.gurru
\sy windurru
\sy windurruyawung
\sy maranji
\sy gardbibarndal
\va
\sc Bubalus bubalis
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a word from the northern and western areas.
\ee There are occasionally wild buffalo still seen but most were killed during the BTEC scheme in the 1980s and 1990s. The meat is good to eat, especially from young ones. It has a strong taste. Buffalo are cranky and dangerous in the bush.

\xv
\sfx

\lx wulngawulngarn
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge military.dragon
\de military dragon, tata lizard
\sd I Reptiles
\re military dragon
\re lizard (tata)
\re tata lizard
\re Ctenophorus isolepis
\re Diporiphora spp.
\re Lophognathus spp.
\sy marndalyji, ligarda
\va
\sc Ctenophorus isolepis
\sc Diporiphora spp.
\sc Lophognathus spp.
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a Yarralin word.
\ee These small lizards often wave their front leg in the air, there are many different types, some are male and some are female. They are used in some ceremonies and there is a special site for them. The name 'wulngawulngarn' is based on the word for sun (wulngarn) because this lizard often looks at the sun.
\cf
\pc tata_lizard.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 20/Sep/2015

\dt 15/Jul/2003

\lx wurlurl
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge yellow-belly.catfish
\de yellow-belly catfish, silver cobbler
\sd K Water Animals
\re catfish (yellow-belly)
\re yellow-belly catfish
\re yellow-belly catfish
\re silver cobbler
\re Arius midgleyi
\sy
\va
\sc Arius midgleyi
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This is a very large catfish that is good to eat. The flesh and fat can be eaten after roasting in hot coals. If a really large one is caught it will need two or three people to pull it in. The spines or prickles on the fins are dangerous. They contain poison and if they prick the skin it causes severe pain and swelling. The spines are broken off and burnt on the fire, thrown in the water or placed in a safe place. If the spine pokes into you, you must slap the area with the tail of the fish. This stops the pain and swelling. Baby catfish are called 'nginnyirda'.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 09/Sep/2015

\xe I want to go fishing.
\rf NH: JM1-001-02 2016: 00:19:04
\xv Yanin-barna wuyurrun.garra.
\sfx
\xe I went fishing.
\rf NH: JM1-001-01 2016: 00:18:47
\xv Galurirrb-barna yana wuyurrun.garra.
\sfx
\xe I'm going fishing.
\rf NH: JM1-001-01 2016: 00:13:16
\dt 26/Jun/2007

\se yalurlu
\de that one did it
\se yalangga

\de thither, to that place

\sfx
\xe Men can't go to that place.

\se yalanginyi

\xv Well, yalanginyi-ma,...
\sfx

\lx yalyirra
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge smoke.tree
\de smoke tree
\sd M Plants
\re smoke tree
\re Eucalyptus pruinosa
\sy jarnbiny
\va
\sc Eucalyptus pruinosa
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a Yarralin word.
\ee Stems and branches that have been hollowed by termites and are of the appropriate diameter can be made into didgeridoos. Sugarbag (native bee-hives) can be found in this tree. Timber from young plants can be use to make fighting sticks or nulla-nullas. The inner bark is chopped off the trunk and boiled in a little water. This liquid is drunk to treat colds, flu and fever and for general sickness. It also relieves pain of sore muscles and general soreness.
\cf
\pc jarnbij.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 25/Aug/2015

\ue
\ee

\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\sn 2
\ge photo
\de photo, picture, video
\sd D Things
\re photo
\re picture
\re video
\sy wujba, yardiwaji, yardiwu

\ve
\sc

\ee

\dt 23/Feb/2018

\lx yarrangun
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge wallaroo
\de wallaroo, blue or hill kangaroo, euro
\sd H Mammals
\re wallaroo
\re kangaroo (blue)
\re blue kangaroo
\re kangaroo (hill)
\re hill kangaroo
\re Euro
\re Macropus robustus
\sy minawud
\sy garriwarna
\sy winangburru
\va
\sc Macropus robustus
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee These kangaroos are often seen in hilly areas and are good to eat after roasting. They are often called the blue kangaroo due to the dark, woolly fur that is bluish in colour. 'Yarrangun' is a term used for the female of this species.
\cf
\pc euro.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 09/Sep/2015

\dt 06/Jul/2017

\lx yarrgalany
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge hairy.yam
\de hairy yam
\sd M Plants
\re yam (hairy)
\re hairy yam
\re Aponogeton vanbruggenii
\sy
\va
\sc Aponogeton vanbruggenii
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee This yam grows in water and wet areas, the yam flesh is white. You can cook it and eat the flesh. It grows near billabongs in wet areas. The yam has hair on it like the waterlily (jigamuru) and the cheeky yam (jarrwana). In the past this yam was common but it is not seen much now.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 07/Sep/2015

\lx yarrigan
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge red.meat.ant
\de meat ant, red meat ant
\sd L Insects and Spiders
\re ant (meat)
\re Hymenoptera spp.
\re Formicidae spp.
\sy
\va
\sc Hymenoptera spp.
\sc Formicidae spp.
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee These ants form well-worn tracks on the ground between their burrows; they are attracted to meat and other foods and can be a nuisance when you are camping in the bush.
\cf
\pc ants.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf

\lx yawarlwarl

\ge crested.pigeon
\de crested pigeon
\sd J Birds
\re pigeon (crested)
\re crested pigeon
\re Ocyphaps lophotes
\sy jardibal
\va
\sc Ocyphaps lophotes
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf

\ee When they call out coo...coo...coo it indicates someone is approaching. The meat can be eaten after lightly roasting on hot coals and ashes.

\dt 07/Sep/2018

\lx yibarrardu
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge emu
\de emu
\sd J Birds
\re emu
\re Dromaius novae-hollandiae
\sy nangurrungurru
\sy wanyayawung
\va
\sc Dromaius novae-hollandiae
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a Yarralin word.
\ee The meat is good to eat, although it is dark red and has a strong smell. Some people don't like the taste of the meat. There is lot of meat on one bird and they are usually cooked in a ground oven. The small chicks have stripes on their bodies and are called 'winini' and 'wididij'. In the past they were hunted with spears and boomerangs, now they are hunted with shotguns. They eat various bush-tucker fruit, especially the black plum (muying). This bird has special cultural significance for Ngarinyman people.
\cf
\pc emu.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 07/Sep/2015

\lx yibu
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge rain
\de rain, rain-time
\sd G Environment
\re rain
\sy
\va
\ve
\sc
\so
\xv Yibu yanarnin janggarni.
\sfx
\xe A big rain is coming.
\rf
\xv Yibu warn.gunga jalanggula.
\sfx
\xe It might rain today.
\rf ER:ESB:4/5/2008, MP:ESB:93, MW:CJ:94
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf Bilinarra
\lv yibu
\lf Gurindji
\lv yipu
\lf Jaminjung
\lv gugu
\pc rain_nguku.jpg
\se

\dt 25/Nov/2011

\lx yiburru
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge black.flying-fox
\de black flying-fox
\sd H Mammals
\re flying-fox (black)
\re black flying-fox
\re Pteropus alecto
\sy najuna, warrba, dijuna
\va
\sc Pteropus alecto
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a Yarralin word.
\ee The flesh can be eaten after roasting. It has a strong distinctive smell and taste. In the past they were killed by throwing hunting sticks into the roosting colonies. Crocodiles eat them when they roost in paperbark trees hanging over rivers and billabongs. They are larger and more common than the red flying-fox. Flying-foxes have special cultural significance for Ngarinyman people.
\cf
\pc Black_flying_fox.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 09/Sep/2015

\lx yilanggi
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge rusty.bloodwood
\de rusty bloodwood
\sd M Plants
\re bloodwood (rusty)
\re Corymbia ferruginea
\sy narrga
\va
\sc Corymbia ferruginea
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee Sugarbag (native bee-hives) may be found in this tree and they are particularly sweet. Didgeridoos may be made from the hollow stems and branches. The timber is not good firewood as it burns very quickly and does not form coals. This species often occurs on sandy country.

\lx yilgiyang
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge swamp.leech
\de swamp leech
\sd L Insects and Spiders
\re leech (swamp)
\re Annelida
\re Hirudinea
\sy yulgiying
\va
\sc Annelida
\sc Hirudinea
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a Yarralin word. 'Yulgiying' is a Timber Creek pronunciation.
\ee These small worm-like animals live in water and wet areas. They attach to the skin and suck blood. When they are removed, the bleeding will not stop for a long period.
\cf
\pc Leech.jpg
\se

\dt 19/Mar/2018

\lx yilirli
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge white.apple
\de white apple
\sd M Plants
\re apple (white)
\re Syzygium eucalyptoides ssp. eucalyptoides
\sy bundul
\va
\sc Syzygium eucalyptoides ssp. eucalyptoides
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a word from the northern and western areas.
\ee This small tree grows in creek beds and on river banks. The fruit may be eaten when ripe, pale pink to white. They are especially favoured by children. When the fruit fall in rivers and creeks they are eaten by turtles (guwarlambarla), black bream (gambajawung) and catfish (warrag). The timber is good for cooking fish and turtles. The flowers are visited by native bees (lanu) who use the pollen and nectar for making honey.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 28/Aug/2015

\dt 11/Oct/2016

\lx yinarrwa
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge
\de barramundi
\sd K Water Animals
\re barramundi
\re Lates calcarifer
\sy manyirrgila
\sy manyin
\sy marna
\va
\sc Lates calcarifer
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a word from the northern and western areas.
\ee The flesh can be eaten after roasting on hot coals. It is very tasty. Barramundi can get large and are hard to catch as they fight hard to get off the line. They are common in billabongs and the big rivers. They are mostly caught using live bait on hand-lines, although visiting fishermen often catch them with lures and rods. There is an important creation period story about the barramundi, the shark and the stingray. Barramundi are totems or Dreaming animals for some people. 'Yinarrwa' and 'manyirrgila' refer to large-sized fish; 'manyin' and 'marna' refer to small fish.
\cf
\pc barramundi.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 22/Sep/2015

\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a word from the northern and western areas.
\ee In the past they were used at some places, like the Victoria River Downs, to carry loads. They could carry long and heavy loads and would sit down to be loaded and unloaded. They occur as feral animals further to the south.
\cf
\pc Camels.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf

\lx yirrban
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge flying-termites
\de flying-termites, flying-ants
\sd L Insects and Spiders
\re flying-ant
\re termite (flying)
\re ant (flying)
\re Isoptera
\sy
\va
\sc Isoptera
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee These flying insects are common after rain in the wet season and are often attracted to outside lights in large numbers. They are a favoured food of porcupines (jungguwurru) who hunt for them. The eggs, found in the ant hills, look like rice and can be collected and eaten.
\cf
\pc
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf

\lx yulgang
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge
\de grasshopper
\sd L Insects and Spiders
\re grasshopper
\re Orthoptera
\sy janyima
\sy bilbijing
\va
\sc Orthoptera
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a Yarralin word.
\ee There are many types of grasshoppers. They can be used for bait when fishing. In the past the old people used to lightly cook them and eat them. Sometimes they occur in large numbers and rather than flying they move along the ground. These can be easily caught.

\lx yulgiying
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge swamp.leech
\de swamp leech
\sd L Insects and Spiders
\re leech (swamp)
\re Annelida
\re Hirudinea
\sy yilgiyang
\va
\sc Annelida
\sc Hirudinea
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue This is a Timber Creek word. 'Yilgiyang' is the Yarralin pronunciation.
\ee These small worm-like animals live in water and wet areas. They attach to the skin and suck blood. When they are removed, the bleeding will not stop for a long period.

\dt 07/Sep/2018

\lx yumarli
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge bush.orange
\de bush orange
\sd M Plants
\re bush orange
\re orange (bush)
\re Capparis umbonata
\sy gurlinyaga
\sy juguru
\va
\sc Capparis umbonata
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The fruit are eaten when they are ripe, a slightly orange-yellow colour. The fruit are sweet and very tasty. The unripe fruit can be buried in the sand to help ripen them; sometimes this might take as long as two weeks. The wood can be used as firewood as it lights quickly and easily. When the fruit are ripe they have a strong pleasant smell, which can be noticed from a long way from the plant. It is difficult to stop eating the fruit when you can smell the sweet scent from them. The bark can be boiled in water and used as a washing medicine to treat scabies. When the large flooding rains of the full wet season are coming this plant can be used to chase the rains away. The leaves are placed on a fire to make smoke, and this is waved towards the rain clouds to make them go away.
\cf
\pc gurlardardi.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 19/Aug/2015

\lf Jaminjung

\lf Gurindji

\xv

\se yurdub manan
\de grind, sharpen
\xv Yurdub-barna mani.

\xe I'm grinding (the grass seeds).
\rf JC:JM1-012 2016 book 2, p6

\lx yurra
\sf
\ps cv
\sn
\ge hunt.away
\de hunt away, chase away (e.g. as white people did in the early days, or hunt away sickness with bush medicine)
\sd T Impact
\re chase away
\re hunt away
\sy
\va
\ve
\sc
\so NH:CJ:4/1/95, NH:CJ:98, ESB
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf Jaminjung
\lv yurruyi
\lf Gurindji
\lv yurra
\pc
\se yurra gangan
\de hunt something away
\xv Nyila-ma yurra ganga janga-ma gulyurru janga ngarlaga.
\sfx
\xe That hunts it away -- a sickness, a bad cold, a headache.
\rf
\xv Yurra ganya jalyi-nggu. Gulgulya yurra ganya.
\sfx
\xe The leaves hunted away that bad cold.
\rf NH:CJ:4/1/95, NH:CJ:98, ESB
\se yurrayurra gangan
\de hunt something away
\xv Yurrayurra-yina ganya, nyarruluny-nginyi ngurra-ngurlang.
\sfx
\xe (The white man) hunted them out, from their country.
\rf NH:CJ:98
\xv Gardiba-rlu-yina yurrayurra ganya, barlarrgu-nginyi, marlarluga, gajijirri, bush-ja.
\sfx
\xe The white man hunted them, from the open, men and women, in the bush.
\rf NH:CJ:7/6/95
\se yurra barrany
\de hunt something away, scare out, flush out prey
\xv Yurra-rna bani gulyjany ngurra-nginyi.
\sfx
\xe I hunted the snake out of the house.
\rf KJ:JM1-017 2016 book 2, p39
\se yurrayurra barrany
\de scare out, flush out prey
\xv Yurrayurra barrany jardgarra-wu, bilygiya-rlu.
\sfx
\xe The egret is going along hunting for food in the water.
\rf NH,KJ,JK:CJ:2005

\dt 23/Nov/2011

\lx yurrudu
\sf
\ps n
\sn
\ge bush.banana
\de bush banana
\sd M Plants
\re banana (bush)
\re bush banana
\re Marsdenia australis
\re Marsdenia viridiflora
\sy gilibi
\va
\sc Marsdenia australis,
\sc Marsdenia viridiflora
\so Ngarinyman plants and animals, Northern Territory Botanical Bulletin No 34, Dept of Natural Resources, Environment, The Arts and Sport & Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation, Darwin 2010
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee The fruit and leaves may be eaten. They are sweet and tasty. The young fruit are the best to eat as they are soft and crunchy. Older fruits become hard and chewy and they may be softened by lightly roasting on hot coals. The flowers can also be eaten. The new fruit that are found in the heavy rain time of the wet season are small and round, and contain a lot of juice; they are the tastiest to eat.
\cf
\pc gilibi.jpg
\se
\de
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\dt 06/Sep/2015

\sy bujigat

\de out of breath, breathless, "short wind" in Kriol
\sd Q State
\re breathless
\sy
\va
\ve
\sc
\so JC,CD,MS:CJ:2018
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf
\lv
\pc
\se jubuyubu garrany
\de there breathless, there out of breath
\xv Jubuyubu garrany, nyila mulurru, janga.
\sfx
\xe That old lady is out of breath because she's sick.
\rf JC,CD:CJ:2018
\dt 19/Jun/2018

\ue
\ee
\cf

\xe The child put weight on me.

\de put weight on something
\xv Nurd yuwarra, ngaja burruwib-gurlu ganggu.

\lx jiwarrb
\sf
\ps cv
\sn
\ge gather
\de gather up, hold together, muster
\sd U Holding and Taking
\re gather up
\re hold together
\re muster
\sy
\va juwarrb, jiwarr
\ve
\sc
\so JC,CD,MS:CJ:2018
\so NH:CJ:98
\xv
\sfx
\xe
\rf
\ue
\ee
\cf
\lf Jaminjung
\lv garrb
\lf Bilinarra
\lv garrb
\lf Gurindji
\lv jiwarr
\pc gather.jpg
\se jiwarrb manan
\de gather up, collect
\xv Jiwarrb-barna mani ngayiny wabawaba.
\sfx
\xe I collected my clothes.
\xv Jiwarr mani balarrgu-nginyi.
\sfx
\rf JC,CD,MS:CJ:2018
\xe He mustered up the horses from the open.
\rf NH:CJ:7/6/95
\xv Mangarri jiwarr manan, nyambanginyi?
\sfx
\xe Why are you gathering together the food? (said to a child)
\rf
\xv Jiwarrb manin mangarri garu-nggu.
\sfx
\xe The kids collected the bread.
\rf
\xv Mangarri-rna jiwarrb mana.
\sfx
\xe I pick up all the food.
\rf NH:JM1-006 2016 book 1, p59
\dt 30/Jun/2018

\ps n
\ge placename
\de Buffalo Hole which is located near Lingara
\sd O Place Names
\re
\so Riley Young with JL and FM; JL?s map as prompt
\pc
\cf
\dt 15/Jul/2015
